PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Telecom: Metered Calls
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. that the public is overwhelmingly opposed to Telecom's plans to introduce time charges for local calls;
2. that while Telecom remains a public enterprise, it must be accountable to the public, its owners; and
3. while Telecom retains a statutory monopoly which shields it from the discipline of competition, it should not be unilaterally allowed to impose extortionate charges upon the public.
Your petitioners therefore respectfully call upon all members of the Senate in Parliament assembled to take action to prevent Telecom introducing time charges for local calls.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Telecom: Metered Calls
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the introduction of time-charging for local telephone calls by Telecom Australia would seriously disadvantage thousands of elderly and disabled people and families, and would add a further burden to the already prohibitive cost of living borne by every Australian.
That accordingly the Senate and Parliament should reject any plans by Telecom to time-charge local telephone calls.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Telecom: Metered Calls
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth:
(1) That we oppose timed local calls by Telecom.
(2) Timed calls should not be introduced in the absence of widespread community support.
(3) Timed calls will seriously affect pensioners, the elderly, low income earners and other disadvantaged groups.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Elector-Initiated Referenda
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That although elector-initiated referendums are conducted successfully in such countries as Switzerland and the U.S.A., no such facility exists for Australian citizens.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should:
Initiate the necessary action for a referendum to be held to amend the Constitution to provide for such an initiative on the following conditions:

If a specified percentage of voters (such as 2%) sign a petition asking that a referendum be held on a certain question the Federal Government would be obliged to hold that referendum and the result would become law.
And your petitioners further humbly pray that the referendum be timed to coincide with the referendum to be held to extend the term of office of the House of Representatives from 3 to 4 years.
And we humbly pray that you may be conscious of God's sovereign purpose for our Nation. And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Constitution Alteration Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
1. the right of the people of a country to make law independent of politicians should be a basic and independent right;
2. consequently there is an urgent need for constitutional reforms.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled, should:
support the Constitutional Alteration (Electors Initiative) 1987 Bill to alter the constitution so as to vest in the electors power to propose laws and to approve or disapprove such proposed laws.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Human Embryo Experimentation Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled-

The petition of the undersigned express concern that some scientists in Australia are intent on undertaking destructive experimentation on human embryos. This subject was examined exhaustively by the 1985-86 Senate Select Committee on Senator Harradine's Human Embryo Experimentation Bill which received 270 submissions and more than 2,000 pages of evidence. The report of the Senate Committee recommended in October 1986 that the Commonwealth Government make unlawful any destructive experiment which frustrated the development of the human embryo.
Your petitioners therefore request the Senate and the Government of the Commonwealth of Australia to:
Implement without delay the major recommendation of the Senate Select Committee to outlaw destructive experiments on human embryos.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.PRESENTERS: CHANEY; CHILDS; EVANS; GILES; MAGUIRE; TATE
PETITION.TITLE: Australian Broadcasting Corporation: Commercial Sponsorship
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate of the Commonwealth Parliament assembled. The petition of these residents of the Commonwealth of Australia respectfully showeth
that the Australian Broadcasting Corporation provides the citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia with the only nation-wide, independent radio and television service
that the independence of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation must be preserved in the interests of the citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia
that the introduction of commercial sponsorship or any form of advertising material from commercial sources, would destroy the independence of the Corporation.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Honourable Senators will oppose the introduction of any form of sponsorship or advertising material from commercial sources into the programmes of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Chaney (from 10 citizens), Childs (from 1,935 citizens), Gareth Evans (from 434 citizens), Giles (from 202 citizens), Maguire (from 120 citizens) and Tate (from 321 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

We, the undersigned citizens of Australia, being concerned that the Australian Government, in breach of its own stated policies, has lifted the bans on the sale of uranium to France; demand that the Government re-impose the bans on such sales, and further, that the Government ratifies and strengthens the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty to prohibit uranium sales within the region.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Casino: Australian Capital Territory
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
(1) That we are totally opposed to the proposal for the establishment of a gambling casino in Canberra or the Australian Capital Territory.
(2) That a casino in Canberra would detract from the unique character and status of our National Capital.

Your petitioners therefore most humbly request the Senate and the Government of the Commonwealth of Australia to reject any proposal or legislation which would permit the establishment of a casino in the Australian Capital Territory.
And your humble petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Health Promotion Foundation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
We, the undersigned.
(i) are alarmed that many sporting, cultural and community groups have been made to feel that they can attract sponsorship only from promoters of unhealthy products;
(ii) call for a National Health Promotion Foundation to be established through an increase in tobacco excise of 10 cents per packet; and

(iii) urge that the National Health Promotion Foundation provide national sporting, cultural and community groups with alternative sponsorship funding so that these groups can flourish without the taint of accepting money from tobacco companies and assisting in the promotion of their unhealthy products.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Jenkins (from 140 citizens) and Reid (from 100 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Australia Card Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the President and Senators in Parliament assembled, your humble petitioners showeth that the proposed Australia Card will have a dramatic impact on the lives of all Australians, and your petitioners therefore request a national referendum on the Australia Card Bill before the proposal is resubmitted to Parliament.
As in duty bound your petitioners will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Judeo-Christian Values
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we are concerned that the Judeo-Christian moral values which have been fundamental in our laws and education systems since the foundation of the country are now being undermined in the current practice of law making, and we are concerned that the values of the secular-humanistic philosophy have taken their place therefore jeopardizing the moral climate of our society and contributing towards immorality and violence in our society.
Your petitioners therefore ask the Senate for the restoration of Judeo-Christian laws and moral values.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: X-rated Video Material
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
We the undersigned,
Express concern over the further delay until 28 April 1988 of the Report of the Joint Select Committee on Video Material.

Call upon the Senate to request the Government as an urgent interim measure to immediately adopt the recommendations and respond positively to the observations of the Senate Select Committee on Video Material by:
ensuring that all videos currently on the market which contain a level of violence beyond the current Film Censorship Board guidelines be withdrawn from sale or hire;
placing a moratorium on the sale and hire of X-rated videos;
promulgating regulations to prevent the transmission by post from Canberra of videos which are banned in the States.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Scullin Primary School
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
We, the undersigned citizens of Australia draw to the attention of the Senate the proposed closure of Scullin Primary School.
We consider it totally unacceptable that the community should be deprived of its traditional-style, viable, neighbourhood school.
The building is at ground level and educationally suitable.
To attend alternative schools would impose lengthy, unsafe journeys on many young children.
The open space surrounding the school is constantly used for organised sport and as a play space.
The closure of such a suburban focal-point would adversely affect our community.
We therefore request that the Senate persuade the Government to abandon the proposal to close Scullin Primary School.

PETITION.TITLE: War Veterans
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The Humble Petition of the undersigned members of the War Veterans' community and concerned citizens respectfully showeth:
That there has been continuous, substantial and damaging erosion of war veterans' benefits and services since May of 1985 in a very wide range of areas;

That it is cruel and cynical of the Government to treat war veterans, many of whom are now advanced in age, in declining health and vulnerable, as expendable and unworthy of optimum care and benefits, when they and their comrades gave of their utmost to this country in its times of greatest need;

Now, therefore your petitioners request that the Senate in Parliament assembled pass appropriate legislation to reverse the decisions of the Government which have brought about the erosion of war veterans' benefits and services.

PETITION.TITLE: Constitutional Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth:
1. That the Constitution of the Commonwealth has served Australia well, is not out of date, has proved to be flexible and should not be radically altered.

2. Our deep concern that the recommendations of the Constitutional Commission and its advisory committees which propose radical changes to the Constitution are threatening to reduce our rights as citizens of the Commonwealth.

3. Our strongest opposition to any referendum proposals of the Hawke Government which gives more power to the Government and less to the people and which concentrates that power in Canberra at the expense of the States and weakens the role of the Senate.

PETITION.TITLE: Mordechai Vanunu: Release from Prison
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament
The petition of the undersigned shows:
Our deepest concern at the plight of Mordechai Vanunu, who revealed details of the nuclear weapons arsenal of Israel;
Our belief that Vanunu's actions were a service to humanity-including to the people of Israel-and were in fulfilment of his duty under international law;

Our belief that the unlawful abduction of Vanunu from Rome, his imprisonment since then, his prison conditions, and his conviction on charges of espionage and treason are denials of his fundamental human rights.
Your petitioners ask that the Senate, in Parliament assembled should:
Resolve to ask the Australian Government to appeal to the Government of Israel to release Mordechai Vanunu immediately and without conditions.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Port Pirie Education Centre: Funding
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
that the Port Pirie Education Centre Inc. has for twelve years fulfilled a wide range of educational needs among underprivileged and isolated rural people in the upper north of South Australia;
that the Federal Government's withdrawal of base grant funding will in effect cause the Centre to close at the end of 1987:

that Federal Government managerial incompetence is evident in deciding to cause the closure of the Centre at the same time as approving a Community Employment Program grant of approximately $50,000 to upgrade the Centre's grounds.
Your petitioners therefore pray:

that the Federal Government will restore base grant funding for 1988 and beyond to ensure that the Port Pirie Education Centre Inc. can continue to provide its wide range of educational services to the people of the upper north of South Australia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pine Gap Defence Space Research Facility

SPEECH.SPEAKER: JENKINS

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I present to the Senate the following petition, which is not in conformity with the Standing Orders as it is not in the correct form, from 15 petitioners praying that the lease of the joint Australian-United States defence space research facility at Pine Gap be terminated:

SPEECH.PARA: We the undersigned ask that the Federal Government advise the United States of America that the Agreement for a base at Pine Gap be terminated by October 1986.
We believe that for the sake of peace and the good of the Australian people the Agreement should be terminated and the Base closed because Pine Gap is base used for military and espionage purposes:

Since the beginning of its operations in 1969 the base has been used for the monitoring of telephone and teletype communications in Australia. Information gathered in this way has been used by the CIA all over the world, much of it can be linked to the overthrow of governments in other countries. Last year it was discovered that the base at Pine Gap was spying on Greece.
The electronic and pictorial information which the base's satellites collect is used to determine nuclear targets on Soviet and allied soil.
Many military activities of the USA approach the verge of nuclear war, they are also co-ordinated from Pine Gap. The war in Vietnam and the US invasion of Lebanon in 1984 are amongst such activities.

Pine Gap devotes only a very small percentage of its time to monitoring of the arms control implementation agreement and the information gathered at such times is so secret that Australia has absolutely no access to it.
The role of Pine Gap will be enlarged according to Reagan's Star Wars plans, which will transfer the arms race into space, threatening the existence of our planet.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

SPEECH.PARA: That the following Bill be introduced: a Bill for an Act to amend the Broadcasting Act 1942, and for related purposes.

SPEECH.PARA: That Senator Sheil be granted leave of absence for the period from 12 April to 29 April 1988 inclusive, on account of absence overseas on parliamentary business.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-
(a) notes the widespread alarm in the nursing home community that has arisen as a direct result of the Federal Government's so-called aged care policy;
(b) observes that the quality of nursing home care in South Australia could seriously be jeopardised if the Government continues to ignore the need for a more flexible policy stance in this area;

(c) further notes the claims of people directly involved with the provision of care to the aged in our community that the Government's policy changes will result in a substantial loss of jobs in nursing homes across South Australia, which will mean declining living standards for many nursing home residents; and

(d) calls upon the Government to put a halt to the proposed changes and conduct a trial of the new funding arrangements in the one government owned and operated nursing home in Australia in order to test the adequacy of its proposed new funding levels.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, when next an Order of the Day for the resumption of debate on a motion moved by a Minister for the second reading of a Bill for an Act to alter the Constitution is called on, the General Business Order of the Day relating to the consideration of the Constitution Alteration (Electors' Initiative) Bill 1987 shall be called on at the same time, that Bill shall be considered together with the Government Bill at every stage, and the questions for the remaining stages of the passage of the Bills shall be put separately in respect of each Bill.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON TRANSPORT, COMMUNICATIONS AND INFRASTRUCTURE

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Senator McMullan, I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, he will move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) That the paper entitled The Canberra Leasehold System prepared by Professor Max Neutze at the request of the Joint Committee on the Australian Capital Territory be referred to the Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure for investigation and report.

(2) That the Standing Committee when considering this matter be empowered to sit as a joint committee with the Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure of the House of Representatives when that Committee is considering this matter, under the same provisions as the joint committee empowered by resolution of the Senate of 3 November 1987, concurred in by the House of Representatives on 5 November 1987, to examine proposed variations to the plan of lay-out of the City of Canberra.
(3) That nothing in paragraph (2) be taken to affect the power of the Senate Committee to consider the matter referred to in paragraph (1) or its duty to report to the Senate on this matter.
(4) That this resolution be communicated by message to the House of Representatives requesting the concurrence of that House in paragraph (2).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-
(a) notes that sales tax, which is Australia's main consumption tax, is growing faster under the Hawke Government than any other of its record breaking taxes;

(b) notes that so far this financial year, sales tax collections have risen by 18 per cent or three times faster than its forecast inflation rate and even faster than the huge 14.5 per cent rise in income tax;
(c) notes that since the Hawke Government came into office this particular consumption tax has had a record increase of 110 per cent to a yearly rate of $7.5 billion in the 1987-88 financial year;
(d) notes that this rise in sales tax represents almost three times the rate of inflation and double the increase in Australian wages, salaries and other benefits under the Hawke Government;
(e) notes that this secret agenda of record rises in sales tax and other consumption taxes by the Hawke Government has been accompanied by record rises in income tax; and

(f) recognises the need for reform of the Hawke Government's unfair and discriminatory consumption taxes which hit ice cream but exclude pornographic magazines and which tax orange juice but not $1,000 ball gowns.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-
(a) congratulates Tasmanian and world-famous axeman, David Foster, on his recent success in being named Axeman of the Decade at the Royal Easter Show;

(b) notes the unprecedented record in woodchopping of David Foster, whose career highlights include not only this recent honour but, since 1976, 85 world titles, the captaining of Australia twice and, in partnership with his father, 6 consecutive double-handed sawing championships at the Sydney Show; and

(c) acknowledges that, including this outstanding personal record of David Foster, Tasmanian axemen in general have led competitive woodchopping for the past 50 years, which is a fitting testimony to their skill and endeavour.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Gareth Evans) agreed to:
That, notwithstanding anything contained in the Sessional Orders, the Order of Business on Thursday, 14 April 1988, be as follows:
(1) Petitions
(2) Notices of Motion
(3) Ministerial Statements, by leave
(4) Discovery of Formal Business
(5) Placing of Business
(6) Questions
(7) Adjournment.
Motion (by Senator Macklin)-by leave-proposed:

(1) That, unless otherwise ordered, where a Bill is introduced by a Minister, or is received from the House of Representatives, after 24 May 1988, and a motion is moved for the second reading of the Bill, debate on that motion shall be taken to be adjourned upon the conclusion of the speech of the Senator moving the motion, and the resumption of the debate shall be made an Order of the Day for the first day of sitting in August 1988, without any question being put.

(2) That, immediately after debate on a motion for the second reading of a Bill is adjourned in accordance with paragraph (1), or following the giving of notices on a subsequent day, a motion may be moved without notice to refer that Bill to a standing committee for inquiry and report by a day not later than the first day of sitting in August 1988.
(3) That this Order cease to have effect at the commencement of the first day of sitting in August 1988.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was not given any notice of this matter and I have just been handed a copy of the motion.
—Notice was given a couple of weeks ago.

—Yes, it was in the Notice Paper yesterday, but that Notice Paper is not on the desk today. I admit that there are some difficulties at the moment because of the absence of the Government Whip. I say cheerio to him, if he is silly enough to be listening. I am trying to read this motion quickly. It is the cut off motion that `unless otherwise ordered, where a Bill is introduced by a Minister, or is received from the House of Representatives, after 24 May 1988, and a motion is moved for the second reading of the Bill', the Bill will go over to the next session, which is in August.

SPEECH.PARA: I notice from reading the Press this morning that a series of Bills relating to the referenda is to be brought into the chamber, presumably, some time after the middle of May. I also read in the Press this morning, and it has not been notified to this chamber, that there is to be a special meeting of the House of Representatives at least on 10 May for the purpose of considering a series of referendum proposals. The Press also indicates that those referendum proposals are expected to pass the Senate by late June. At the moment, according to the information that I have, the Senate is not scheduled to sit later than the first week in June. I would have thought that, if the Government really desired to see a successful referendum or successful referenda take place, it would give sufficient time for the Senate to consider these very important issues. However, it appears that it is not going to give the Senate and, particularly, the House of Representatives sufficient time to consider what it believes to be major questions of public policy relating to the Constitution in this bicentennial year.

I read in this morning's Press that some of the referendum proposals will relate to such questions as the entrenching into the Constitution of certain freedoms, including freedom of expression, freedom of religion and the right to trial by jury. As will be recalled from what happened when the Bill of Rights was before the chamber, there are not only nuances in respect of freedom of expression to be considered but also real issues to be determined as to precisely what that means. One only needs to go back and dust the covers of the debates on the Bill of Rights to see that the Government was not sure what it meant by the words that it proposed to have inserted into the Bill of Rights. It did not even know what they meant when it came to the question of freedom of expression, freedom of speech. I hope that it has got its act together now, because it can be guaranteed that there will be a very substantial debate in the chamber and it will require far more time than the time which will be allowed after we receive the Bills from the House of Representatives, presuming that they are passed by the House of Representatives. It would, therefore, be unlikely that we would receive the Bills in this chamber until 24 or 25 May, and we would then have a period of only five or six days to consider the Bills.

TALK.START.PARA: —They will gag them through.
—Senator Walters says that the Government will gag them through. How will it do that, Senator Walters?
—They have the Democrats supporting them. They supported them last time.

—I hope that on a very serious matter such as this the Australian Democrats certainly would not gag or guillotine that sort of debate. In respect of those referendum Bills, I am wondering whether there should not be an amendment which would require the Government to introduce those Bills prior to 24 May so as to enable the chamber to give full consideration to them. Of course, the Government needs to have these referenda Bills through both chambers of Parliament before we rise for the winter recess, otherwise it cannot have the referenda in September when it desires to have the referenda because of the constitutional formalities concerned. I guess that the Government knows what I am talking about and I assume that most other honourable senators know what I am talking about. So if the Government does not get the Bills through before the winter recess, it cannot really, in effect, have referenda in September. The Government is all geared up to have the referenda in September. It is the Government's right to be geared up for that, but let me say to the Government that I, for one, will be making sure that the matters that are proposed for referenda are subject to the minutest scrutiny by this chamber. I believe that this proposal as it currently stands will not give us sufficient time to deal with those matters before the winter recess. If the Australian Democrats, the Opposition and the Government agree, I believe that it would be best to adjourn the debate on this motion until the next day of sitting so as to give consideration to the matters that I have raised.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not appropriate for me to speak to this motion, by earlier agreement, but I just want to clarify some matters that Senator Harradine has raised. First of all, just on the procedures this morning, it was my understanding that the Acting Government Whip, Senator Maguire, was in the process of telling those attending the meeting about these arrangements when that meeting was interrupted inadvertently. There was a disposition to fully brief them, so it should not have come as any surprise. Moreover, it is the arrangement, as I understand it, that one of Senator Harradine's staff attends these Whips meetings when these arrangements are made. Certainly there is no disposition to create any barriers to procedural communications.

SPEECH.PARA: On the more substantial issue of time available for debating the referendum proposal, the intended timetable is essentially as follows: That the Bills be introduced in the special sitting of the House of Representatives on 10 May; that they be debated in the House of Representatives about a week later-on 17 May; that they come into the Senate that week; and that they commence being debated in this place about 23 May. So that timetable is within the parameters of Senator Macklin's motion. I hasten to add that I believe that the Australian Democrats would not be uncooperative were that timetable to be disrupted for any reason. Indeed, it is on the assumption of sensible cooperation about matters of major moment, quite apart from the fact that the Government would be beaten anyway, that the Government is accepting this essentially formal motion without a squeak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —In light of the comment that has been made, I think I should make the Opposition's position clear. In the past we have supported and again today we will support the placing of some time limit on the introduction of fresh legislation that will be dealt with in this session. We think that is in the interests of orderly consideration of legislation.
—If you win government will you do the same?

—In response to Senator Ray's interjection in which he asks whether we would do the same in government, it has been a matter of lament for me both in government and in opposition that, for whatever reason, there appears to be this propensity to produce legislation late in the session. I do not approve of it and I think it cheapens the parliamentary pro- cess and often makes it rather meaningless. I have little doubt that when we are in government, given the way in which the Senate has been reconstructed, we are likely to face exactly the same restrictions. It would be very odd if we did not.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn to the concerns that have been expressed by Senator Harradine. This motion in no way sets the limits of what would be required by the Opposition in terms of allowing proper debate. All that this motion does is to say that Bills introduced after a certain date, in the absence of some agreement from the Senate to the contrary, will stand adjourned to the next session. That does not mean that the Opposition would in any way go along with, consent to or cooperate with a foreshortening of debate on essential and major matters such as proposals for constitutional change. Just as the Opposition has sought the fullest possible debate on major questions such as the introduction of the identification card, the Bill of Rights Bill and so on, we would see a major debate being involved in proposals to change the Australian Constitution, not least if those changes affect the role and function of this chamber; and there has been some suggestion that they will.

I simply wish to give Senator Harradine an assurance that the sorts of concerns that he expresses are no different from the concerns held by the Opposition that there should be very full debate on these matters. I hope that the whole of the Senate will be united in that view. Often we have seen detailed and contentious legislation dealt with in the House of Representatives in the space of less than a sitting day. That legislation has then been debated for days in the Senate, I think to very good effect. I suppose the simplest and most recent example of that is the Bill of Rights Bill. There was a substantial debate in this place on that Bill which enabled the public to catch up with the debate and to register its concern about a proposal which would have made a very substantial difference to the structure of government in this country. We are all in the position where we do not know what the Government will select from the smorgasbord of constitutional change that has been put forward by the Constitutional Commission. The Opposition has expressed its concern that under the guise of obtaining what might be regarded as popular and widely supported measures, such as the increase in the parliamentary term to four years for the House of Representatives, the Government might produce fundamental structural changes which reduce the Senate to some sort of poor man's House of Lords.

I can give the Senate an absolute assurance that all of those proposals will receive the greatest scrutiny from the Opposition. We will fight very hard to ensure that there is proper parliamentary debate as a prelude to any possible referendum, because that debate will be an important part of informing the public of the true implications of what is being put forward. In this area the Australian Democrats will have a significant role to play, particularly if there are elements of the proposals that they as a party support. I hope that they accept that there may well be a need for a substantial debate to take place in the Senate if we are to ensure that there is broad public understanding of the issues. I hope that they will not join with the Government in foreshortening the constitutional processes, foreshortening the debate and enabling these things to be shoved on to an unsuspecting public.

I do not know what proportion of Australians read booklets that they receive on constitutional change. I suspect that the majority of them do not. Therefore, I believe that the opportunities for debate in this place are critically important to the public's understanding, and indeed the media's understanding, of issues that are raised by constitutional amendment. Though I do not believe there is any need, I would be interested in any specific amendment that Senator Harradine might like to move with respect to constitutional changes. However, I doubt that we could cover an amendment by any particular resolution. In the end the actual resolution of honourable senators will be required to ensure that the Government does not rush through major provisions. I hope the Opposition will have cooperation. In light of what Senator Harradine has said I know we will have his support. I hope that we will have the cooperation of other honourable senators to make sure that that line is held.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I table explanatory notes for the Department of Aboriginal Affairs relating to additional estimates of expenditure for 1987-88.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator Gareth Evans) agreed to:
That the Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
Mr President, this Bill contains amendments to the National Crime Authority Act 1984 and the Telecommunications (Interception) Act 1979.
The amendments to the National Crime Authority Act 1984 are in Part II of the Bill.

The primary purpose of the amendments to the National Crime Authority Act is to repeal s. 63, the sunset clause. This will ensure the Authority's continued existence beyond 30 June 1989 and meets a commitment made as part of the Government's election platform. The decision to continue the Authority beyond 30 June 1989 is a recognition of the valuable and innovative role which the Authority has played thus far in the fight against organised crime. In the last 4 years, the Authority has demonstrated the effectiveness of the task force approach in this fight. This approach uses teams of highly skilled lawyers, accountants and police investigators endowed with special powers beyond those available to police. The impact of the NCA has been felt in the areas of drug trafficking, white collar crime and the corruption of public officials.

The other critical aspect of the NCA's operations is the support it enjoys from all States and the Northern Territory which participate in the Inter-Governmental Committee on the National Crime Authority chaired by the Commonwealth. As well as references from the Commonwealth, the Authority currently has one or more references from five States and the Northern Territory.

The Government's intention to repeal the sunset clause was communicated to the State and Northern Territory Ministerial representatives at the last meeting of the Inter-Governmental Committee on the NCA, who expressed their continued support for the Authority and noted the need to amend their own Governments' underpinning legislation.
Clause 4 incorporates some related and consequential amendments to the terms of office of the Chairman and members of the Authority.

The Government is proposing to recommend to the Governor-General that the present Chairman of the Authority, Mr Justice Stewart, be re-appointed for a period of one year from the date of the expiration of his present term of office i.e. 30 June 1988.

The Government considers that the Authority will clearly benefit from continuity of leadership and direction in the period of adjustment and consolidation following the repeal of the sunset clause. Accordingly, the Government sought Mr Justice Stewart's agreement to an extension of his term of appointment. Mr Justice Stewart has agreed to the proposed re-appointment on the basis that the extension would be for one year only. In proposing the re-appointment, the Government is conscious of the importance of the contribution made by Mr Justice Stewart to the Authority's establishment and work thus far. It looks to him to set the Authority on a solid foundation now that its future is assured.

At the same time, the Government believes that, as a general principle, the existing four year limitation on the term of appointment of members of the Authority and the prohibition on the re-appointment of members should be retained.

Consequently, clause 4 contains transitional provisions which specifically provide for the re-appointment of Mr Justice Stewart for one year only. These provisions also enable the re-appointment of the other two members of the Authority beyond the date of effect of the sunset clause when their terms of appointment under the Principal Act were to expire, provided that their total term of appointment does not exceed four years from the date of their initial appointment. This provision will similarly provide a level of continuity of experience and direction for the Authority.

Clause 4 contains a further amendment which makes clear that appointments of less than four years are possible. This introduces the necessary flexibility into the Act to accommodate the possibility that a person suitably qualified to be appointed as a member may not be in a position to accept a four year term of appointment.
Part III of the Bill amends the Telecommunications (Interception) Act 1979.
There are two substantive amendments contained in Part III.

At the request of Judges of the Federal Court, an amendment is to be made to section 6d, which deals with eligible judges under the Act. The amendment will ensure that eligible judges, in the performance of a function or power conferred on an eligible judge by the Principal Act, have the same protection and immunity as a Justice of the High Court has in relation to proceedings in the High Court. This will replace a more limited protection now provided by the sub-section and will give eligible judges the same protection they have when sitting as judges.

The other main amendment will require the Commissioner of the AFP to keep certified copies of warrants, and of instruments revoking warrants, issued under Part IV of the Principal Act. (These warrants authorise the interception of telegrams). The purpose of the amendment is to remove an apparent incompatibility in provisions dealing with the manner in which these warrants are handled. The amendments will make it clear that Part IV warrants and instruments of revocation are to be delivered to the Managing Director of Telecom, with the AFP retaining a certified copy.
Two other minor drafting amendments are also made to the Principal Act.
Debate (on motion by Senator Knowles) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: TEXTILES, CLOTHING AND FOOTWEAR DEVELOPMENT AUTHORITY BILL 1988

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 25 March.
Clause 63 (Confidentiality).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —The Textiles, Clothing and Footwear Development Authority Bill 1988 does not implement the Government's plan for the textiles, clothing and footwear industries. What it does is establish an authority to implement the Government's plan. The Opposition's viewpoint is that the Authority is not necessary for the implementation of the plan; that the Authority will prove in fact to be an intrusive quango, and that it will impose upon the plan a bureaucracy to which the Opposition is opposed. So, although the Opposition supports the general thrust of the Government's textiles, clothing and footwear plan, it opposes the Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee has reached the stage of dealing with clause 63 of the Bill, the confidentiality clause. That clause purports to establish confidentiality of information supplied to the Authority by the industry. However, as I pointed out previously, clause 63 (2) in effect guts clause 63 (1), which imposes a requirement of confidentiality. Subclause 63 (2) provides that the confidentiality provisions do not apply, firstly, for the purposes of this Act or, secondly, as required or permitted by law. The Government has accepted that argument in part in that it has agreed-this is the amendment that has been moved-to delete from proposed subclause (2) the words `for the purposes of this Act; or'. However, subclause (2) will still provide that the confidentiality provisions do not apply to anything done `as required or permitted by law'. As I have pointed out previously, the provision is as wide open as it was previously. Once the Bill becomes law in due course-assuming that the Australian Democrats support the Government in passing this legislation-in effect the confidentiality provisions will not apply to anything done in relation to this Bill. That will gut the confidentiality provisions in subclause (1), and indeed will make the whole of clause 63 meaningless. The coalition parties believe frankly that the Government's amendment is not worthwhile and that the whole of subclause (2) should have been deleted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —If I understand Senator Lewis correctly, he is arguing that the change in the wording suggested in this amendment produces a tautology-in other words, that the phrase `as required or permitted by law' remains in, but the words `for the purposes of this Act' go out. He is arguing that when the Bill becomes law the removal of paragraph (a) does not make a great deal of difference. But if that is the basis of his argument, this amendment is simply a clarification and removes some verbiage. I see therefore no reason why the Democrats should not support this Government amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment agreed to.
Clause, as amended, agreed to.
Clauses 64 to 68-by leave-taken together.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make a few remarks on clause 66, which gives the Authority very wide powers of delegation and goes to the heart of the question whether there should be an Authority at all. It is to this point that I wish to direct my remarks today as I was unable to participate in the second reading debate. As it is appropriate that my colleague the shadow Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Lewis, be the sole Opposition speaker, if any, on the third reading, I hope that the Chair will grant me a small amount of licence now. I make these comments with Senator Lewis's full support.
—We will grant you time, not licence.
—I thank Senator Button.
—The senator is entitled to 15 minutes.

—I will not take anything like that amount of time. I wish to make my views clear on this Bill for several reasons. In particular, from February 1985 to April 1987 I was chairman of the Opposition's industry, commerce, technology and science committee and in that period my committee and I personally had close and constructive contact and consultations with the industries as they waited for the Hawke Government to develop its plan for the textiles, clothing and footwear (TCF) industries to replace the existing plan which is due to expire at the end of 1988-a plan that was introduced in the first instance by the Fraser Government in 1980 or thereabouts. My committee and I visited many plants, large and small, and met virtually all the leaders of the TCF industries. It is unquestionable that the strong support that the Liberal and National parties gave the TCF industries in their fight for an economically rational but reasonable plan played an important part in the details that the Government finally announced in late 1986 and mid-1987.
—This is licence rather than time, Senator, I might add.

—I thank the Minister. I notice that he has not deferred from that observation, though. As Senator Chaney, the then shadow Minister, said in late 1986, as the then shadow Minister Senator Messner said in June 1987, as I have said on behalf of the Opposition's industry committee, and as the now shadow Minister, Senator Lewis, said in the second reading debate on this Bill, the Liberal and National parties support the broad thrust of the Government's plan. We are committed to continuing that plan when we win government even though it is painfully clear that the policies of this Labor Government chop and change so much, at great cost to confidence and therefore investment in industry, that we cannot be sure what shape the plan will then actually be in.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to make it clear that we on this side of the chamber support the TCF industries' legitimate wishes for a stable framework of government policy within which to operate, in which to invest and employ labour and in which it can become increasingly advanced technologically and increasingly efficient. The industries are already highly efficient technically by world standards. There is more that they want to do, and I am sure they can achieve their aims if they are allowed to get on with the job. What we say to the Government and to the industries themselves, however, is this: the establishment of the Textiles, Clothing and Footwear Development Authority will not help the TCF industries to achieve their objectives. On the contrary, it will place another costly bureaucratic roadblock in their path. It will inevitably become increasingly cumbersome and it will inhibit the very changes and restructuring that the industries wish to undertake and which the Government's plan envisages. I say this in the light of the clear and painful experience of the Government's car plan and steel plan. New authorities were established under both of those plans. The evidence is clear, and the industries themselves affirm strongly, that in both instances the operations of the relevant authority have proved disastrous. They have never lived up to the expectations the Government so optimistically set for them when they were established.

The TCF industries have told us that they are concerned that if the Authority is not established, the Government may reopen the whole plan, and this would put at risk the safeguard mechanisms in the plan in which the industries place such major store. But there is no logical reason why this should be the case. The Bill before the Senate does not deal with the safeguard mechanism. The mechanism does not need this Authority for its operation. So it would be an act of gross hypocrisy and gross disloyalty to the TCF industries if the Government were to put at risk the safeguard mechanism in the absence of the establishment of the Authority. The TCF industries are understandably very wary of this Government. They have seen it dishonour many of its commitments in the past. I think in particular of the arbitrary slashing of bounties in the 1986 Budget, without any discussion at all with the industries and in clear breach of the spirit of the existing TCF plan. The industries have also been subjected to the never-ending increases in the cost and regulatory burdens placed on industry as a whole by this Government.

I am fully aware of the grave concern on the part of the industries that they are facing another arbitrary change to their operating environment in the May mini-Budget, with the prospect of another across the board cut in industry assistance. So it is understandable that the industries are nervous about this Government. But there is no logical reason why a decision not to establish a TCF Authority should place the industries' important safeguard mechanism arrangements at any risk whatsoever. The functions envisaged for the Authority can be carried out more efficiently, with greater expertise, less cost, less duplication and less bureaucracy, under the existing structures of government-including, in particular, within Senator Button's own department-and without the draconian and, one could almost say, totalitarian provisions contained in the Bill. In other words, the Liberal and National parties oppose this Bill not because they wish to place the TCF industries at any additional disadvantage, but, on the contrary, to provide for a more efficient government environment that is conducive to their aspirations and opportunities in the 1990s.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will comment briefly on what Senator Short has said. He mentioned the proposed Textiles, Clothing and Footwear Development Authority for the industry. He said that everything could happen better without that Authority. I say to Senator Short that the facts destroy his argument. The industry asked for that Authority, but he now says, `We, the Liberal Party in opposition, know better than the industry. We say that there shouldn't be an Authority because things would work better without it'. But the industry asked for it, and the sort of argument he has put forward displays a mixture of patrician attitudes and a misunderstanding of the nature of government administration. What he is now arguing is that, having received some views from certain companies or others in the textile and clothing industry, those companies should be immune from any other economic changes which may take place. All of these matters are put forward as an argument. I wonder whether those matters represent the position of the Liberal Party in reality. Senator Short's speech displayed that there is no conceptual framework for considering some of these issues, particularly with respect to what he said about the nature of the Authority.

SPEECH.PARA: As I have said publicly-and I say it again here-I am not in favour of wall to wall authorities. I just do not believe in that concept. I know that Senator Short does not believe in it. But there are industries in this country which are very costly to the Australian community and which in the past have been sick industries. Let us take, for example, the textile, clothing and footwear industry. For many of the companies involved it is a highly profitable industry. There are enormous cash flows and a very quick return on investment. What we have to be concerned about with an industry like that is the commitment in the industry to employing people, improving the performance of the industry, improving quality and getting into exports. Senator Short may say that the market will take care of that. He is not in favour of the market taking care of it because in the same argument, by implication, he said that he supported continuation of very high protection levels for this industry. He really has to come to grips-I do not want to patronise him but we are here in a political debate context so I will say what I think-with what he is on about as a member of the Opposition.

I will tell Senator Short what I am on about. I will be frank about it. We have a big trade deficit in this country. We are living beyond our means. Senator Short never fails to remind us of that. We have to develop industries in this country which are as good as industries in the rest of the world in terms of their capacity to export, their capacity to trade in the international marketplace and their capacity to deliver quality and satisfactory goods to Australian consumers. What Senator Short wants to do is to nurture them and say that they have to be protected from all those difficult pressures which the rest of the world's industries have to face up to. At the same time he expects them to improve their performance, and so on. This is an enormously difficult industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think we are all well aware of that.

—Yes. I have sat around a table with eight or 10 of the manufacturers in this industry whose personal fortunes run into billions of dollars between them-not millions, but billions. They are very concerned about maintaining levels of protection for their operations. I understand that. Why would they not be concerned? But the Australian consumer has to be considered. The justification for the Authority is that there is a public interest which has to be looked after beyond what the market in a country like this is able to do. That is what it is about. We could debate these issues at length over a period. No doubt we will do so, and I will welcome that. I think we have to be clear about what we are doing.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Short has not moved any amendments, so I will not comment further. I am grateful for his contribution because it has given me an opportunity to put my view as to the function of the Authority. Senator Short says that the industry may resent the presence of an Authority and that the functions could be performed by the Department. He knows as well as I do, as an ex-public servant, that if there is anything that industries resent it is not so much authorities but public servants, and the direct organs of government being involved in the day-to-day activities. The Authority will have people who have had direct experience of working in the industry. That is one of the advantages of that course. The cost of these things is not great. If it is translated into Public Service terms we would probably have a line ball situation as to cost. For example, as I said in the Estimates Committee hearing last night, when we established the Automotive Industry Authority-I make no apologies for that as I think it has been highly successful-these sorts of things were said. It is an Authority which I believe has the confidence of the industry, which is much more than the Public Service could achieve.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise a couple of points. Firstly, as Senator Button has pointed out, and as I read into the record during the second reading debate, the industry certainly does want this Textiles, Clothing and Footwear Development Authority. I read into the record part of a letter from Mr Keith Purcell, who is the Executive Director for the Textile, Clothing and Footwear Council of Australia, in which he certainly raised some objections to the legislation as it was originally framed. Those objections have been substantially answered by the amendments which the Government has moved.

SPEECH.PARA: The second brief point which I would like to make is that it seems to me that the Opposition has philosophical difficulty over the question of free marketing, or the operation of the market and government control. It seems abundantly evident to the Australian Democrats that we are well beyond the laissez faire stage where the market can simply be left alone and the market somehow will serve the common good, as Adam Smith once said when he described the invisible hand. As I have said before, there is no a priori reason why the operation of competitive greed in a market system should serve the common good. It surprised me that Adam Smith's philosophical view of that situation should have survived for as long as it has. There is abundant evidence that it does not and the market operates towards monopolies very quickly. Of course, we have seen that recently in Australia to a marked extent in a number of areas.

One sees the evident failure of this particular industry in some very important respects. I pointed out-and I think this occurred in Senator Cook's second reading speech-that, of the total wool clip, only 5 per cent is processed in Australia. If there is anything that we should be doing by way of competing more successfully industrially it should be adding value to those products that we are already producing in Australia. Yet only 5 per cent of our wool clip is actually processed in Australia.

Senator Cook went on to point out that only 10 per cent of our cotton crop and virtually none of our leather and hides are processed and turned into finished goods in Australia. Most of these which are can more than adequately compete with products manufactured elsewhere in the world as regards quality, style and everything else. So it seems to me quite clear that the market simply cannot be left alone. The market system will not serve, and has not served, the best interests of Australia. Clearly the industry itself has recognised this. The industry has called for the Authority and the Government has responded to that and has set up substantially the authority as requested by the industry. That is the reason why the Democrats have supported this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button, in his response to my colleague Senator Short, made reference to what this statutory authority will achieve. Let me make it clear that we shall be observing the statutory authority to see whether it does in fact achieve what Senator Button is talking about. I hope it does. I wish it well in its tasks. But I suspect that once again this will be a case in which Senator Button's legislation and the actions of his Government's bodies do not live up to Senator Button's rhetoric. Senator Button's rhetoric is very good. We all acknowledge that much of what he says seems reasonable and plausible. Everyone says, `Isn't that marvellous'. But the problem is that Senator Button's rhetoric is so very frequently not matched by his Government's performance in office. This is another such case.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Button also said in his response that the industry wants this authority. Senator Coulter has confirmed that industry leaders want this authority. What the industry leaders in fact wanted was some monitoring body, a body to monitor the plan to ensure that if there was a major reduction in this industry the plan would be deferred or delayed in some way as would be outlined by the Minister so as to halt the reduction in protection for a period. What the industry was seeking was some body, perhaps an authority or perhaps some other body, to monitor it. The Government has acknowledged that. I refer to page 7 of Senator Cook's second reading speech where he says:

The establishment of such a body was recommended by the TCF Industry Council. The Council saw the need for a specialised monitoring authority with responsibility for identifying the nature of changes occurring under the plan . . .
But in the very next paragraph Senator Cook went on to say that although that might have been what the industry wanted it was not what it was going to get. He said:

I see the role of the authority as being broader than that envisaged by the Council. While it will be important to ensure adequate oversighting of the plan, I consider the Authority's major function will be to administer the industries development strategy . . .

Earlier, in almost the opening paragraph of his second reading speech, Senator Cook had said that the main function of the Authority would be to implement the industries' development strategy. It may very well be that the industry leaders wanted a monitoring authority; they are getting much more than a monitoring authority. The fourth faction of the Australian Labor Party in this chamber, the Australian Democrats, once again supports the Government in all that it is doing. No doubt Senator Coulter will rise to protect Senator Button from such an attack being made by me by saying that he has a letter here saying that industry leaders want this Authority as it stands at the moment. And they do, because they are scared that if they do not accept the Authority being imposed upon them by this Government the Government will change the plan and all the investments which they have made in this industry since the plan was first announced will be at risk. So the Government is squeezing the industry in this way.

The plan has already been changed. Let me explain in which way. In a statement which Senator Button made on 5 June 1987 he said that $27m would be provided to the Australian Industry Development Corporation (AIDC) to finance investment in raw material processing projects. If one looks at proposed new section 25 (c) of this Bill one will see that it shows that this will no longer be the case as the Government will be providing finance to AIDC only to cover interest on and the cost of money borrowed by AIDC for investment in raw material processing projects. So there has been a change. As my colleague Senator Short said, these industries are fearful of this Government-not only the textile, clothing and footwear industry but all of these industries. They do not know where they are with this Government because it keeps changing its mind. It does not allow managers in industry to make the necessary long term decisions. Senator Button is supportive of what I am saying. He will use words to say, `Yes, managers need long term propositions so that they can make long term investment decisions'. He knows that is right as I know it is right. But the truth of the matter is that his colleagues, Mr Keating and Mr Dawkins, and his Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, do not listen to him, and they are the ones who might allow him to make these statements out in the community but they are the ones who implement the changes which are so frequently disastrous to industry.

I mentioned what proposed new section 25 (c) of this Bill does. It shows that already the plan has been changed since Senator Button announced it on 5 June. The change shows three things: Firstly, it shows that already there have been changes to the plan. Secondly, it shows that the Minister made a statement about the $27m for which he has received wide publicity. Once again, he cannot deliver on the details because the Government will not let him. His senior colleagues will not let him or he is not able to. In this instance I presume that his colleague Senator Walsh, and the Department of Finance, would not let him have the money to finance these important projects. The third thing the change shows is that in the present environment of internal debate about privatisation the Minister could not be seen to be giving the AIDC $27m for investment in the TCF industry sector when the AIDC is generally very strapped for funds and requires a substantial equity injection. This approach of funding only the cost of borrowing will affect AIDC's gearing ratio and perhaps further constrain its ability to raise funds for investments in other sectors. So, as I said, there have been substantial wide-ranging changes as a result of this. Notwithstanding that there appears to be only a minor change in the Bill, in fact there has been a very important change in what the Government is doing. Once again I say that Senator Button's rhetoric, which is all fine and dandy, is in fact not supported by his Government's actions. After all, he is the third most senior Minister in this Government. So he cannot back away as he always endeavours to from the decisions of his Government and say, `It is not my fault. You will have to talk to Mr Keating or Senator Walsh about that'. He is the responsible Minister.

Let me turn at this stage to that part of Senator Button's speech a few moments ago when he said that the Opposition parties will have to get their act together on tariff protection and the lowering of tariffs and suggested that, although we talk about lowering tariffs, in fact we support high tariffs. Quite the contrary. The truth of the matter is that we believe in and support a quite significant phased reduction of tariffs after proper consultation with industry. The difference between our policy and the rhe-toric of Senator Button is this: in addition to a phased reduction of tariffs, we believe that it is essential to free up the economic and industrial relations system which this country has; in other words, to deregulate the labour market, to reduce the burden of regulations, to lower corporate and personal taxes and to get the government out of its interference with industry.

If this Government were to take those steps, it could lower tariffs much more rapidly than it can at the moment. The present Government takes the easy step of lowering the tariffs. The difficult step is to undo the shackles on industry to enable industry and the economy to take advantage of the lowered tariff protection arrangements. If the Government would, as I said, deregulate the labour market and remove the rigidities from the structure, from the system, which this country has at the moment, at the same time as it reduces protection, then industry and this economy would be able to take advantage of the lowered protectionist regime which Senator Button so frequently talks about.

There is one other point which I now come back to, and that is clause 66 of the Bill, rather than answering Senator Button's response to Senator Short. I draw attention to clause 66 and in particular to subclause 1 (b) which, in effect, says that the Authority may by resolution delegate to a member of the staff of the Authority all or any of the Authority's powers under this Act. I ask those industry leaders who are being squeezed by this Government to support this Bill to consider what the consequences of that might be, to consider that the Authority may very well delegate to a member of its staff the power to conduct a detailed inquiry into any particular aspect of the management of any particular business in the textile, clothing and foot-wear industries of Australia. What a significant power that is. Subclause 1 (c) says that if they can get the approval of the Minister they may delegate that power to anyone in Australia, whether he is a member of the staff of the Authority or otherwise. Any person in Australia may be delegated this power to conduct the activities of the Authority, with all of its powers including the very wide powers of investigation.

If there is any clause at all by reason of which this Bill ought to be rejected, then by itself clause 63 of the Bill is, in my view, a good enough reason to throw out this legislation, apart from all the other measures that we have referred to during the debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I let this debate continue I should point out to the Committee that, with the tacit acceptance of the Committee, I permitted Senator Short to open a wide-ranging debate not strictly relevant to clauses 64 to 68. I would like the debate now to be confined to the clauses before the Committee, as all senators have had a chance to speak on the matters raised by Senator Short.

—I wish to use the opportunity afforded by this debate to speak to clauses 64 and 65. The discussion of these clauses effectively concludes the committee stage of the consideration of this Bill. I wish to make an appeal to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) with regard to division 2, which actually contains the provisions for giving certain encouragements to the industry to move into a modernisation phase. This of course is to be applauded. But all this good work is going to be undone if, in the May economic statement, we are going to lose the benefits of accelerated depreciation.
—Order! Senator Watson, we are on clauses 64 to 68. How are your remarks relevant to those clauses?
—In the supply of information to the Authority under clause 64 and financial assistance under clause 65. Those comments conclude my remarks.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I fully appreciate your ruling, Mr Chairman, and I do not want to enter into an expanded debate. Some people do not suffer fools gladly; I do. But I do not suffer misinformation gladly, and I just want to make a couple of comments to correct some points made by Senator Lewis.
—I think that in the circumstances I should ask the Committee whether leave is granted. Is leave granted? There being no objection, leave is granted.

—Senator Lewis said, `Senator Button cannot back away from these things'. I assure him that Senator Button does not want to back away from these things. Let me deal with the points he made. He tried to make two main points. The first was that the industry had asked for a monitoring authority. That, in its view, is an authority to make sure that as far as possible the effects of protection reductions are as limited as they can possibly be. That is what a monitoring authority means to the industry, and I do not blame it for that as it has its own interests to look after.

SPEECH.PARA: But the honourable senator then sought to make the point that in fact I really have not given it that sort of authority at all, that I have given it an authority that will administer and implement the industry development plan. Sure, I have done that. The alternative would be to have just a monitoring authority and give it the taxpayers' money, which is implicit in the industry development plan, and let it do what it likes with it. Well, this Government is not about that, and I want the honourable senator to be quite clear about that, because we are not in a position to give handouts of taxpayers' money to particular industries and say, `You can do what you like with it, fellers. Take the money; we will keep the box'. That is implicit in the honourable senator's argument.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish!

—The honourable senator can say, `Rubbish!'. His rhetoric is excellent-`rubbish', `crap', all these sorts of interjections. That is all very good! Brilliant rhetoric, Senator, brilliant repartee! But the fact of the matter is that that is what is implicit in his argument. As I said in answer to Senator Short, the industry asked for an authority. It is getting high levels of protection and money for the industry development plan, and it is the responsibility of the Government to see that that money is properly spent, thank you.

SPEECH.PARA: The second point the honourable senator tried to make, by referring to section 25 of the Act, was that we had backed away from the raw materials processing section of the industry plan. We have not for a moment, as $27m will be there to finance the interest bill of the Australian Industry Development Corporation (AIDC) in making loans for raw material development companies of world scale. That will be there. We have not backed away from that at all. I do not know where the honourable senator got that idea from. He, in his role as an Opposition spokesman, can remind me if it is not there. He says that he will watch the Authority. He can watch me too and see whether the money is delivered.

It will be delivered because, as Senator Coulter said earlier, we have to do something about the further processing of Australian wool, hides and cotton in this country. But it is no good doing it in Mickey Mouse backyard shows; we have to do it in world class plants. That is what that money is about. But before any money is made available there has to be a report to the Government, which I will be quite happy to make available to Senator Lewis, from consultants about the feasibility of some of these suggested projects. That will be done by, by repute, the best international textile consultants in the world. It is being done now. The report will be available in about a month. Once it is available, the money will be available to the AIDC.

I do not know who blew that piece of misinformation into the honourable senator's ear. I warn him: One can walk around the textile, clothing and footwear industry and be given plenty of information about competitors and everything else. They do not hesitate. People say that politicians are nasty to each other. They should try the people in this industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —You should try the people in the arts industry.
—Yes, or people from the Opposition, I suppose. I just want to make the point that it is no good directing this sort of demonology about me and all this sort of stuff on the basis of misinformation.

SPEECH.PARA: Finally, Senator Lewis made a point about continuity. Industries want to know where they are going. I could not agree with that more. Look at the motor vehicle plan. Those opposite were in government for 27 years out of the last 30 before this Government was elected. In the last 15 years of their Government, 10 changes were made to the motor vehicle plans-10 motor vehicle plans. Every second year there was a new motor vehicle plan. This Government has been the first government in the history of this country to give some sort of continuity to the motor vehicle industry in terms of a plan. Those opposite should ask any of the people in the motor vehicle industry what they think about it. They do not like it all, but they say that this Government has given some continuity.

Those opposite should not come here and criticise this Government about questions of continuity. They should look at their own abysmal record. I could go through it from A to B-it is quite a short record in terms of performance-and illustrate the point which I am simply trying to make. All I am saying is: Be careful about handing out lectures on continuity without looking at some of the facts. Mr Chairman, I am grateful for your indulgence. I hope that you will now put the clauses to the Committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question is that clauses 64 to 68 stand as printed.
—I will be only a few moments--
—Is this relevant to clause 68?
—Yes, it is relevant to what Senator Button has just said.
—Is leave granted for Senator Lewis to speak on that subject? There being no objection, leave is granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not develop the argument any further. I draw Senator Button's attention to his statement on page 7 of the plan as originally announced on 5 June. He said that an amount of $27m will be provided to the Australian Industry Development Corporation (AIDC) to finance investment in resource processing. Clause 25 (c) talks about the AIDC and states:

SPEECH.PARA: where the Corporation participates in any such project-the provision of finance to the Corporation for use by the Corporation in the payment of interest on, and the cost of, money borrowed by the Corporation to enable it to participate in the project.

I read that as meaning that, instead of being granted $27m to fund the project, what the Government was intending to fund was only the interest on the money which the AIDC would have to raise in order to carry out its funding. The interest on $27m will be a lot less than $27m. That is the way I understood that. I may be wrong. If I am wrong, please tell me so.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are wrong.
—Thank you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer to clause 65, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: Any financial assistance under this Act shall be provided out of money appropriated by Parliament for the purpose.

I make two appeals to the Minister: the first is that he does not use the threatened across-the-board tariff cuts to scuttle the industry and that, if there are to be tariff cuts, he recognises those industries that have had their plans put in place after the currency realignments and differentiates them from the other industries. My other appeal is that, in any review of the taxation provisions and in the May economic statement, he recognise that in the financial assistance packages to try to modernise plants within the textile industries he must not scuttle the current depreciation allowances, which could effectively make the modernisation program within this plan so much more difficult.

Senator Button responded, `Yes, you are wrong'. I said, `Well, if I am wrong, I am wrong'. I just want to make sure that that is recorded in Hansard. If it was not recorded previously, it is now recorded in Hansard, because my belief and my instructions are that I am right and that Senator Button is wrong.
