SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —The debate on the Textiles, Clothing and Footwear Development Authority Bill 1988 has been somewhat confusing because it has ranged over a number of days. I simply wish to make crystal clear the position of the coalition parties. We are concerned for the textile, clothing and footwear industries. We are concerned for the people who work in them and for the future of these companies. We recognise the great contribution which they have made in the past to our economy, especially the contribution which they have made to rural cities around Australia. I can vouch personally for the contribution which the Warrnambool mill has made to the city of Warrnambool. I point to the value to the city of Horsham in Victoria of Pacific Dunlop Ltd's Holeproof company's recently opened $2m factory which is employing about 135 people.
—Hear, hear!

—Senator Button said, `Hear, hear', but in fact Senator Button has made many criticisms of these industries. We on our side recognise and acknowledge that many of them are at the leading edge of technology. If that is doubted, I draw attention to the report of the Industries Assistance Commission (IAC). I quote from page xx of the introduction, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: Indeed, many firms visited used state of the art technology in their processes or had sound reasons for not doing so.
Senator Button again made some disparaging aside to one of his instructing public servants in the chamber when I was saying those very things about these firms being used--

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on a point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President. Senator Lewis does not know what I said to my officials. He has no idea what I said and he should withdraw that comment because it is totally incorrect and dishonest.
—Senator Button, there is no point of order.

—If Senator Button has taken great exception to that, I will withdraw it, but it certainly did not give me the impression that Senator Button was approving my remarks about the report of the IAC and about the textile, clothing and footwear industries in Australia using state of the art technology. If Senator Button takes exception to it and denies that that was the purport of his aside, I withdraw it. As I have mentioned before, some textile, clothing and footwear industry leaders are concerned that the defeat of this Bill would put the plan and the safeguard mechanism in jeopardy. We say to them that that is not so. The bureaucratic, intrusive quango established by this Bill is simply not necessary to the plan. If it were necessary to the plan, we would not be opposing its creation. After my many years of experience in the textile industry and my many years of experience in this Parliament investigating the activities of quangos, I say to these industry leaders that this body will prove to be a millstone. The coalition policy is that in the interests of stability and predictability the next coalition government will maintain all current sectoral plans in whatever form they are when we take office, unless we say otherwise publicly before the next election or at some stage of the debate, as I am doing now in relation to this matter.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition does not oppose the textile, clothing and footwear plan as announced by Senator Button. We support its broad thrust. It moves in the right direction as it gradually reduces barrier protection and eliminates quantitative restrictions, whilst encouraging firms to become more internationally competitive. It may need some modification by us in office, especially in the light of the many benefits to industry of our other policies. I should add that in his second reading speech the Minister said that the plan is not immutable, so I suspect that when we get into office the plan will not be as it was announced by the Minister on 5 June last year. Indeed, I have warned industry leaders to expect changes to be announced in the Treasurer's May statement. Senator Button would know that industry leaders would consider announcements of major changes to the textile, clothing and footwear plan as in fact a breach of trust by him after their lengthy negotiations with him. But so be it.

As I have said, fundamentally the Liberal and National parties support the plan and in general will maintain what is left of it when we get into office. What we will not support is the establishment of this Authority. On many occasions we have expressed concern about the level of day to day bureaucratic intervention in industry. Notwithstanding the amendments to this Bill, it creates a quango which by its own establishing legislation will be bureaucratic, intrusive, inquisitive and interfering. Indeed, that is the way in which the legislation designs the Authority. The coalition parties say that the Authority is unnecessary and, indeed, this Bill is an excellent example of the different approach to industry adopted by the Australian Labor Party, on the one hand, and the Liberal and National parties on the other hand. We will be voting against it.
Question put:
That the Bill be now read a third time.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Bill read a third time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Nuclear Non-Proliferation (Safeguards) (Consequential Amendments) Bill was first debated in this chamber in the week before Palm Sunday this year, a day on which, of course, people concerned with this type of legislation tend to gather in great numbers around Australia. At that time I had the opportunity to begin my contribution to this debate, which I shall now continue.

SPEECH.PARA: I remind honourable senators that this is really a technical Bill that will amend the original Nuclear Non-Proliferation (Safeguards) Act, which prohibits the communication or processing of information applicable to enrichment, reprocessing, heavy water production, nuclear weapons production or other matters, without a permit. In other words, one can distribute design information on nuclear weapons if the Minister so allows. Because a patent application could communicate some of the information covered by the original Act, this Bill will amend the Patents Act 1952 to allow the Australian Safeguards Office to issue or deny permits for patent applications dealing with enrichment, reprocessing, and so on.

The Australian Democrats believe, of course, that it should be illegal to distribute information on nuclear weapons production, reprocessing or heavy water production under any circumstances; and that information on enrichment to greater than 20 per cent uranium 235 also should be banned, given that non-proliferation is the objective of the Bill. However, that prohibition should be made in the original Act. Although the Australian Democrats still wonder why the Government wants to leave open these options, we support the Bill as a necessary adjunct to existing legislation if the Government wishes to continue down this track.

Of course, the Australian Democrats do not in any way approve of the use of uranium, and believe it important that we consistently put that position. Unfortunately legislation such as this draws to our attention all the more readily that it is mere window dressing for honourable senators to pass such legislation while we are mining and exporting uranium, and especially so while we are exporting uranium to France.

The Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Gareth Evans) pointed out in his second reading speech on this Bill that this is not momentous legislation. That seems to the Australian Democrats to be a massive understatement. The whole issue of non-proliferation, which of course is dependent on safeguards, is one upon which we believe it is very important to spend time thinking. Claims are consistently made by the Hawke Labor Government, other proponents of the uranium industry and people who appear not to have deep concerns about the proliferation and existence of nuclear weapons that the safeguards under which we export uranium are perfectly adequate. Already in this debate honourable senators have heard clear evidence that that is simply not the case. If that evidence were not available before, which of course it was, it was supplied by my colleague Senator Sanders in the debate in this chamber on 24 March. That evidence arose from information supplied from Germany which made quite clear and established on the public record that the safeguards are a sham, that those claims have been shot to ribbons and are full of holes.

At that time Senator Sanders exposed in a very public way this uranium safeguards scam, as he called it. To quickly summarise what Senator Sanders said, he pointed out that documents that had been received from reliable sources in Europe proved that two German firms, Nukem and RWE, conspired to bypass Australian safeguards in order to produce weapons grade uranium. In that case those safeguards failed completely, and the only way that we as a uranium exporting country found out about this was through leaked documents from one of those companies, which has now been closed down by the German Government. The watchdog that we have relied upon in the European context, the European Atomic Energy Community, directly approved that deal. Senator Sanders went to considerable trouble to authenticate those documents and he had several translations made of them. He then pointed out what this meant to a country such as Australia that is still exporting uranium.

It is obvious that our position on the export of uranium is now shakier that it has ever been. Perhaps to remind honourable senators and listeners to this broadcast, the process involved two stages. In the first stage, nuclear materials which could be upgraded to weapons grade were swapped. In this case it was Australian material. In the second stage, the actual labelling of the material was swapped so that the material would not be recognised and known as Australian material that would be used in an unapproved fashion. By swapping the material, our Australian safeguard system was totally circumvented.

The Australian Democrats are pursuing this issue. Senator Sanders has announced that he will introduce a nuclear non-proliferation exports Bill which, while still making clear that the Australian Democrats do not approve of the mining or export of uranium in any event, will have the object of plugging some of those holes. Senator Sanders's Bill will contain measures with which I am sure no Australian would disagree if Australia is to export uranium. The Bill will ban the export of uranium to any country which had not signed and ratified, or which had withdrawn from, the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons-surely a very basic point; any country which has not signed and ratified or which has withdrawn from bilateral safeguard agreements with Australia; any country which has not accepted safeguards on all its nuclear facilities. I remind honourable senators that none of those requirements is met by all countries to which Australia at this stage is prepared to export uranium. The Bill will also ban exports to any country planning or continuing to build or test nuclear explosive devices-perhaps the most critical point in this legislation. The Government's comfort in saying that our uranium is only exported for peaceful purposes was blown apart by Senator Sanders's revelation of the safeguards scam. The only way that we can ensure that any country that gets our uranium cannot and does not go into nuclear weapons is to export to a country which is not planning or continuing to build or test nuclear explosive devices, along with the other safeguards earlier mentioned.

One of the other requirements in Senator Sanders's Bill would be that we must not export uranium to any country which has stationed on its soil nuclear explosive devices belonging to another country, or which is exporting nuclear material or technology to any country which does not satisfy the earlier conditions. That has been one of the major problems in the proliferation of nuclear weapons in the world since we first knew and understood the power of splitting the atom and used it for warlike purposes. Uranium is exported to countries which then enter into arrangements under the lap with countries which then develop nuclear capabilities.

Countries such as Pakistan and South Africa come to mind. Senator Sanders obviously has a provision in his Bill which would prohibit Australia exporting to a country which has not agreed not to involve Australian nuclear material or technology in international flag swaps of the kind which has been proven, at least on one occasion, to have taken place in the Nukem situation.

If we want to continue to talk about safeguards, which are essential to non-proliferation, we can go back and think about the horrific after-effects which we can now see from earlier nuclear tests-Monte Bello, Bikini Atoll, Maralinga, and now the shifting of the French tests from Mururoa which, it seems, has become honeycombed. Goodness knows what will happen there in the next two or three years. So much for safeguards. We already have nuclear victims on this planet living a miserable existence-not just victims from Hiroshima and Nagasaki, but victims in the Pacific, in our own country, and particularly among indigenous communities. To them `safeguards' is a hollow word. One of the areas that must cause great concern in respect of nuclear safeguards is our knowledge of the cover-ups which have taken place, and which continue to take place, in the nuclear industry, whether in terms of nuclear armaments or nuclear power.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, not in the nuclear industry.

—I have referred to a major cover-up which Senator Sanders has had a great part in revealing, but there are plenty of other examples. I notice my colleague from the Australian Labor Party saying, `No, not in the nuclear industry', that it could not happen in that industry, but there is plenty of evidence in the nuclear power industry as well that there have been cover-ups. There have been many accidents. I have in my hand a fairly weighty document called the Cousteau Almanac, which is not, as Senator Michael Baume suggested, a tome on bottom of the harbour but an interesting document by Jacques Cousteau, which mentions some of the nuclear accidents which have occurred in the nuclear industry. Without going into any detail, I remind people of those accidents and of their consequences. I ask the question: what do these do for non-proliferation safeguards? Where are the safeguards for people?

SPEECH.PARA: Windscale, the first of the nuclear plant accidents, was documented in October 1987. The documentation details the impact of this accident when the shutting off of the cooling system went awry, releasing enormous amounts of energy which had been accumulated. That process having commenced, the wind carried plant effluent over the Irish Sea. The winds then shifted and the effluent went across the Lancashire area. Now, many years later, we are faced with questions arising as to the health of people in that area, mutations in fish in the Irish Sea and so on. Those are the sorts of things that we face. I refer to Idaho Falls, in 1965, where there was a small United States Government experimental reactor. Again, there was difficulty in getting information on that matter, but there was an overheating problem; the radiation that was released did not go very far, but there was very severe contamination. At least two people were killed almost immediately, and a third died shortly thereafter. The bodies of the three victims were so `hot' that they were buried in lead coffins.

That is the sort of thing that has been occurring in the nuclear industry. At Fermi, outside Detroit, Michigan, there was an incident at an atomic power plant in 1966. Another occurred at Browns Ferry, Alabama, in 1977. The Tennessee Valley Authority-a power authority originally set up as a hydro-electricity authority-claimed that in that case no member of the public was exposed to radiation, and it was subsequently claimed that the Browns Ferry accident demonstrated that nuclear plant problems could be contained. For a time at least the American public seemed satisfied that these sorts of accidents could occur and that the public would not be affected. Then, of course, came the accident at Three Mile Island in 1979-an accident which is still having its impact, not only on the health of the community in that area but also on the economics of the nuclear industry which I shall mention briefly a little later.

I also refer to the incident at Chernobyl about which in the short space of time that is available to me today I shall not go into detail, except to say that as time passes, as more information is gathered, more and more concern is expressed. I point to an article by Peter Kellner in the Age of 11 March which points to some of the latest information that is arising post-Chernobyl. Dr Gould, who is now analysing the figures, has come up with the view that in the four months immediately following Chernobyl between 30,000 and 40,000 more people died than was normal for that time of year in the affected areas. I make the general comment that Dr Gould is one of a growing number of American and European scientists who believe that many more people are harmed by the indirect effects of leaked radiation than perhaps by the diseases which evidently are caused directly. We should not dismiss this growing body of concern when some of us stand up here and defend the nuclear industry. Certainly the Australian Democrats do not for a moment do that.

I mentioned briefly the question of the economics of the industry. Earlier in the debate my colleague Senator Coulter went into that matter in some detail but, lest Senator Lewis accuse me of being on the far left of the Left of the Labor Party, which he often does, I can point to the Uranium Information Centre's own newsletter, which I think could be seen to be on the of the far right Right of the Liberal and National parties. In October last that newsletter, which comes frequently to all honourable senators to give us the correct information about the nuclear industry, pointed out that the Atlas Corporation was leaving the uranium industry and closing down its uranium operations at Moab in Utah due to continuing problems in the domestic uranium industry. The company had suffered a net loss of $US52.1m in the year ended 30 June 1987. There is an illustration of the results of the uneconomic nature of the industry. That is even without this industry being culpable, being called to account, for the on-costs of its environmental, social and, particularly, health effects.

I return for just a moment to Senator Lewis's accusations in this debate about the Australian Democrats. On 24 March, Senator Lewis made the claim for some reason that, because the Australian Democrats stand firmly and solidly against nuclear proliferation and against the mining, milling, export and use of uranium, that somehow makes us a left wing group, or a bunch of left wing individuals. That claim seems a little at odds with a couple of headlines I have here, one of which says, `Close Lucas Heights, McLachlan urges'. The McLachlan concerned is the President of the National Farmers Federation. Unless Senator Lewis is going to say that the National Farmers Federation is the fifth faction of the far left of the Left of the Australian Labor Party, I think his argument is somewhat inconsistent. I congratulate Mr McLachlan on his understanding of how important it is that we be able, as a country, to produce nuclear-free food for the world market. Perhaps even further, I congratulate him on his understanding that pure food of all kinds, food which is as free from chemicals and nuclear and other contaminants as possible, can only be an economic plus for Australia. So I think Senator Lewis's claims about left wing lunacy and his referring to opponents of this industry as maddies are erroneous.

As I have said, this particular debate began in the week before Palm Sunday. It was particularly interesting this year to see that, amongst the tens of thousands of people who marched in the city of Melbourne and the hundreds of thousands who marched around Australia, perhaps more than I can remember before, a particular sort of crowd assembled to express their concerns about these issues. In fact, it was a crowd predominantly made up of young people, of groups particularly of secondary school age who seemed to have come along for a day to express their views and to march with all sorts of other people. When the march in Melbourne went down Bourke Street, approximately another third again joined the march, having been at the annual church service which this year took place at St Paul's Cathedral. It was particularly interesting to see on that Sunday night that even the television cameras had not been able to find any of those crazy maddies or loonies which they usually highlight in their coverage of Palm Sunday.

It seems to me that more and more this is becoming a mainstream issue in the Australian community, that less and less the predominant voices are voices of some sort of politically extreme ideology. They are, in fact, the voices of those young people who in greater numbers, in greater proportion than I have noticed before, were at the march. Particularly exciting for me, as an Australian Democrat, was the fact that when assembling with my group of people before the march about a dozen young girls and boys, I would say about 12 to 14 years of age, came up and, although they were totally unknown to me and I had never met any of them before, they asked whether they could assist us to carry our banners. That sort of thing indicates that this was far from a left wing loony exercise.

Indeed, those people who are continuing to promote the nuclear industry and to promote nuclear strategies of defence-people such as Mr Spender, who seems recently to have been suggesting that we should be stationing nuclear weapons in Australia-need to realise that a recent United Nations Association poll showed that some 3 per cent of Australia's population will wear that sort of thing. Mr Ian Sinclair, of the National Party of Australia, continues to call for nuclear submarines. Senator Parer said in this debate that we should be enriching nuclear fuels here in Australia, They are increasingly becoming minority views. The views held by the Australian Democrats are not the views of some way out left wing radical group. There has been a lot of criticism of young people in this debate. It has been suggested that they are being fooled, tricked, by a bunch of lunatics. That is not true. They are looking at the pluses, the minuses and the facts of the situation. They can read history; they know there are nuclear victims out there in our own country and in the Pacific, and they want all of this sort of thing stopped. I am sorry that this legislation, which of course the Australian Democrats support, goes only a tiny way down that track.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak briefly on the Nuclear Non-Proliferation (Safeguards) (Consequential Amendments) Bill. I suggest that the Australian Democrats have again demonstrated their failure to understand the differences between the nuclear power industry and nuclear weapons production, and the fact that the whole of the rationale of the Treaty for the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons (NPT) and its various arms, such as the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) and other safeguards regimes, are based on the fact that nuclear power is with us, that it will continue to expand, that it will be with us for a long time and that it can bring great benefits. It gives to those states that look for those benefits and that wish to go down that path some security that products will not be diverted from the 50-odd nations that utilise nuclear power towards the development of nuclear weapons. That is why the Non-Proliferation Treaty and the safeguards regime have become so important. That is why I support them, and why I think it is a matter of great regret that groups such as the Democrats continually confuse the two issues and therefore in effect debase the NPT and the safeguards regime. We heard this again this morning, in a reference to Palm Sunday marches. The majority of Palm Sunday marchers, Mr Deputy President-as you and I both know, because we both participated-attend to urge upon the nuclear powers of the world restraint and movement towards ultimate nuclear disarmament. We do not go to try to force upon the 50-odd nations that see benefit in the utilisation of nuclear power the view that they should desist from going down that path which has been to their benefit.

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill is just another small contribution towards further enhancing Australia's part in the safeguards regime, Australia's part in contribution to the Non-Proliferation Treaty. It does so by requiring applications for patents that may include certain nuclear information to be submitted to the Australian Safeguards Office for consideration. On some rare occasions there may be in a patent application information that should in some way be precluded from public dissemination on the basis that it may be contrary to the rationale of the safeguards regime. It is a very small contribution, as I say, because although it is directed towards private research there is next to no private research in this field currently being conducted in Australia. That is not surprising because, in turn, there is no government research in the area of nuclear power production-a decision that has been positively taken by this Government. That, to me, is a matter of regret and it demonstrates the inconsistency of the approach of this Government to the subject, which is really the theme of the few words I want to say today.

This Government has really attempted to get the best of both worlds. In doing that, it has become something of a laughing stock in the international community. Let me take the example of its attitude to the production and sale of uranium. Australia, by virtue of this Government's policy, sells uranium because the Government recognises that it is commercially sensible to do so, but it limits sales to production from three mines. In some ways it therefore believes, as I said, that it can gain the best of both worlds-that it can be seen to be acting to restrain nuclear production while at the same time seeking to gain economic benefit from it. It is inconsistent--

TALK.START.PARA: —What would you prefer to do-have open slather?

—I would prefer commercially to utilise the resource subject to a proper safeguards regime. One should sell to those who comply with the safeguards regime, either through the NPT or through adequate bilateral safeguards. At least that is consistent. Furthermore, it would put one in a position where one is just as secure within the safeguards regime as one would be under this Government's policy. If the Government adopted that position, it would no longer be a laughing-stock. It could therefore allow other mines in Australia to be developed, provided that it controlled sales and ensured that sales were subject to the international safeguards regimes.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government should not attempt to dictate, as it has done, that certain uranium mines in Australia seem to produce some more morally satisfactory ore than others, which is obviously ridiculous. I am sure that the Minister for Resources (Senator Cook) would realise, from his travels overseas, that it not only bemuses those who purchase our products but means that our credibility is lost. I am trying to say that the Government's efforts to gain the best of both sides of this argument mean that inconsistencies that are produced turn us into a laughing-stock.

The Government has a similar attitude to research. As I said, in some way this Government believes that it can justify the mining and selling of uranium but not justify research into nuclear power production in this country. In some way, by doing what most would say is totally unwise-that is, limiting any form of research-it believes it can go not only to the Australian people but to the world community and claim to be doing so with clean hands. I suggest that that is ridiculous. It is time that this Government decided whether it wants to get into or out of the industry. One thing we can say for the Australian Democrats is that at least they are consistent-they are consistently naive. They are still trying to find some way to stop the world and get off. At least they have been consistent in their position on this matter.

The economic demand for this product is soaring. It is something that the Australian Democrats should recognise. In July last year the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development Nuclear Energy Agency and the IAEA concluded that world uranium production would have to be increased vastly-according to some analysts, by 37 per cent by 1995 to meet world demands. By the year 2025 world demand would be two to five times that of 1995. I remind you, Madam Acting Deputy President, that Australia has 30 per cent of the world's uranium resources but accounts for just 12 per cent of the world market this year. If we continue to maintain the restrictive policies presently in place, we will account for only 18 per cent by 1994. Instead of earning $1 billion annually, as we should be doing, we are getting only about one-third of that figure-about $320m. We on this side of the chamber believe that provided that the safeguards, which we strongly support, are maintained and adhered to, we should be in the market and not moralising in the way that this Government has been doing.

I move to the third inconsistency that is demonstrated by this Government in its approach, and that is its attitude to further enriching and processing. In some way this Government feels that selling the product in its crudest form-that of yellowcake-and not adding any value added process to the basic product, is also in some way acting in a more moral way. In actual fact, it can better be argued that if this Government were really interested in the process of restraint, of securing adherence to the treaty, it would be better if these processes occurred in Australia. The longer that one maintains control of the nuclear process-in this case the longer that Australia maintains control of the nuclear process-the more one contributes to the safeguards regime. I would have thought that that was obvious. Therefore, if the Government wants to go down the moral path of argument, as this Government does, I would have thought that it would be easier and more logical to argue that if we retain the product longer and process it in Australia, we would be morally better off than is the case having regard to the attitude of this Government, which is simply to get it offshore as soon as possible so that it principally becomes somebody else's problem. That is the third inconsistency in this Government's approach to the nuclear industry.

In this industry technology is now changing quickly. There are great opportunities for Australia to get into the area of processing. We have quite a good basic research record in this country. There is no reason why we could not be contributing to world knowledge in this area as we seek to do in so many other areas. Not only would we be contributing to our economic well-being, which we on this side of the chamber believe is important, but also we would be building our legitimacy in contributing to the safeguards regime. In other words, we would be building our right to contribute to what I would like to see as an ever more effective NPT and a general safeguards support system.

I have not raised the subject of defence and our responsibility for defence, which was mentioned by Senator Powell. In the recent decision-making process on what form of submarine would best serve this country in the future, the Government dismissed the option of submarines powered by a nuclear reactor-I am not talking about armaments-for ideological reasons. The Government really had no choice because it is practically impossible to go down that path if there is no nuclear infrastructure to support such a submarine industry. We do not have it in this country because the nuclear industry is precluded by this Government's policies. Therefore, it simply was not an option.

I say all of this as one who on many occasions in this chamber has spoken in support of the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty and has urged in different ways that Australia contribute to its further development and security. With some 900-odd nuclear facilities in the world, one would have thought that there was enormous opportunity for diversion of nuclear products. The fact that there have been so few allegations of diversion over the decades is, I believe, a major credit to the Non-Proliferation Treaty, the International Atomic Energy Agency, to all those states which have supported it and to all those scientists who have contributed their professional working lives towards supporting it. I hope that Australia will continue to do so also.

I note the priorities as set down by the IAEA. I think those priorities are worthy of mention and support. Four priorities are listed. The first is the further development of nuclear power. This has always been one of its priorities because that is the other side of the safeguards regime. Countries will contribute only if something is done to benefit them and further development of the industry is seen as important. The second priority is the enhancement of nuclear safety. Originally this was not seen as a principal task of the IAEA. It was not concerned about the safety of nuclear reactors. It was concerned about safeguards against diversion. I am pleased to say that the Agency is now putting a much greater percentage of resources into the question of nuclear safety. Unfortunately it tended to occur after the Chernobyl experience but at least now nation states are recognising that the world community as a whole through this Agency can make a major contribution. One day I would like to see the states of the world prepared to agree on standard safety measures for reactors to become part of an international and binding safety regime in the same way as they have become part of a regime to avoid diversion of nuclear products.

The third priority set out by the IAEA, which it sees as its obligation, is the provision of technical assistance to developing countries. I am pleased that it is continuing down that path. The fourth responsibility is the ever-strengthening of the safeguards regime; in other words, the regime which provides for material accountability, for containment and for surveillance procedures.

I have said on many occasions that the strengthening is necessary. So many of the shortcomings of the regime are obvious. Such shortcomings are that there are nuclear states which are not members and that particular privileges are given to nuclear weapons states under the agreement which simply engender a reaction against the system by some non-nuclear weapons states and therefore weaken it. Of course, recent allegations of breaches require detailed and careful consideration and remedial action. As I said a moment ago, if we want to contribute to safeguards we have to build a legitimacy to get into the debate. That is one of the reasons I believe that it is in Australia's interests to build that legitimacy not only by providing as the basic resource portion of our ore bodies as fuel but also by being seen as part of the processing industry, by being prepared to engage in research that can be contributed to the Agency and that can become part of the wider world knowledge in this particularly important area of power production.

The recent intermediate-range nuclear forces treaty contributed to restraining vertical proliferation of nuclear weapons. That is commendable but, as we all know, a non-nuclear weapons state such as Australia can play only a small part in this area. There still remains a major part that we can play in achieving the equally important goal of restraining horizontal proliferation of nuclear weapons. I commend the Government for making another small but positive step forward in the form of this Bill but I urge upon it that there is so much more that this country can do towards contributing to a stronger horizontal non-proliferation regime if the Government would only open its eyes and be prepared to become consistent rather than inconsistent and change its basic attitude, which has simply had the effect of discrediting this nation overseas. I want to see the regime strengthened. When we on this side of the House are in government we will certainly act to do so. In the meantime, I would like to see this Government doing much more along that most worthwhile path.
(Quorum formed)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Nuclear Non-Proliferation (Safeguards) (Consequential Amendments) Bill 1987 is a Bill to make amendments to the Patents Act 1952 consequential upon the enactment of the Nuclear Non-Proliferation (Safeguards) Act 1987 and for other purposes. The Australian Democrats support this Bill which, to quote from the second reading speech of the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button), states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . is not momentous, but it sets in place necessary procedures to ensure that the Safeguards Act and the Patents Act operate in a complementary and harmonious fashion.
When Senator Lewis spoke earlier on this Bill he said:

It is simply a machinery Bill to ensure that the Patents Office acts with authority in meeting the requirements of the Safeguards Act without breaching the Patents Act. It has no wider implications than that.

In a nutshell, that is precisely it because past so-called safeguards have not prevented France from using our uranium in its own weapons program involving nuclear testing in the Pacific, which of course is much closer to Australia than to France. The export of Australian uranium to France is against the Australian Labor Party's own policies. The safeguards in this Bill are intended to operate in conjunction with the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) and the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons Treaty.

There are countless examples in the present monitoring system of tracking exactly where our uranium goes being a failure. Senator Wood gave details of this in his speech when he described the sorry history of monitoring discrepancies. The most notable example at present is the allegation made in Germany earlier this year that in 1985 and 1986 the IAEA lost fissile material sufficient to make 250 nuclear bombs. Just recently there has been a lot of debate in this place about allegations made by members of the European Parliament that the labels on consignments of unenrichable American uranium are being exchanged for those on uranium of Australian origin so that Australian uranium could be enriched to weapons grade-in direct contravention of the Australian safeguards agreement with Euratom.

The details of this exchange were graphically illustrated by Australian Democrats Senator Norman Sanders when he showed that Australian exports to Germany had gone astray and that Euratom, the nuclear watchdog, failed to to its job. As I said before, Australian uranium exports to France are clearly contrary to rule 94 of the Australian Labor Party policy platform which states that Australia will refuse to allow the supply of Australian uranium to France until France ceases testing nuclear weapons in the South Pacific region. These exports tend to wander around Europe in different forms-to France, Finland and even the Soviet Union. Australian uranium even ends up in Soviet nuclear weapons. So the nuclear safeguards are in fact a myth designed to keep an ignorant population happy in their beds.

I would like to remind the Senate that Senator Macklin has had for some time before the Senate the Customs Amendment (Prohibition of the Exportation of Uranium to France) Bill 1987. The notice of motion for this Bill was given on 14 September 1987. We have the unfortunate situation of our uranium being mined in our national parks. It would appear that our national heritage is being sold for 30 pieces of yellowcake. This is exemplified in Western Australia, where the public is being misled over uranium safeguards.

I would like to speak briefly about the Rudall River National Park. The Federal and Western Australian governments claim to oppose further uranium mining. The Federal Government also claims it wishes to maintain its three-mine policy, and the State Government claims to have a moratorium on mining in our national parks. But in reality, as with the safeguards, it is the almighty dollar that talks rather than anything else. In fact, the report of the Bailey Committee on Exploration and Mining in National Parks and Nature Reserves which was recently put out by the Western Australian Government recommends in summary that mineral exploration and mining should be allowed in the State's national parks and nature reserve systems. This means in reality that mining exploration is being carried on in the Rudall River National Park, the Hamersley Range National Park, the Nambung Pinnacles National Park, the D'Entrecasteaux National Park, the Fitzgerald River National Park, and the Queen Victoria Springs Nature Reserve.

The Bailey report put out by the Western Australian Government should be rejected because mining and exploration are destructive land uses and therefore are totally incompatible with the purpose of a national park or nature reserve. The mining industry cannot rehabilitate areas of natural native vegetation to a satisfactory standard. Unlike the benefits derived by society from national parks and nature reserves, mining is non-sustainable. The mining industry has free access to in excess of 81 per cent of the Western Australian national parks and nature reserves, which together cover only 5.6 per cent of Western Australia. The Bailey report did not consider the option of not allowing mining in national parks and reserves and therefore it does have an inherent bias towards exploitation. Finally, mining our national parks and nature reserves will not solve Australia's long term economic problems, because the mining industry is using the economic situation as a lever to get access to our conservation areas.

I also remind the Senate of some interesting figures for national park visits which show an increase in usage. The figures I have here are for the State of New South Wales for the years 1978-79 to 1981-82, when the visits doubled to 14.3 million. In Queensland they increased between 1975 and 1980 from 2.13 million to 3.8 million. Studies in Queensland, in particular of the Cooloola National Park, suggest that the spin-offs economically for local communities around national parks are also substantial.

I wished to speak only briefly on this Bill. Although, as I have already said, it is impossible to be absolutely sure about safeguards, the Australian Democrats do support the legislation as the support of any safeguard is better than none at all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —This debate has been longer than might have been expected for a machinery Bill. The Nuclear Non-Proliferation (Safeguards) (Consequential Amendments) Bill is supported by all of us in the chamber. It is a matter of unanimity and it is a matter consequential upon decisions already taken in the Parliament. We are in favour in this debate of strengthening the safeguards as they are in conjunction with the very important treaty to which Australia is a signatory, the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty. This debate has continued for such a long time because members of one small element of this chamber, the Australian Democrats, who sometimes describe themselves as being to the left of the Australian Labor Party and who are rejected in their arguments by the Opposition and by the Government, have, one after another, along with an independent nuclear disarmament senator, taken it as a platform to put forward their strictly minority views about the nuclear power industry and about nuclear arms.

SPEECH.PARA: I agree with my Opposition colleagues in this debate that as the Democrats want to use this debate as a platform to put forward their minority and unconvincing views to this chamber, as they do to the public, it is time for us to restate why we reject these views and point out why it is that the words of the Democrat speakers, one after another, have fallen not on deaf ears but on very alert ears not only in the Opposition but also in the Government. Alert as we are to the phoney arguments that are put forward by the Democrats, we reject them on intelligent and responsible grounds. From time to time the Democrats have even alleged that there is a vested interest among people in the Government or the former Government, that senators in the Liberal Party have a vested interest in protecting the nuclear power industry or the export of uranium from this country and the mining of uranium, or that we have a vested interest in maintaining a defence alliance with our close friends in the world. It is not because of a vested interest or some prejudice in the debate that we reject the minority arguments of the Democrats; it is because we are responsible. We believe that nuclear power is necessary to meet the energy needs of the world, that it is a safer and cleaner form of energy than coal and that where it is financially viable it should be used for the benefit of mankind. We in the Opposition and the Government are not industrial Luddites. We cannot turn back the industrial revolution or the technology revolution. We cannot turn back the need of the world for heating, for cooking or for lighting. Fifty countries in this world have nuclear power as their electricity source. The Democrats want them to abandon that. We believe that attitude is irresponsible, and we are not moved in the debate by the speakers for the Democrats on this Bill.

Beyond that, the Democrats have confused this issue of nuclear power with that of nuclear arms. However, the Opposition is not confused, and we reject the confusion that the Australian Democrats make in their blind, slavish opposition to anything that looks like uranium or is in any way connected with nuclear matters. They confuse everything and oppose the Australian uranium industry. I seriously think that they are pulling this country backwards because they have had some influence on this Government. The influence that they have had on the Government was outlined by my colleague Senator Hill when he said that we have all protested for five years that the Hawke Labor Government has restricted uranium mining to three mines. There is good uranium and bad uranium in this country. Those who got the blessing of the Hawke Government in just three mines are allowed to proceed with the mining and export of that uranium on the safeguards that have been established by the Fraser Government and bilaterally supported by both the Liberal Party and the Labor Party. The safeguards are in place and the uranium is here in Australia. It can safely be mined and exported to those who subscribe to the safeguards that we have established. The Democrats have pulled back this country by inducing the Labor Government to have half a uranium policy and half a nuclear power policy. We reject that and it has been referred to earlier.

In the second part of my remarks I want to refer to the references that the Democrats have made to the peace movement and to the Palm Sunday marches. There is no monopoly on the desire for peace. How ridiculous it would be for me as a Liberal senator and a founder and co-convenor of the parliamentary disarmament group to claim that I, as a South Australian Liberal, had some monopoly on putting forward a path for peace for this country or for the world. I would be laughed out of court. But I am afraid that that is what the Democrats are doing in this debate. They think that they have got some unique enlightenment, that they alone have the answer to peace. The rest of us in this chamber reject that false claim. On Palm Sunday we should observe what is actually happening. The Democrats and members of the Labor Party, the Liberal Party and the National Party participate in the demonstration for peace and security. Increasingly the prominence in the Palm Sunday marches for peace around our cities is falling to the churches. After all, Palm Sunday is a Christian festival. It is the day when the churches remember Our Lord coming into Jerusalem mounted on a donkey, the very symbol of peace, and leading to the events of Easter.

I am very happy to see that the churches have increasingly put their actions in line with their words and beliefs to make this a Christian march. Senator Powell, who represents the Democrats, has already acknowledged the swelling of the numbers because of the churches. But, at the same time, we see that the numbers have been falling. No one disputes that. The overall attendance at Palm Sunday marches has been declining as the people of Australia are less and less convinced by the loony left. The element that has been growing in those Palm Sunday marches is the direct Christian participation by the churches and, most noticeably, following central church services around our capital cities. So when, even after this last Palm Sunday march, the Democrats claim some monopoly of the Palm Sunday marches, they are wrong. Let me make it quite clear that the Liberal Party calls energetically for disarmament and peace. We have applauded the intermediate-range nuclear forces agreement. We look for the implementation of that recent treaty to see both the Soviet Union and the United States intermediate-range nuclear forces withdrawn from Europe and Asia-indeed, from every place. But we press on to do all that is in our power to see a 50 per cent reduction in strategic nuclear weapons. We want to see some achievement in the aspirations of Gorbachev and Reagan and of the peoples of the Soviet Union and the United States-indeed, the people of Australia. We are all pressing towards that most significant step-it is the next step in my view-on the peace agenda.

The Democrats put forward their distortion of the way ahead for peace for this country or for the world. However, I need to point out that we would be putting in jeopardy the achievement of 50 per cent nuclear disarmament reductions if we were to follow their path. It is only on the basis of stable deterrence and mutually verifiable disarmament that we will see a responsible way forward to achieve the disarmament, peace and security that we are looking for. Let it be clearly understood in this debate that the Opposition rejects unilateralism and rejects any group-left loony or otherwise-claiming that it has a monopoly on peace. The Opposition rejects the confusion of the nuclear power industry, all of the issues connected with that and the requirement for the safeguards that we have in place with the debate about nuclear weapons. Let it be restated that the Opposition does not see Australia developing nuclear weapons in the future, but we see it as essential to gain a reduction in the number of nuclear weapons that already exist in the world. We should have a responsible approach and not a head in the sand, irresponsible approach that we have had in this debate from the minority of senators, including the Australian Democrats.

I remind the Senate that for 10 years we have been hearing these arguments from the Democrats. The support for those arguments is falling in this country. The overwhelming majority of members of parliament rejects those views and supports the engagement of Australia in the mining and export of uranium. The Opposition calls for more than that-it calls for the processing of uranium to the advantage of Australia. This Parliament also calls for disarmament through mutually verifiable means and not through the irresponsible processes put forward by the Democrats. The Australian people have voted in election after election to support the policies that I am now summarising. There is no monopoly on peace or wisdom in a small left-leaning minority in this chamber. Like those who have preceded me, I support the Bill that is before us and note the rejection by the majority of this chamber of the arguments put forward by the minority that I have been criticising.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was forced to rise in this debate on listening to the rather silly remarks made by Senator Teague. Fairly obviously the problem with Senator Teague is that, having been a failure in trying to get the shadow education portfolio, he has now decided to make another portfolio presence for himself in this place. He has decided-I invite honourable senators to look through previous Hansards-to come in here during debates when he is not on the speakers list and have a go at the Australian Democrats. I am quite happy for him to do that because in fact most of the time he makes a fool of himself, as he has just done. Senator Teague should look at what Senator Jenkins, Senator Sanders and Senator Powell said in the debate, because the proposition they put forward was not that we had a monopoly on peace; we have never claimed that. In fact, it was very interesting that Senator Teague never once attempted to quote from Hansard. If he attempted to do that he would find that he would not have a quote to stand on. Nobody in our Party, or indeed nobody that we have worked with on this issue, has ever claimed a monopoly on peace. However, I discovered in Senator Teague's comments-he can look at the Hansard record if he wants to-that he characterised himself as the founder of the nuclear disarmament group.
—As one of the founders.

—Senator Teague should look at the Hansard record. I am quite happy for him to look at the Hansard record on that matter. In fact, it was Senator Colin Mason of the Australian Democrats who alone initiated the exercise and then invited others to act as co-chairmen because he wanted the exercise to be broad based.

—I take a point of order. I do not want to enter into a competition with Senator Macklin in relation to statements that have been made. Many people have been responsible for founding the disarmament group. I reject the claims made by Senator Macklin.
—Order! No point of order is involved.

—It is very interesting indeed that the man who loves to come in here and to criticise is so thin skinned that he cannot take anything said of him. Having claimed credit for the exercise from Senator Mason, who is no longer a member of this place, having big-noted himself, Senator Teague wants to continue that type of personal attack. If that is what he wants to do, he will receive the same sort of thing back. But I am not interested in engaging in that particular exercise with a lightweight such as Senator Teague. His ability to argue a point is the reason that he is still inside the paper bag. Senator Sanders has presented evidence to show that nuclear safeguards do not work. If Senator Teague has never listened to any of the arguments about the connection between nuclear weapons and the nuclear generation of electricity-and he has not-I invite him to read the speeches, which I will send him, that appeared in Hansard prior to the world knowing, even though those people who had an interest in this matter knew, that Pakistan, supported no doubt by Senator Teague at the time, was in fact generating electricity that it could not possibly use because it did not have the grid on which to use it. In fact, what Pakistan was doing was using the generation of electricity as a front to develop a nuclear weapons capacity. Of course, we now know that it has that nuclear weapons capacity. The generation of electricity was a pure front. That is why there is an intimate connection between the two.

SPEECH.PARA: The reason we have made the comment we have on this Bill is very clear, and that is that the capacity, the skills and the understanding required for the successful operation, such as it is, of a nuclear power generating industry in any country are the selfsame skills that are required for the generation of nuclear weapons. If Senator Teague cannot get that through his thick head, I give up on him. Most other people have actually recognised that intimate connection of skills. We do not make that connection simply because uranium happens to be involved; we make that connection because the skills required in those two fields are identical, and that is where one leads to the other. It is a very simple connection that Senator Teague has failed to grasp in his ignorance. I must admit that I am very sorry for him for that. In future I would like Senator Teague to refrain from making his silly and stupid comments about our position on this matter. It is a complex matter. Senator Teague wandered into the area and got his feet blown off. I suggest that in future he stay out of this debate because obviously he has not bothered to read any material on this matter.
Sitting suspended from 12.45 to 2 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate in his capacity as Minister representing the Prime Minister and as Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations. Does the Minister support the requirement of the Australian Labor Party National Executive, conveyed to members of the Parliamentary Press Gallery in a letter from the Party's Acting National Secretary, that members of the media who cover the next ALP National Conference must hold an appropriate union ticket?
—I am unfamiliar with that letter, and I shall seek to obtain an answer to the question.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. Is the Minister a member of the ALP National Executive?
—The Minister was not there.

—I hear Senator Ray's interjection. For the sake of Senator Button's reputation, I am pleased that he was not there. Mr Henderson, who I am sure Senator Button agrees is or was the Acting National Secretary of the ALP, wrote to journalists saying:

QUESTION.PARA: I am writing to advise you that at its 7 April meeting, the National Executive agreed as follows:

`That all journalists, photographers, film and sound crews working at all ALP national conferences be required to be financial members of a relevant trade union, and that they be required to produce proof of union membership at the time of their accreditation at national conferences'.

I shall not quote the rest of the letter, but that is the substance of the motion passed by the National Executive. I ask the Minister whether he supports the imposition of compulsory unionism on those who cover the National Conference, and whether he will take a stance in favour of protecting freedom of speech and freedom to pursue one's occupation in these circumstances.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was asked in the original question whether I was aware of a particular factual situation. My answer to that question was no. Senator Ray helpfully interjected to say that I was not at the National Executive meeting at which apparently this matter might have been discussed. Having said all that, I do not find the suggestion that in order to be admitted to any particular forum journalists should be members of a union to be a matter that inhibits freedom of speech, as Senator Chaney put it. What was the other part of the question?
—Freedom to practise in order to carry on their job.
—I do not regard that requirement as being either of those things.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to an article in the Townsville Bulletin on 6 April entitled `A Loans Scandal Emerges in the Sugar Daddy Game'? The article alleges a political motivation for the Export Finance Insurance Corporation's decision to secure loans made to Cuba and Nicaragua to buy sugarcane harvesting equipment from Australia. Is the Minister aware that this article was written as a result of a question and media release by Mr Alexander Downer, the honourable member for Mayo, and a question by Senator Lewis last month? Does this article misrepresent the situation in relation to loans? Does it ignore the significant assistance that the loans have provided to Australian industry? Will the Minister advise what Austoft Pty Ltd, the Australian company in question, has had to say about the allegations being made by the Opposition and the writer of this newspaper article?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —That article was drawn to my attention. I must say that I am concerned about it because the article is clearly based on an answer I previously gave in the Senate. I thought that answer would have been sufficient to stop what I regarded as an intellectually dishonest campaign by the conservative side of politics in relation to this matter. I do not want to go over old ground on the issue. However, I simply make the point that it is not the policy of this Government to put foreign governments through an ideological filter before allowing companies to do business in those countries.
—Except with uranium.
—And except for South Africa.
—I would have hoped, with the unanimous support of the Liberal Party Opposition--
—Just do not misstate the position.

—I hope with the unanimous support of the Opposition. If there is any doubt about that, I hope that the Opposition will let us know-and of course there is some doubt about the Liberal Party's attitude to that question. The point I was trying to make before Senator Lewis interjected on Senator Colston's question is simply that we do not put companies through some sort of ideological filter in relation to other countries with which Australian companies are entitled to do business. I believe that is an important principle in the administration of concessional loans and other assistance to companies involved in export markets.

ANSWER.PARA: The company that is the subject of this article in the Townsville Bulletin, which refers to a loans scandal in the sugar daddy game, is called Austoft. As I said in the Senate previously, that company is one of the two premium manufacturers of sugarcane harvesting equipment in the world. Nicaragua and Cuba produce significant quantities of sugar, and that is very important to their economies. Austoft has been very much maligned by this article and by what was said in the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —The company has not been maligned by anything I said.
—Perhaps Senator Lewis had better correct a misapprehension that the company has. I shall quote what it said:

ANSWER.PARA: Mr A. Downer and Senator A. Lewis are making political capital out of an export trade matter and are not telling the complete story.

The company goes on to make the point that overseas suppliers who are competitors of Austoft are being assisted by agencies in their countries, similar to Austrade, which will guarantee loans that will be used to buy equipment. That statement refers particularly to Germany, which is the other significant manufacturer of sugarcane harvesting equipment. The company said further:

In the particular case of the sales ex Austoft a competitor was involved and loan funds were offered by a foreign country to that competitor. The granting of this insurance facility to Austoft allowed high technology export sales to be made and kept 250 people employed at Austoft during a period of domestic uncertainty in the industry. In Bundaberg the multiplier effect of this is estimated at 6:1 and, therefore, we could readily assess that some 1,500 people were affected by this decision.

They are 1,500 people in Senator Stone's electorate in Queensland, most of whom are employed by a very good company which is competitive in world markets and which has ancillary companies, subcontractors and so on contributing to that effort. The result was that a good company was assisted through a difficult time. However, all we hear in this place is ideological criticism of that decision. The company had this further to say:

Some years ago Australia was able to export its primary products, raw materials and manufactures to clients in stable developed countries. Today we are not afforded that luxury and we must, by necessity, divert our export effort to less stable developing countries. This, of course, increases the risk of non-payment and need for insurance.
What Mr Downer and Senator Lewis fail to recognise is some essential facts about export industries in this country--

TALK.START.PARA: —If we had decent interest rates in Australia. That was the point.
—No, that was not the point you were making. Your point was quite clear. The company went on to say:

ANSWER.PARA: It rather appears to me that they-
that is, Senator Lewis and Mr Downer-
are not businessmen and some realities of risks of doing business should be brought to their attention.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Finance. Does the Minister agree with recent suggestions that the worst is over in terms of economic hardship, as has recently been stated by both the Treasurer and the Prime Minister? Does he agree that Australians, especially middle income earners, can expect an end to the fall in living standards which they have been experiencing in past few years? In particular, does he agree that there is now room for a relaxation of wage restraint?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On the question of living standards, in the long term sustainable living standards are determined by productivity with some adjustment for movements over time in the terms of trade. I do not think that is disputable. I was asked whether I think that the worst is over. I certainly do not think that the worst is over for the National Party of Australia or the coalition. Senator Stone sooner or later will spit the dishcloth out of his mouth and again wipe his boots on the Opposition Leader, Mr Howard, as he and his Federal parliamentary leader were doing for most of last week. So I certainly do not think the worst is over for the Opposition coalition. Indeed, I think that it has hardly begun. On the question of the economy--
—Keep it up. We found out in Groom how fond of you they are!

—I am sorry, Senator Chaney, I did not follow that. We all know that on Tuesday night of last week his lackeys cruised around the Press Gallery for a couple of hours painting the Opposition Leader as the macho man who had put everybody down; on Wednesday Senator Stone wiped his boots on him; on Thursday Mr Sinclair wiped his boots on him; and on Friday Mr Howard said that it was quite all right for the National Party to have a different tax policy from the Liberal Party of Australia, having said three days earlier that coalition tax policy was binding on the National Party as well as on the Liberal Party. If I may offer a bit of gratuitous advice to the Liberal Party, or repeat such advice as I offered to the Liberal Party a couple of weeks ago, and in particular to Mr Greiner in New South Wales--

—I rise on a point of order, Mr President. The point of order is not that the Minister should not offer gratuitous advice, but that he is now clearly debating the question. Indeed, I think that he is debating some other question, which is even more objectionable. I ask you to call the Minister to order.
—Order! The Minister is tending to range rather widely. I ask him to return to the question that he was asked.

—Certainly, Mr President. Is the worst over? It is a fact, Senator Stone-well, one cannot be absolutely certain that it is a fact, but it is beyond reasonable dispute-that the current account deficit for this financial year will come in at around or probably just below 4 per cent of gross domestic product (GDP). That is down a full two percentage points from where it was a couple of years ago and where it was in 1981-82. When it has fallen an extra one per cent, it will be at a lower level than the GDP growth rates recorded on average under this Government. In other words, with another one per cent fall in the current account deficit, that deficit will be lower than the average GDP growth rate, provided that that growth rate is maintained and the foreign debt as a proportion of GDP, it follows inescapably, will fall. Certainly if the worst is defined in quantitative terms, then on that assessment the worst is over.

ANSWER.PARA: The Prime Minister and the Treasurer, however, and, if I may say so, I, have all been stating for several months-and in the Prime Minister's case as recently as a couple of days ago or towards the end of last week-that Australia cannot afford to go on a wild spending spree or relax the sort of fiscal discipline that this Government has applied. The Prime Minister did not say this, but I am sure that he had it in mind: above all, Australia cannot afford the sort of wild spending spree and the fiscal ratbaggery which showed itself in the 1982 Budget and which was again demonstrated by the Opposition in the run-up to the last election campaign. We cannot afford to bring down a Budget with no economic strategy, as Mr Howard did in 1982-just a political strategy aimed at buying up a sufficient number of pressure groups by offering them either tax bribes or expenditure bribes to hopefully, he thought, get him past the next election. We certainly cannot afford that.

In regard to the matter that was raised a while ago as to the relationship in the coalition, I notice that the other day Mr Greiner had some consultations with Sir Charles Court. There are not many things that I admire about Sir Charles Court, but I do admire one thing and I also believe that he was indisputably correct: he knew how to deal with the National Party or the Country Party. He kicked it in the teeth, because it has nowhere else to go. I gave Mr Greiner that same piece of advice a couple of weeks ago. I am sure that he will take no notice of it, and in a couple of years time or in the run-up to the next election he will regret not having taken any notice of it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Leaving aside the diversionary remarks of the Minister for Finance, which were as much expected as they were in line with his normal approach to answering questions in this place, may I nevertheless ask him-in doing so I point out to him that the current account deficit this year will come in at rather lower than he claimed credit for-whether he will agree that the whole, if not more than the whole, of that improvement in 1987-88 over 1986-87 has resulted from the sharp improvement in the terms of trade? Does the Minister therefore agree that if there is any underlying adjustment in the trade and services account of the balance of payments, it is so far proving to be no more than is necessary to account for the continuing deterioration in the property income servicing account? In other words, will the Minister agree that the treadmill on which this Government's policies have launched Australia in increasing debt and continually underlying balance of payments deficit to increase that debt further, is still running as fast as ever? Will he in the light of that answer the question whether the worst is over, or whether, as Ministers in this Government only recently before the New South Wales elections were claiming, there is a long road still to go?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I said earlier, the current account deficit as a proportion of GDP stood at around 6 per cent in 1985-86. I said that there was little doubt that it would come in at 4 per cent or a little lower in 1987-88. Apparently Senator Stone does not dispute that.
—It will be about 3.3 per cent.

—We cannot be sure of that yet, although I certainly believe that it will come in at below 4 per cent. I was then asked whether the whole of that improvement was due to a movement in the terms of trade. The answer to that is no. It is true that there has been an appreciable improvement in the terms of trade. For the year ending December the improvement was, I believe, 7.6 per cent, which does not account for all of that very large improvement in that short period by a long way. Other factors contribute to the closing of the gap. For example, it should be acknowledged that to a very large extent it is a function of devaluation of the Australian dollar, though not entirely due to that. There has been a massive increase in tourism, with foreigners spending money in Australia, which has made a large contribution. It is probable that in recent months a significant factor in maintaining the import flow has been investment in plant and machinery-something which, though it would, if that sort of investment continues to grow, have a short term negative influence on our current account deficit and so on, in the long term is probably needed to solve the problem in a permanent way.

ANSWER.PARA: Finally, I commend an article published in today's Australian Financial Review and written by Michael Stutchbury which takes up, among other things, questions on the current account deficit. It points out that in 1981 when the current account deficit was running at about 4 per cent-that is, a little higher than it probably is at the moment-Senator Stone was saying it should go higher. In case people cannot be bothered getting the Financial Review to read the article, it ought to be put on the record that its conclusion is that Senator Stone has almost invariably proclaimed his infallibility on economic forecasting and economic analysis, and almost always been wrong.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: INTERNATIONAL UNION FOR THE CONSERVATION OF NATURE AND NATURAL RESOURCES

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories inform the Senate of details of the visit to Queensland by a delegation from the International Union for the Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources (IUCN), which is assessing Australia's nomination of the wet tropical rainforests for the World Heritage List?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —In a rather tacky performance in the Senate a couple of weeks ago Senator Boswell did ask whether or not the IUCN delegation was being taken on some sort of secret junket around Australia. As a result of Senator Morris's question I am now able to put the lie to that assertion. The itinerary for the visit of Jim Thorsell, Professor Hamilton and Mr Lucas has now been developed, and I think a copy has been sent to Senator Boswell. Within the limited time available for this visit appointments have been made for the delegation to see the Queensland Premier-that is, the current Premier and not the one that Senator Boswell supported-and also the Queensland Minister for Environment, Conservation and Tourism. Having listened to him a few times, I am sure he is a Minister the honourable senator does support. Various other Queensland Government officials will be met in Brisbane, and there will even be a meeting with the Queensland Government's notorious NORMA-the Northern Rainforests Management Agency. Also, Queensland Forestry Department officials will be meeting with the delegation three times on site-on the Mount Windsor tablelands, at Downey Creek and at a third site that the IUCN delegation may choose. Furthermore, an officer of the Queensland National Parks and Wildlife Service has been asked to travel with the delegation for five days. So presumably he is on the junket as well. The delegation is also going to meet with representatives of the timber industry, local Aboriginal communities, the mining industry, local councils, the Cairns Chamber of Commerce and conservation groups. That shows, of course, that the IUCN is treating this exercise seriously. It is in a short time meeting with an extraordinary number of interest groups and government officials. Of course, I have not mentioned the fact that I am meeting the members of the group as well, and we have since organised for Senator Puplick, at his request, to see them also.

ANSWER.PARA: The fact that this is going on is no surprise, and it demonstrates just how serious the IUCN views this task. I know it has been said that the IUCN is simply a rubber stamp but it should be pointed out that last year 41 of the 63 World Heritage nominations scheduled were successful; so roughly a third of the applications put before the IUCN were not proceeded with. So from the Commonwealth's point of view I would have to say that we welcome this rigorous analysis. We have nothing to hide. We have the scientific information available, and it will be produced. We are confident that, based on that information, the outstanding natural heritage that we have in our north Queensland rainforests will stand up to the test and be successfully nominated in December.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Attorney-General aware that on Friday, 9 April Dr Arthur Hempel and Mr Lawrence Etheredge were extradited from Western Australia to Israel to face charges relating to the alleged theft of the schooner Orionia, which has been returned to Israel? In the light of the statement by Senator Tate during the committee stage of the Extradition Bill 1987 and the Extradition (Repeal and Consequential Provisions) Bill 1987, on 19 February of this year, that `We do not have extradition treaties with nation states which in our opinion do not have sound legal systems', what steps will the Minister take to ensure that Dr Hempel and Mr Etheredge are treated in a correct manner and are subject to a fair trial? Has the Attorney made contact with the United States Attorney-General to monitor the trial jointly? Can the Minister assure the Senate that Dr Hempel and Mr Etheredge have had access to an attorney and that they will be legally represented by counsel of their own choice in accordance with Article 14 of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, to which Australia, Israel and the United States of America are signatories? Does the Minister know whether the trial will be in English or in Hebrew? If the latter, does the Minister know whether the defendants will have access to free interpreting and translating facilities, also in accordance with Article 14 of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question, which was asked in five parts: The answer to the first question is yes. As to the second question, following the departure of Dr Hempel and Mr Etheredge, the Australian Embassy in Tel Aviv was asked to monitor the trials and report back on their progress. Prior to the issue of the warrants of surrender, the Attorney sought advice as to the legal system in Israel. The advice confirmed that Israel's legal system is basically a common law one and that the rules of evidence in criminal justice matters are similar to those in Australia.
