The answer to the third question, concerning whether the Attorney has made contact with the United States Attorney-General to monitor the trial jointly is no, he has not. However the United States consulate in Perth is aware of the matter. As to the questions about access to an attorney of their own choice and so on, the Criminal Procedure Law 1965 of Israel provides, in section 11:

ANSWER.PARA: No person may act as defence counsel unless duly qualified to do so and unless the accused has expressed in writing the desire to be represented by him or has given him a power of attorney or he has been appointed by the court for that purpose under section 13.
Section 13 provides, so far as is relevant:

. . . where the accused not being represented by counsel is of insufficient means . . . the court may, either upon the application of one of the parties or on its own motion, appoint counsel for the accused.

The fifth question was whether we know whether the trial will be in English or in Hebrew. Dr Hempel and Mr Etheredge raised the question of the litigation language of Israel throughout the extradition proceedings. The magistrate who first heard the extradition case heard evidence that civil proceedings relating to the vessel Orionia prior to their departure from Israel had been conducted in English. The Attorney-General subsequently sought further information on this issue and was advised that while proceedings are usually in Hebrew all judges and lawyers speak English and argument before Israeli courts is often in English. He was also informed that where the defendant is non-Hebrew speaking and the proceedings are conducted in Hebrew, the defendant would as a matter of course have access to an interpreter.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Local Government and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women aware of criticism claiming that the Federal Government has excluded local government from its efforts to advance equal employment opportunity for women, and will she explain the Commonwealth's role in assisting State and local governments to promote equal employment opportunity for women?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Commonwealth's affirmative action legislation does not cover local government, as of course local governments are constituted under State Acts of Parliament. So far, only two States have developed legislation to cover equal employment opportunities in local government but I am pleased to say that in Western Australia the Equal Opportunity Act of 1984 is administered by the Directorate of Equal Opportunity in Public Employment. Part 9 of the Act requires that councils do prepare an equal employment opportunity management plan by 8 July this year. In Victoria, schedule 6 of the Local Government Bill (No. 2) is currently before the State Parliament, and it addresses the adoption of equal employment opportunity practices by councils. The Commonwealth has assisted States and councils in the development of employment opportunity equality in a number of ways. The Local Government Ministers Conference has been very supportive of this issue and has asked the National Review of Local Government Labour Markets, set up under its auspices, to address the issue of modern personnel practices, including, of course, equality of employment opportunity.

ANSWER.PARA: Under the local government development program-a program which is funded by my Department-a number of projects have been funded in the past to highlight the need for more work to be done in the area of equal employment opportunity within local government. There has been a pilot program in New South Wales. The Municipal Officers Association of Victoria has also prepared a national report on the development of equal employment opportunity in local government. The Municipal Officers Association has also undertaken a study of women's representation among elected representatives.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Finance concerned about the plight of an increasing number of pensioners with relatively small incomes from investments who are now being required to pay provisional tax? Is it a fact that about 340,000 pensioners will be paying this tax by July and up to half a million will be in that position by 1990 if the current limits remain?

—I presume that the question was addressed to me because I represent the Treasurer. It is, of course, a taxation matter and therefore it is a matter for the Treasurer, not me. I do not know whether the figures that were cited are correct. They sounded, however, to be in about the right ballpark. I believe-this is subject to confirmation-that the Treasurer is looking at this matter now, or will be doing so in the near future.
—Can the Minister for Transport and Communications advise the Senate of the outcome of his recent air services discussions with Japan?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased to be able to advise the Senate that, as a result of very successful bilateral aviation talks which concluded last week between Australia and Japan, airline passenger services between the two countries will increase by 60 per cent during 1988. Under the new agreement the total number of Australia-Japan services operated by Qantas Airways Ltd, Japan Air Lines (JAL) and All Nippon Airways will jump from the existing 21 services per week to up to 30 services per week by the end of the year. The 60 per cent figure derives from the fact that some increase has already occurred in this calendar year, plus there are different sizes of aircraft-747s and 767s-operating on the route. A 60 per cent increase in capacity overall is contemplated. This very significant increase, to be phased in throughout the bicentennial year, does of course recognise the enormous growth in recent years in the number of Japanese tourists visiting Australia and the fact that this growth is expected to continue.

ANSWER.PARA: The agreed boost to air services will begin this month with a further increase in October, but there is scope in the agreement for new services to be introduced earlier if possible. Qantas will proceed with plans to introduce more services to Sydney, Melbourne and Perth, along with additional seats to Brisbane and Cairns. In particular, there will be a second weekly service to Perth and two additional services to Melbourne, giving Melbourne daily access to Tokyo. The way is also clear for the Japanese carriers, JAL and All Nippon Airways, to introduce up to a total of five new services per week to Australian ports this year. Both countries will be reviewing demand early next year to look at services to operate from April 1989.

This is just another demonstration of the extraordinarily explosive and rapid growth in international aviation which continues to occur. It is another demonstration of the capacity of our national carrier-and the Government, as a whole, negotiating on its behalf-to secure commensurate increases in aviation access rights, notwithstanding some of the criticism we still continue to hear from more churlish-minded souls who are continuing to assert that those opportunities are not being taken advantage of.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Transport and Communications to the answer he gave me on 18 March concerning the release of confidential information on the coastwatch contract by the Department of Transport and Communications to the Labor member for Kalgoorlie, Mr Graeme Campbell. The Minister will recall that he said:

QUESTION.PARA: I have no information whatsoever about the particular matters to which Senator Knowles refers.

Is it true that Mr Vanda Gould, a director of Amann Aviation Pty Ltd, wrote to the Minister on 9 February to outline many concerns that he had, including the release to Mr Campbell of confidential information on Amann's financial backing by the Department? Is it also true that the Minister responded to Mr Gould's allegation in a letter bearing his signature and dated 30 February-a date which, to my knowledge, does not exist other than in Senator Evans's office? In view of the Minister's knowledge of this particular allegation, why did he say that he knew nothing of the matter and, hence, mislead the Senate?

TALK.START.PARA: —One explanation could be that the letter does not exist if it was dated 30 February, but we will follow up that particular exercise in metaphysics later. I still have no recollection of the matters. I will need to refresh my memory on them. All I can recall is that I was the recipient-I do not know whether I was the beneficiary, but I was certainly the recipient-of an endless series of long and turgid letters from Mr Vanda Gould throughout a substantial period-dropped copies of which invariably went to the Opposition, I notice, at the same time, although this was not acknowledged until subsequently-retailing an endless series of allegations about various alleged misdemeanours and errors of judgment perpetrated against him and his company by a variety of people. I ceased to read those letters in detail at an early stage and I replied, as I recall, not least because the matters in issue were manifestly squarely related to litigation then in existence from Amann Aviation involving the Commonwealth. The matters were obviously ones for the lawyers to resolve and, as I recall, I tended to reply in those terms. I will need to check my recollection of the particular matters to which Senator Knowles refers. If I have a further answer I will give it to her as soon as possible.
—I seek leave to table the letter from Senator Evans to Mr Gould dated 30 February.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Is it not true that the Government has decided to discontinue the full time position of the Australian Ambassador for Disarmament? Is it also true that the Peace, Arms Control and Disarmament Branch of his Department has suffered serious staff reductions? What are these measures and do they indicate that the Government believes that the pursuit of international disarmament is a part time job? Have Australia's abilities to participate effectively in international processes of disarmament and arms control been seriously reduced? Do these decisions call into question the Government's commitment to disarmament and has the notion of an Ambassador for Disarmament become a public relations exercise? Finally, do these decisions reflect yet another abandonment of Australian Labor Party principles, specifically the electoral promises to maintain with adequate resources a disarmament and arms control section within the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade and an Ambassador for Disarmament in Geneva?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Our top level representation in Geneva currently provides for three ambassadors, one each in the United Nations, disarmament and trade fields. Towards the end of this year the position of Ambassador for Disarmament and the position of permanent representative to the United Nations will be combined. There is no question of any downgrading of the Government's global priorities or activities in such areas.
—He never had a job to do in the first place.

—Senator Stone will be in the same position soon if he keeps opening his mouth in the way that he is-that is, if Mr Howard summons up the courage to do what he ought to do. There is no question of any downgrading of the Government's global priorities or activities in such areas as disarmament and human rights, which are amongst the key functions of the missions in Geneva. The staff of the two delegations will be quite unaltered apart from the merger of the two ambassadorial posts. We are able to move to this less costly arrangement without any loss of effectiveness because of Mr Butler's success as disarmament ambassador in raising Australia's standing in multilateral disarmament diplomacy. We believe that this vindicates our earlier decision to appoint a separate ambassador for disarmament.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the more general questions about staffing and so on, the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, like all other Federal departments, is undergoing substantial cuts in staffing. It is a measure of the continuing high priority that the Government attaches to disarmament that the staff resources allocated to that work have been cut less than many other areas of the Department, not counting staff previously engaged in work specific to the International Year of Peace in 1986. The Government continues to allocate considerable numbers of staff to disarmament, overseas, in the Department in Canberra and in technical agencies such as the Materials Research Laboratory and the Australian Seismic Centre. Australia is maintaining a capacity to contribute very effectively to the international processes of arms control and disarmament, including through the continued appointment, as I said, of an ambassador for disarmament, albeit a post merged with another. So it follows that the answer to the other parts of Senator Wood's question, in so far as they are anything other than purely rhetorical, is no.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Resources. The Minister should be aware that, by all forecasts, whether they be by the Bureau of Mineral Resources, Geology and Geophysics or the oil industry, in the absence of major oil discoveries, we in Australia will be looking at an import bill for oil in the early 1990s of between $3 billion and $5 billion a year, which will further disastrously affect the standard of living of every Australian. The Minister is reported as having told the Australian exploration companies on Tuesday, 22 March, that the quest for self-sufficiency in oil should not be an overriding consideration. He said:

QUESTION.PARA: There is no point in subsidising petroleum exploration at the cost of other productive sectors in the economy which would otherwise be earning the export income to pay for oil imports.

Can the Minister advise what those other productive sectors are, leaving out the gas from the North West Shelf? What does the Minister mean by `subsidies' when normal company tax is 49 per cent, yet any new offshore discoveries face a disincentive tax of around 70 per cent? Can the Minister respond to statements by the Australian Petroleum Exploration Association (APEA) Chairman, Mr Dave McDonald, that the consultative process promised when Senator Gareth Evans launched the Energy 2000 review 27 months ago had degenerated into little more than lip service to the concept and that the Government's attitude to domestic investment was at best confused and too often hostile?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —When Senator Parer rose I thought he might ask me a question about coal prices but, since Mr Sinclair has been muzzled by the coalition and has now complained that he had to withdraw his Press release supporting the Government on coal prices because he did not actually see it and it went out without his authority, Senator Parer does not have the courage to raise any questions about coal.

ANSWER.PARA: Let me go on to the question that Senator Parer, several weeks down the track after my address to the APEA conference, finds some interest in raising. I am certainly aware that, given the prospectivity of Australia, the known reserves of crude oil in this country and the expectations about the future, it is logical to assume that Australia will be facing an import bill for crude oil towards the end of the century. Whether it will be of the order that Senator Parer asserts-$3 billion to $5 billion per year-is a moot point. Senator Parer's estimate assumes that there will not be any dramatic new discoveries and that oil prices will remain considerably low, as they are at the moment-although I see that just yesterday the price rose by $1 a barrel. It is still expected by most prognoses to remain low for a long time yet. Senator Parer assumes also that Australian exploration companies will not put the effort into exploring either our continental margins or our onshore prospective areas in order to make further discoveries. I suggest that all of those assumptions throw the assessment of what the import bill might be into considerable doubt.

However, Senator Parer asks me to say what will be the offsetting other efficiencies in the economy, excluding natural gas. We know that at the end of the next year the North West Shelf project will begin exporting natural gas out of Australia to Japan and earning, as I recall-I think this figure is accurate-in excess of $2 billion a year.

TALK.START.PARA: —I asked you to exclude that.

—The honourable senator asked me to exclude it, but he was talking about sufficiencies. I am saying that we cannot exclude it when we are looking at energy. We are not aiming to achieve some mythical self-sufficiency in oil reserves when the amount of economic and other resources in this country can best be used in investing in other undertakings which will guarantee that our economy will grow and that we will become a much more vibrant economy. We are concerned not about self-sufficiency but about a strategic supply of energy reserves. I think Senator Parer ought to go away and think about that, because that is the most sensible allocation of resources in the economy. There are several other economies in the world to which I draw his attention, most notably Japan, where that is also true.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the figures that Senator Parer has given us, I overheard an interjection, I think by Senator Walsh, about his assertion that there is 70 per cent taxation on oil development in Australia. I think his interjection was that that figure is not true or is wrong. I concur absolutely with Senator Walsh. That might be a figure that some prophets on the exploration side nominate as an up-to figure, but that is not the figure that I have in front of me.

TALK.START.PARA: —Come clean. What is the higher tax rate?

—If the honourable senator pipes down, I will come to him in a minute. The Opposition seemingly wants to argue, in raising the question of a tax for economic rent purposes, that the resources of this country, which belong to the people of Australia, should not attract an exploitation tax in addition to normal company tax. If Senator Parer wants to put that proposition, I suggest that he get up and put it and try to justify it to the community, which wants a fair return on the resources that we have.

—I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. In view of the response by the Minister and as even he admits that we have a prospective import bill, although he might quibble about the size of it, does he not realise that 49 per cent, or whatever the nominal company tax rate of the day is on profits from oil, is more attractive than 70 per cent of nothing, which could occur in addition to the $3 billion or so increase in imports if the Government persists with its policy of secondary taxation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Parer assumes in asking that question that the sole determinant of whether there is exploration in this country for further reserves of crude oil is the tax regime and that, if the tax regime were changed, there would be a sudden upsurge of exploration. There are four factors which determine the level of exploration in this country. One is the price per barrel of oil that is available. That is an obvious attraction in that if it is a high price, people invest to chase the profit that is entailed, and if it is a low price, they will not. The price of oil at the moment, despite the $1 per barrel increase yesterday, is still down around our socks. It is a very low price by past standards.

ANSWER.PARA: The second consideration is the prospectivity of Australia. How prospective are we in terms of finding reserves? There are differing views about that. Held against the Persian Gulf, it is argued that we have a very low prospectivity, which is a fair enough observation. But at the APEA conference to which Senator Parer referred, the Director of the Petroleum Division of the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd., Peter Wilcox, said inter alia-I do not have a precise quote-that we write down the prospectivity of Australia; that it is much higher than people allow for. The third consideration is the operational costs, which is not necessarily a factor in this argument. The fourth factor is the taxation regime. Our taxation regime in terms of economic rent tax is comparable with those of other competitive countries and is able to be adapted to encourage exploration in areas of most need.

Finally, if Senator Parer is worried about taxes being a determinant, let us look at the statistics. APEA in its monthly bulletin of January or February reported that the number of onshore exploration wells to be drilled in Australia this year is at a record level and that there is a very large number of offshore wells to be drilled as well. If we take all those factors together, I think Senator Parer's tax argument falls into disrepute.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women aware of reports that Mr Greiner is to downgrade the Women's Co-ordination Unit by removing it from the Premier's Department and placing it in the Department of Community Services? Is she aware that Mr Greiner claims he is `interested in results, not in playing games'? Given the achievements for women as a consequence of women's affairs being significantly placed in the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet at the Federal level, what consequences does the Minister see in the mismatch between State and Federal government departments in dealing with women's issues?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question that Senator Crowley raises is a very important one and I am rather surprised that Mr Greiner should be unaware of the very excellent report A Decade of Change-Women in New South Wales 1976-1986. I would recommend it as excellent reading for members of the Opposition and also Government members although they are much more aware of what has been achieved in regard to status of women policy in New South Wales. It is of concern to me that Mr Greiner should even be considering downgrading the Women's Co-ordination Unit in New South Wales because from the Commonwealth point of view and certainly from my point of view, living as I do in Queensland where there is no such commitment to women's policy, over many years I have seen New South Wales as serving as a model in terms of its commitment. Certainly I do not want to underestimate the role that has been played by Western Australia, South Australia and Victoria in more recent years, but New South Wales has been working on developing its status of women policies over a much longer time.

ANSWER.PARA: It has been a feature of Labor governments in this country to accord the status of women to the highest possible area. In the Federal Government the Office of the Status of Women was returned by Bob Hawke to the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet. Of course, Malcolm Fraser had downgraded the Office and put it with the Department of Home Affairs. It is important to acknowledge how very significant it is for the work that is undertaken by any women's unit, whether it is at State or Federal level, to be where it can be across all government portfolios. I have talked to Senator Vanstone about the importance of this in relation to how the Office of the Status of Women functions. I am very disappointed-though not surprised, I must admit-that Mr Greiner should be making this consideration. I suggest that if he reads what has been achieved over the last 12 years he might have a better understanding of the vital role that has been played by the women's unit. I suggest that if he were to transfer the women's unit to the Department of Community Services he would in fact be marginalising the position of women in New South Wales; he would be saying that the only concern the New South Wales Government has in relation to status of women issues is in regard to community services. Obviously, women are vitally concerned with community services-I have no arguments about that-but women are concerned about every area of government activity. They are just as concerned about transport issues.
Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I might leave that to another occasion. Is it not interesting that it should be a member of the Opposition saying that this is boring.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. The Minister is inciting interjections by debating the subject and I would ask you to ask her to answer the question to enable us to proceed with other questions.
—I ask Senator Reynolds to address the Chair and I ask that interjections cease.

—I will go on with what I believe is fundamental to this question. I am sure that Senator Chaney, as a person who I believe does have some commitment to improving the status of women in Australia, will understand that it is of concern to me that Mr Greiner get a full briefing on what is necessary in terms of the women's unit remaining in his Department because it does have implications at the Commonwealth level.

ANSWER.PARA: I reported in the Senate just recently on the very good report that we received recently when officers of the Department reported to the United Nations Committee on the Elimination of all Forms of Discrimination Against Women and said that the United Nations recognised the very important work that has been done by the Australian Government over the last five years. It would be most disappointing if the newly-elected Premier of New South Wales were to do anything that would place that good reputation that we have built up over a number of years in jeopardy in any way.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. Are references in today's Press correct that as a result of the Prime Minister's intervention Dr FitzGerald has been told to rewrite portions of the review of Australia's future immigration policy to be more politically appealing? Is it true that this followed expressions of objection by some senior Australian Council of Trade Unions leaders who were shown selective details of the final report? Does the Minister agree that the review is now discredited in that the public is never to learn Dr FitzGerald's views? If the Government wanted a politically sanitised review, why did it not simply produce a White Paper out of the office of the Prime Minister or that of the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs?
—I know nothing about that suggestion. I will make inquiries and obtain an early answer.

—Is the Minister for Consumer Affairs aware of Press reports that a certain brand of wine cooler has been advertised as being `government endorsed'? Is the Government concerned that this kind of advertising could conflict with the national drug offensive, which seeks to discourage alcohol abuse? Can the Minister inform the Senate of what action he has taken about this advertisement and what the response has been?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Devlin's question relates to an article in the Sydney Morning Herald of 14 March on wine coolers. The article arose out of a Press release from Senator Haines of the Australian Democrats. She expressed concern at the availability of the Tropicana wine cooler produced by Lindemans. The concern was on the basis, firstly, that the wine cooler advertised itself as being government endorsed. The second level of concern was that there may not have been sufficient enforcement of an agreement between State, Federal and Territory Ministers as to the regulated size and ingredient composition of wine coolers. Thirdly, Senator Haines expressed general concern about under-age drinking.

ANSWER.PARA: The background to this problem is that the Federal and State Ministers have been concerned about the production of wine coolers and their proliferation and particularly concerned about the access that some people might give themselves to them, deceptively in terms of the levels of alcohol in wine coolers. Accordingly, State and Federal governments have had gazetted-it is ready for adoption-a food standard governing both the upper alcohol level being 3.5 per cent and also the package size being a minimum of a one litre container. Another aspect of the standard is total ingredient designation. Having reached that stage, the Government had been advised by the wine industry that all coolers currently under production were conforming to that standard, and we believe that they are. However-Senator Haines rightly raised this question-the claim of government endorsement of wine coolers could be deceptive and could be seen to be deceptive by consumers. The argument is that in advertising the Tropicana wine cooler as being government endorsed, although the company was referring to the size of the package and the labelling thereon, an impression could have been left with the community that the actual alcoholic product was government endorsed.

Arising out of the point that Senator Haines raised at the time, I contacted Lindemans, which produces this wine cooler, and raised the matter with it. In response it agreed not to continue production of this container labelled in such a way, and it has agreed to change the labelling to remove the government endorsement.

In closing, I thank not only Lindemans for its co-operation in ensuring that an area of misrepresentation would not be proceeded with, but also Senator Haines for raising this matter in a constructive way and accordingly for helping to achieve a positive response.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 22 March 1988 Senator McLean asked me a question relating to automated correspondence, particularly in regard to letters sent by the Department of Social Security. I have some further information to add to the answers that I gave him on that day and on the next day.

ANSWER.PARA: The nature of the work of a particular department of state, its volume of routine or standard correspondence and the size of relevant client groups are all relevant issues to the correspondence procedures adopted by departments. Accordingly, it is impossible to generalise about the use of automated correspondence. It is also impossible to generalise about the legal force of different types of such correspondence, since legal status would depend upon the purpose of the letter, the specific provisions of the relevant legislation and the actual form of the letter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-On 25 March in the Senate there was a somewhat acrimonious debate about events which had occurred in Parliament House the night before. During Question Time Senator Chapman asked me a question which contained the following allegation:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . Mr George Gear, chairman of the so-called social national price watch committee, who is reported in today's Age as saying he was `supporting the workers' by drinking for free at the non-members bar? Will the Minister dissociate himself and the Government from the totally irresponsible attitude adopted by the honourable member for Canning, who so sanctimoniously rails against alleged overcharging by doctors and others . . .
In the course of answering that question I said:
. . . the simple point which the honourable senator-
that is, Senator Chapman-
is trying to make is made by singling out an Australian Labor Party member of parliament and accusing him of outrageous behaviour, on the basis of some statement which he is alleged to have made.
A little later on I said:
He-
I was referring to Senator Stone-
has a total monopoly on morality in these matters and suggests that nobody else has any.
I went on to say:

We can play this game in the Parliament. I could dig up . . . a Liberal Party senator who was found lying on the lawns last night, and ask whether he paid for his drinks. But I am not going to do that, because there is absolutely no point in it except in the minds . . .

I understand that that remark has been misinterpreted as my alleging that I somehow found a Liberal Party senator lying on the lawns the night before and associated it with some particular person. That is not so. I must say that in the course of the now 14 years that I have been here incidents of that kind have not been beyond my notice. In fact-I will be quite blunt about this-in the course of that time I have seen incidents of that kind involving Liberal members of Parliament and, just as Senator Chaney said to me this morning when we had a discussion about it, I have seen Labor members in that situation too. There is no dispute about that. Anybody who tried to dispute those facts over a period of time would be taking himself a little seriously. Those events do occur.

TALK.START.PARA: —What, lying on the lawns? You do not mean lying on the lawns, surely?

—I regard lying on the lawn as a totally innocuous offence. It is a very good thing to lie on the lawn. If it were accompanied by drunkenness or other morally reprehensible activity-horizontal refreshment, as it is sometimes called- it would be reprehensible; but lying on the lawn in itself is not.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to make it quite clear that, in so far as I made that remark, I was not seeking to apply it to any Liberal senator. I do not know, but I do not believe that any Liberal senator was in that situation on the night in question. If anybody feels that the cap fits, we will all keep it secret. But I do not believe that anybody from the Liberal Party side of the House was in that situation. If my remark has been interpreted in that way, I apologise. I was trying to give the Parliament an example of how, by making these unsubstantiated allegations, we can debase the process of debate in this House, and I did not want to do that.

DEBATE.TITLE: MID-TERM REVIEW OF THE CAR PLAN

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a statement entitled `Mid-term Review of the Car Plan' and to move to take note of the statement.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —In May 1984 I announced in this chamber a new policy package for Australia's passenger motor vehicle (PMV) industry. That plan was an early and major initiative by this Government to begin the process of change, renewal and revitalisation of Australia's manufacturing sector. We faced at that time a profound sense of pessimism and lack of direction which had come to permeate our motor vehicle industry. That is not surprising. There were eight or ten car plans in the 12 years before the 1984 plan was announced. Through the passenger motor vehicle plan the Government sought to encourage confidence where there had been uncertainty. We sought to foster a shared strategic vision after a decade of crisis containment. The plan set out to take an important Australian industry in difficulty into a position of competitive strength in the 1990s.

SPEECH.PARA: The plan was from the outset a key element of the Government's approach to industry policy. It was established to provide the framework for the necessary transition from a high-cost domestically oriented industry towards a more competitive, internationally oriented industry supplying Australians-and the world-with better quality automotive products at more reasonable prices. The agenda for the industry in the 1990s set the following long term objectives:
The industry needed to be able to prosper, with lower levels of government assistance.
It must provide consumers with quality products, at reduced prices in real terms.
The necessary restructuring needed to be carried out with minimum levels of disruption.

While most, though not all, of these objectives are being met, they remain the objectives which the Government seeks to achieve through its PMV policy. To allow us to achieve the objectives we set up the Automotive Industry Authority (AIA) and asked it to embark on a strategy with the following elements:
Rationalisation of the industry in terms of models and manufacturing groups.
An increase in the competitiveness of the industry to become an area of strength of the Australian economy rather than weakness.
Arrangements to accomplish the changes with minimum disruption and cost.

These strategies remain as relevant today as they were in 1984 and the industry, with the active participation of the Automotive Industry Authority, has made substantial progress in implementing these strategies:

After only three years there has been major rationalisation of producers. Holden's and Toyota are to enter into a joint manufacturing venture, while Nissan and Ford are investigating ways in which they, too, can integrate their manufacturing activities.
By the end of next year I expect that the number of models produced in Australia will have reduced from 13 to eight. Average volume per model will have increased from 25,000 units to over 40,000.

Automotive exports reached $755m in 1987, an increase of $290m or 63 per cent over the previous year. This is almost double the level of 1984. Other export programs which are planned or about to be implemented, promise a continuation of this growth in dollar terms over the next two or three years.

Investment has also increased sharply. For example, in the vehicle sector, investment has risen from an average of $194m per annum in the period 1982 to 1984 to $503m per annum in the period 1985 to 1987. This shows confidence in the viability of Australian car manufacture into the next century.
In the past four years, the industry has embraced the challenge of restructuring, in spite of a very weak vehicle market.
The plan has enabled this to happen without major disruption to the people employed in it-with one notable exception: the closing down overnight of the Besco Batteries plant in Sydney.
Even where there have been plant rationalisations to improve overall efficiency, these have been achieved with long term planning, and significant consultation with the work force.

The terms of the plan have always provided for a mid-term review of its progress. That review has been carried out by the Automotive Industry Authority with the aim of ensuring that the plan's mechanisms are continuing to reinforce the strategy and promote achievement of the objectives as we move towards the 1990s. The review found that while good progress had been made there was room for improvement. It concluded that the better competitive environment for the Australian industry now enabled some acceleration of the original plan provisions to ensure that the incentives for adjustment are maintained. The review also found that there was room for improvement particularly in the objective of achieving more affordable cars for consumers. The level of prices of local production is a real concern to the Government.

The initial plan had, as an objective, a reduction in real prices over time. This objective remains. The Australian consumer deserves to receive benefit as soon as possible, given the level of assistance afforded this industry. Resulting from that review, the recommendations made by the Authority and consultation with the industry and its unions, is a series of adjustments to the mechanisms of the plan to ensure that the plan remains on track and the objectives are achieved by 1992.

The primary objective of the decision I am announcing today is to reinforce the original plan framework. But there is a secondary objective. The Government is also taking the opportunity provided by the improved competitive position of the Australian industry to ease the passage of the industry into the post-plan environment from 1993. An abrupt shift in the policy environment at the end of the plan would be in no-one's interest. The Government had considered announcing this decision in the May statement but due to the potential impact on the motor vehicle market of delaying the announcement we have decided it should be released without delay.
I now turn to the specific refinements to the plan decided by the Government. Details are provided in an accompanying paper.
I seek leave to have the remainder of the statement incorporated in Hansard because documents have been circulated containing the specific provisions.
Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-
Quota/Tariffs

The major unforeseeable change since 1984 has been the fall in the value of the Australian dollar. International competitive pressure on the Australian car industry has slackened considerably. The Government intends to re-assert that pressure in several ways to restore the incentives for change originally envisaged.

First, from today tariff quota protection for the Australian industry is abolished. These quotas, which have been in place in some form since 1975 were not to have been finally withdrawn until 1992. This decision will be recognised in Australia and abroad as a milestone for an industry getting back on its feet. In taking this historic decision the Government noted that this was a further demonstration of Australia's commitment to the current round of Multilateral Trade Negotiations.

Second, tariff rates are to be reduced faster and further than originally announced. From today, the operative tariff of 57.5 per cent is to be reduced to 45 per cent. There will be further annual reductions from 1989 leading to a rate of 35 per cent in 1992.

To retain competitive relativities, tariffs on light commercial vehicles and four wheel drives are to be reduced immediately from 35 per cent and 25 per cent respectively, to 20 per cent and will then be phased to 15 per cent by 1992. The Government is pleased that these reductions will be a direct and immediate contribution to containing costs for business and farmers.
Local Content
The Government has given particular attention to the local content arrangements of the current Plan.

The Australian component producers, as a result of the Plan's stability, the depreciation of the Australian dollar particularly against the Japanese yen, and the 85 per cent local content scheme have found themselves in a very competitive position compared with imports.
In addition there has been extensive company rationalisation which has created a significant number of sole suppliers in this sector of the industry.

While some components companies have taken advantage of these benefits to improve their general performance a significant number have not. This lack of performance has come about because this sector has tended to experience less adjustment pressure from the Plan than other areas of the industry.
The components sector should be subject to the same pressure for change as other parts of the industry.
This will be achieved within the framework of the 85 per cent local content scheme.

The system of prohibitive compounding penalties imposed on Plan producers for non-achievement of the 85 per cent local content target will be removed. They will be replaced from 1 January 1989, by a less stringent system of non-compounding penalties on imported content, in excess of the 15 per cent duty free concession available to plan producers. Beginning in 1989, these penalties will be the same as the duty rates applying to passenger motor vehicles. The additional flexibility to be provided to plan producers by this measure will add to the competitive pressure on component suppliers.
Export Facilitation

The aims of the export facilitation arrangements of the Plan are to facilitate produce rationalisation and to reduce component costs in Australia, as well as to open doors for exports of vehicles and components in their own right. The Car Plan seeks to give the Australian industry every opportunity to join in the increasingly integrated global market for vehicles and vehicle components.

The Government values the export facilitation arrangements and the achievements which have already flowed from them. Major overseas markets have been prised open where they would otherwise have remained closed. Production runs for certain components have been increased towards world scale. Export facilitation will continue to be a feature of the Car Plan. Details of the changes proposed are in the accompanying paper. In essence there will be an expansion of the available credits of 5 per cent although these will only be earned at 50 cents of export credits for each dollar of exports. The changes we have made in this area partly restore the effect of this scheme envisaged in 1984.
International Trading Practices

The Government is committed to ensuring that the Australian industry not be disadvantaged by unfair trading practices by exporters to Australia. Accordingly, I have instructed the Automotive Industry Authority and the Australian Customs Service to intensify surveillance.
Monitoring and Review

These adjustments to the Plan have been designed to re-establish the competitive circumstances for the Australian industry originally envisaged in the Plan. The Government does not expect therefore, that there will be serious disruption of production or employment as a result of the adjustments.
Nevertheless I have instructed the Automotive Industry Authority to monitor and report to me on the impact of the adjustments.
Post-Plan Review

Consistent with the Government's concern to provide a stable environment for longer term industry planning, I am confirming today the Government's intention to provide reasonable notice of the environment to be faced by the industry after the Plan ends in 1992.

To provide the necessary period of notice, the Government envisages that a reference would be sent to the Industries Assistance Commission in 1991, for consideration by the Government early in 1992. However, it should be clear from the nature of the changes I have announced today that the present Plan-as adjusted-is very much a transitional mechanism designed from the outset to enable our automotive sector to move from the difficulties of the 1970s to a less protected, more open environment in the 1990s.
New Zealand

The Government is conscious of the potential implications of these changes for trans-Tasman rationalisation. The changes to motor vehicle arrangements in New Zealand recently announced by the New Zealand Government may have corresponding importance.
Accordingly, I have spoken with Mr Caygill, my counterpart in New Zealand, and we have agreed to begin immediate discussions between officials about a range of issues.
Implementation Arrangements

Legislation will be necessary to effect the changes in tariff rates. The Government will be introducing the changes in the context of a Customs Tariff Amendment Bill as a matter of urgency. Alterations to administrative arrangements will be published in a forthcoming Australian Customs Notice.
Conclusion
In 1984, I announced a policy for this industry which set clear goals, and a means to achieve those goals. The automotive industry has accepted the challenges I put before it in 1984.
Restructuring is taking place without signifi- cant disruption.
Exports are increasing significantly.
The industry has been investing heavily to enable it to compete with reduced levels of assistance.
The measures I have announced today ensure that all we have so far achieved is not lost.
And in addition, it creates the right environment to achieve those aspects of the Plan which have not yet been realised.
CHANGES TO ASSISTANCE ARRANGEMENTS FOR THE PASSENGER MOTOR VEHICLE INDUSTRY
The broad outline of the changes is summarised below:
Import Regime
Tariff quotas have been abolished with effect from 13 April 1988. Also with effect from that date and subject to the passage of necessary legislation through Parliament:
The previous tariff of 57.5 per cent on CBU passenger motor vehicles is to be 45 per cent and will be phased down to 35 per cent by 1 January 1992 along the following lines:
42.5 per cent-1 January 1989
40 per cent-1 January 1990
37.5 per cent-1 January 1991
35 per cent-1 January 1992
CKD packs and certain OE components will now attract the CBU tariff rates.

The tariff on CBU light commercial vehicles and CBU and CKD 4WD vehicles (including amphibious vehicles) has been reduced immediately to 20 per cent. This tariff will be further reduced to 15 per cent in 1992 along the following lines:
19 per cent-1 January 1989
18 per cent-1 January 1990
17 per cent-1 January 1991
15 per cent-1 January 1992
The tariff on CKD light commercial vehicles packs has been reduced to 10 per cent immediately and the differential with the tariff for CBU light commercial vehicles will be maintained.
Margins of preference applying to goods of Developing Country, Canadian and Forum Island origin remain unchanged.
Goods of Papua New Guinean origin remain free of duty.
Arrangements to apply to trade with New Zealand will be finalised following consultations with the New Zealand Government under CER.
Local Content

The present requirement for Plan producers to meet an average local content target of 85 per cent of the value of their production remains unchanged. Plan producers retain their right to import 15 per cent of the value of their production duty free.

However, while the penalty duty for OE components not complying with the local content target will remain unchanged for 1988 it will be aligned with the CBU tariff rates from 1 January 1989, to be applied as necessary at the end of each calendar year, as follows:
42.5 per cent-1 January 1989
40 per cent-1 January 1990
37.5 per cent-1 January 1991
35 per cent-1 January 1992
Export Facilitation

The export facilitation scheme for Plan producers is to be amended to provide that the upper limit for export credits under the scheme be increased to 20 per cent of value of production in 1988 with a credit earning of 50 cents in the dollar on the export performance above 15 per cent.

The component producers' scheme is to be amended to provide that the upper limit to export credits under the scheme be increased to 25 per cent of original equipment sales in 1988 with a credit earning of 50 cents in the dollar on the additional export performance.
The importers' scheme is to be maintained in its present form and extended for a period of two years beyond the end of the present Plan (i.e. two years beyond 31 December 1992).
With effect from 1 January 1988 the current two year limit for carry forward of surplus local content is to be removed.
The transfer of local content as well as the transfer of export credits between Plan producers is to be permitted.
Under all export facilitation schemes export credits are to be available for use in the year they are earned and not be restricted by the previous 15 months validity limitation.
Unfair International Trading Practices
International prices for vehicles will be monitored to detect any unfair practices that may arise and enable appropriate action to be taken to combat any adverse effects on Australian industry.
Post-Plan Review

The new arrangements, with the exception of the export facilitation arrangements for importers, will apply until 31 December 1992 with arrangements after that time to be determined following an inquiry by the Industries Assistance Commission to be initiated in 1991. The industry will be given reasonable notice of any changes resulting from this inquiry.
Further Information
Details of the new arrangements are being incorporated in the Passenger Motor Vehicle Manufacturing Plan and will be the subject of a forthcoming Australian Customs Notice.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the statement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me say at the outset that the coalition parties welcome the Government's announcements today of changes to the passenger motor vehicle car plan. The changes are necessary because of the limited competition in the industry due to the devaluation of the Australian dollar and other factors reducing pressure for restructuring in the industry. They are also necessary because the plan of the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button), as he admits in the statement, has clearly failed to achieve the one objective that is of major importance to most Australians; that is, that the cost to Australians of a new Australian produced motor vehicle would fall. In other words, the Minister's proposal in the original plan, repeated today, is to deliver quality vehicles at reduced prices in real terms. It may very well be that the quality of Australian vehicles has been improving, but in the meantime prices have been going through the roof. I refer to a Press release which I issued on 23 January this year in which I stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The Labor Government's actions are harming the interests of Australian consumers and removing the new car option from ordinary Australians. It now takes the average worker 46 weeks wages to buy a standard Commodore compared with less than 39 weeks wages as recently as 1985.

That very much goes to the sort of thing that I was talking about this morning during the debate on the Textiles, Clothing and Footwear Development Authority, namely, that frequently Senator Button says things with which the whole of the Senate, in fact most people in Australia, would agree. But the truth of the matter is that his Government fails to deliver, as indeed it has failed so very much to deliver in relation to the motor plan-that is, the position is not in accord with Senator Button's words or rhetoric about the Australian motor plan.

Changes to the plan have become necessary. In essence the reason is to compensate for the failings of government policies and actions. This Government sent the dollar through the floor and kept interest rates high. The combined effect through higher component costs and reduced competition has resulted in car sales reaching the lowest levels in 25 years. Importers have been at their wit's end and car yards have been closing across the nation. In that same Press release that I mentioned earlier, issued on 23 January this year, I stated:

Car prices have increased by about double the rate of increase of the Consumer Price Index over the last two years and sales of new motor vehicles have declined to the levels of the early 1960s. Industry figures show that about 447,000 new motor vehicles were sold in 1987 which is almost 250,000 less than in 1985. As a result, production of cars has also declined dramatically.

Some of the other actions of this Government that contributed to this-no doubt Senator Button would attempt to exclude himself being responsible for these things but, as I said earlier today, he is after all third in the seniority of this Government; so he must be responsible for the collective decisions of this Government-included tax changes such as the fringe benefits tax and sales tax changes. Today's changes to the car plan are clearly therefore a response to the Government's own policy failings.

The Opposition, unfortunately, has not had the benefit of examining the Australian Automotive Industry Authority review report and so it is difficult to comment on the appropriateness of the fine details of some of the changes. We have also not had the opportunity to consult with the industry, either the car makers or the component suppliers, to hear their concerns or the likely effects of the details. The Opposition has always supported the basic direction of the car plan and, as I have said, in general we support the changes the Minister has outlined. Today's announcement of changes to the sectoral plan invalidates many of the Government's policy undertakings and destroys any predictability about Government actions for industry.

As I have said, in order to provide predictability to managers of industries, we have indicated that we will support sectoral plans when we come into office after the next election. But we have always made it clear that if circumstances arose such that it was necessary or desirable to change the plans in some way or other we would do so, but we will do so following consultation with relevant industries. However, I question whether the Minister or his Department has adequately consulted with the various elements of the affected industries, particularly as it appears that only the Minister and the Department have seen the Automotive Industry Authority report. The Minister's Press release describes it as stage 2 of the car plan. In fact, as I say, it is a change forced upon the Government by circumstances.

The Minister says that this has all happened as a result of the devaluation of the Australian dollar. The truth of the matter is that the dollar fell through the floor back in May 1985. Rather than the dollar devaluing, in fact its value has been increasing, revaluing upwards, in recent weeks. I wonder whether Senator Button thought that he had to get his plan out before the value of the dollar got up too high and he would not be able to go on with the plan which, no doubt, has been in his mind now for at least two and possibly three years. Senator Button frowns at that suggestion, but the truth of the matter is that, although he says that the plan is being introduced as a result of the devaluation of the Australian dollar, the massive devaluation of the Australian dollar occurred back in May 1985. So the Minister must have had this plan floating around as a possible option since that date.

The truth of the matter is that the passenger motor vehicle industry has been waiting for, expecting and anticipating changes to the plan because of the devaluation of the dollar and especially its devaluation in relation to the Japanese yen. It is that devaluation which has made Japanese motor cars so expensive in Australia. The result of that has been that the tariff quotas have become unnecessary to protect Australian car manufacturers. The value of the Japanese yen and the value of the German mark in relation to the Australian dollar-the change in the relative value of both currencies has been massive-have forced up the price of cars imported from Japan and Germany to such a extent that Australian car manufacturers have not had to worry about tariff quotas. If I recall correctly, although the quota was at about 85 per cent, in fact about 87.5 per cent of motor vehicles being sold in Australia today are manufactured in this country.

One matter I wish to raise with the Minister is the speculation about tariff changes. Let me outline to the Senate the speculation over tariff changes in recent months. During the election campaign in 1987 Senator Button commented that he was thinking of implementing across-the-board tariff cuts. His Treasurer, Mr Keating, disagreed with Senator Button, saying that across-the-board tariff cuts would not be implemented. No doubt Mr Keating had smelt the breeze of the election and decided that he would not have a bar of such a proposal. As I recall it, about Christmas time Mr Keating actually started to talk about across-the-board tariff cuts. I understand he floated a cut of about 25 per cent. In January this year Senator Button's Department originally started to talk about a 25 per cent across-the-board tariff cut. Then there was a Press leak or a Press release-I am not sure which-in which the Department indicated that it was considering a 20 per cent across-the-board cut.

On the other hand, Treasury mooted the elimination of tariffs over a five-year period. The Centre for International Economics said that across-the-board cuts should be larger than 25 per cent. The Australian Chamber of Commerce welcomed Treasury's zero option. The Confederation of Australian Industry demanded consultation with business before changes occurred and said that it preferred an industry by industry approach. The Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, said that decisions on protection would be made at some time during 1988. The National Farmers Federation called for a 20 per cent cut for all industries. The Australian Chamber of Manufactures called for a phasing in of tariff cuts coupled with a reduction in government imposed burdens. The Business Council of Australia argued that across-the-board cuts would be more acceptable when the cost of transport, regulation, taxation and inefficient labour practices was addressed. The Metal Trades Industry Association and the Textile, Clothing and Footwear Council of Australia warned of the impact of across-the-board cuts. That was not bad speculation on tariff cuts for the month of January.

We then move to February of this year. The Metal Trades Federation of Unions threatened industrial action if across-the-board cuts were introduced. The Federated Chamber of Automotive Industries pleaded that the key elements of the car plan should remain unchanged, irrespective of tariff changes. During February Senator Button affirmed that tariff cuts would be made but said that the extent and means of cuts were still uncertain. Mr Dawkins claimed that Australia would become an `impoverished anachronism' if the Government ducked from protection reduction. Still in February, the Victorian Employers Federation said that it was unrealistic to expect Australian industry to invest against a background of changing tariffs. The Australian Chemical Industry Council believed that across-the-board cuts would lead to a drastic drop in investment within industry. The Australian Chamber of Manufactures revealed that some sectors of Australian industry had already begun to delay making investment decisions because of the uncertainty. Any sudden changes in tariffs would have a serious impact on industry confidence. Finally, during February Senator Button said that no industry would be exempt from tariff cuts.

Somewhere along the line the Government began to realise that the speculation about tariff cuts was doing immense damage to industry in Australia because people were deferring investment decisions while the Government made up its mind what it was going to do. The deferral of investment decisions is causing drastic problems for this country at present because we need major investment in industry. Clearly the speculation about tariff cuts is harming that investment. During March there was very little speculation about tariff cuts, but this month Cabinet's structural adjustment committee has been talking about and leaking information to the Press or issuing Press releases-I am not sure which-about its consideration of various proposals. Last week it was talking about a 15 per cent across-the-board tariff cut. Over the weekend we read that it was talking about a 10 per cent tariff cut over a period of five years. Yesterday Mr Kerin, the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, announced a comprehensive review of assistance programs for mining, agricultural and energy industries and referred to the $1.2 billion worth of assistance to industry. Apparently Treasury is now reported as favouring the elimination of all tariffs over a 10-year period.

The significance of all of that is that this massive speculation has been creating great problems for Australian industry and has resulted in almost a cessation of investment in plant and equipment while the Government decides what it will do. As I said, yesterday Mr Kerin made his announcement about what will be happening in relation to primary industries. Today Senator Button made his announcement in relation to the motor vehicle plan. His announcement today is of, I think, a 21.7 per cent cut in tariff protection to this industry, and the abolition of tariff quotas. The abolition of tariff quotas is unimportant, as I have said, because as a result of the devaluation of the Australian dollar the quotas have not been used. However, the cut of tariff rates from 57.5 per cent to 45 per cent is significant, because other industries around the nation will be speculating as to what the May statement will contain for them.

TALK.START.PARA: —I'll bet.

—Senator Button says, `I'll bet'. He knows as well as I do that that means that investment decisions will now be deferred until after the May statement. I call upon the Government to come out and tell industry now. They should not wait until the May statement. After all, Senator Button said in his Press release today that the Government had considered announcing this decision in the May statement but, because of the potential impact on the motor vehicle market of delaying the announcement, has decided to release it immediately. So should the Government immediately announce its decision in relation to all other industries. It should do so now. Admittedly, to this Government May may seem not to be a long time away. However, to those people whose future is dependent upon the Government's decisions in this area, it is a long time away. This damaging speculation will in no way be stopped by what Minister Kerin said yesterday and what Minister Button said today.

SPEECH.PARA: The problem with the Labor Party simply lowering the protection is that it does not also free up the rigidities of the labour market and reduce some of the regulatory burden of the industry. I am not here particularly talking about the passenger motor vehicles industry, because there has been much movement in that industry. I congratulate the manufacturers, the employees and the union involved for their ability to try to be flexible. I am talking about the Government's speculation about across-the-board tariff cuts. The Government's problem is that there must be a freeing of the rigidities in the labour market. There must be an attack on the burden of Government regulations and a deregulation of the labour market to allow the benefits of a lowered protection regime to flow through the community. Under the Australian Labor Party Government, industry is being or would be squeezed by reductions, while in effect the rigid industry structures, which are becoming worse under this Government, have tied industry's hands behind its back.

We call upon the Labor Party in government to move into the area of deregulating the labour market and making a substantial and worthwhile reduction in the burdens of regulations. For example, we point out that three months ago the Government announced that the Industries Assistance Commission would conduct an inquiry into government non-tax charges on industry. I understand that at this stage the Industries Assistance Commission still has not received terms of reference. In January I called on industry to identify the trade-offs which it needed to accompany any reductions in protection. There have been reports that Ministers favour such trade-offs. However, the only trade-off here is a watering down of the local content arrangements. Industry can only hope that some trade-offs will be announced in the Treasurer's May statement.

When the Government announced this car plan in 1984 it set objectives, and today Senator Button has repeated the objectives, including the one objective to which I particularly referred, which is to provide Australian consumers with quality products at reduced real prices. In the light of current prices of motor vehicles in Australia, that objective must be seen not only to have failed but also to be quite laughable. It seems to me to be quite strange that with Australian car prices the way they are, with importers having considerable difficulty bringing in vehicles at a more modest price for Australians, it is a matter of great criticism of this Government that it has taken so long for it to get around to announcing this motor vehicle plan. It describes the plan as stage 2, but in effect it is a variation of the plan forced upon the Government by the crisis of the dollar devaluation, the Government's fringe benefits tax and sales tax, and the Government's maintaining and propping up of high interest rates in the community.

I do not resile from my opening remarks that the coalition parties support the changes introduced by the Minister. However, we say that it has taken the Minister a long, long time to get around to introducing these changes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish briefly to associate myself with the remarks just made by my colleague Senator Lewis in relation to Senator Button's ministerial statement this afternoon. In speaking to the motion of condolence in relation to the late Sir William McMahon yesterday afternoon, I said that perhaps the finest hour of Mr McMahon, as he then was, was when during the 1960s he waged a persistent and courageous battle against the heavily protectionist policies then being introduced into our industrial structure by the then Department of Trade and Industry and its then Minister.

SPEECH.PARA: It is true that, as Senator Button said this afternoon, since that time the Australian car industry has been pretty much of a shambles. However, as my colleague Senator Lewis very cogently said, and gave a good deal of chapter and verse in so doing, the shambles did not end with the introduction of the present car plan. Nothing could better illustrate that conclusion than the fact that a major change in the parameters of that plan has been announced by the Minister this afternoon. As Senator Lewis said, it is the massive devaluation of the Australian dollar that has produced the outcome which today we are seeing the Government seeking to adjust by way of this ministerial statement. One might almost think that the devaluation of the Australian dollar came, so to speak, as a result of the intervention of some set of circumstances totally unrelated to the policies of the Govern-ment.

TALK.START.PARA: —An act of God, almost.

—An act of God, as Senator Chaney has suggested. One might agree with that very much-that it has nothing to do with the policies of the present Government. Indeed, the Minister on page 6 on his statement said:

SPEECH.PARA: The major unforeseeable change since 1984-
that is, since the plan was put down-
has been the fall in the value of the Australian dollar.

I think that the Minister can fairly claim that the fall in the value of the Australian dollar at the time it occurred, and perhaps even more generally, was in a sense unforeseen in that it was not predicted at that time, but the fact is that it did not come about by chance. It came about because of the overwhelming lack of confidence which was induced in our foreign exchange markets by two circumstances. The first was by the generally growing loss of confidence in the competence of the present Government to conduct the affairs of this country, symbolised by the growing size of our overall balance of payments deficit; and, secondly, and in particular, by the shambles which arose in February 1985 at the time of the so-called MX missile crisis, which caused many people overseas to wonder what was going on in Australia and to think that perhaps it was time to remove from this country any or at least some of the investments they may previously have had here.

I focus on the words `major unforeseeable change since 1984' simply to underline the point already made by Senator Lewis that the situation we are examining has not come upon us suddenly today or been due to an act of God, as Senator Chaney quite rightly suggested. It was due to the policies of the present Government. As Senator Lewis also said, that was just over three years ago. At the time I was writing a newspaper column for the Melbourne Herald and the Sydney Morning Herald. I have not looked up the precise date, but within six to 12 months of that event I wrote a newspaper column in which I pointed out to Senator Button, who was the Minister at the time, that certain consequences of the major fall in the value of our currency had occurred at that time fairly recently. I suggested that one of those major consequences was that he should move quickly-I underline the word `quickly'-to remove the quite fortuitous amount of additional protection which had been handed out to our industrial interests, including those in the car plan, by that event, but which was not in fact allowed for at the time when the plan was brought down because, as Senator Button's words today confirmed, it was unforeseeable.

Giving the Minister, therefore, the extreme benefit of the doubt and saying that he might have taken six to 12 months to come to the same conclusion, one would have to say that he has wasted at least two years since that time in coming to the conclusions at which at last he seems to have arrived. Again, I associate myself entirely with Senator Lewis when he said that of course we welcome the changes which have been announced this afternoon. Our criticisms go not to those changes, but firstly to the fact that they represent not at all a triumph of the plan, a triumph of the adjustment process which the plan as such was supposed to bring about, but rather pure circumstance, and indeed a circumstance brought about by a failure of other Government policies.

Only a few weeks ago on 23 March the Opposition raised a matter of public importance calling upon the Senate to note the failure of this Government to address the causes of the serious decline in Australian living standards. As I said in that debate-and Senator Chaney may also have referred to this same matter in that debate-one of the simple, clearly understand- able, easily recognisable symptoms of that failure to maintain living standards in this country has been the manner in which motor car prices have soared during the time this Government has been in office. As I pointed out at the time, this explosion in the price of motor vehicles between May 1984 and December 1987 has raised the price of a Ford Laser by 63 per cent. To put the best possible complexion on the matter from the Government's point of view, I would point out that in the same period the price of a Ford Falcon has risen by 43 per cent. I do not necessarily want to associate cause and effect between what we or anybody else might have said at that time about motor vehicle prices and the Government's announcement today, but we were pointing to a general sense of anger in the Australian community about what has happened to car prices. I am glad to see that the community's anger, with whatever help the Opposition has been able to give in expressing that anger here in this place, has forced the Government finally, at least two years later than it should have, to take account of these developments-and better late than never.

I have to say from where I sit in this chamber that I particularly welcome the reduction in the level of protection that is now, belatedly, given on light commercial vehicles, and four-wheel drive vehicles. Among other things, those vehicles are particularly important to the small business community, including those quintessential small business people, the farmers. Given the mess which this Government has been making of our economy, I believe that it is certainly desirable that the protectionist playing field should be somewhat levelled in the way in which the Minister has announced today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to speak for very long this afternoon, but I would preface my remarks by pointing to the figure which the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) has given us in his paper `Mid-Term Review of the Car Plan'. In the paper he said that in 1987 automotive exports reached $755m. I draw attention to the fact that those of us who were expected to comment on this paper were given a copy of it at 1 o'clock. Here we are at this time, when it is not yet 4 o'clock, and we are expected to make some intelligent assessment as to where that document is heading us. We have seen several times recently that major Government documents have been submitted and debated on the same afternoon. The Australian Democrats reserve the right to comment further on this paper and the implicit adjustments to tariffs and various other matters implied in it when we have had more time to examine the details closely.

SPEECH.PARA: The Button car plan, so-called, is good and bad in parts. It is good in the sense that perhaps for the first time we have seen an Australian government taking a rather longer view of planning some part of Australian society, the economy, than has been the case hitherto. But the plan is bad in the sense that this view is still incredibly short term and single-minded. Last night I had the fortune to hear a person who is visiting this Parliament from the Swedish Commission for the Future. That gentleman in looking at Swedish health models, society models as they would impinge on health in Sweden, spoke of mid-term and long term planning. In Sweden, evidently, mid-term planning means looking 10 to 15 years into the future. Compare that with the Button car plan.

TALK.START.PARA: —I'll bet they know what is going to happen then, too.

—It is not a question of knowing what is going to happen, Senator. It is a matter of looking at various alternatives, intelligently planning our future and then deciding which of those alternative futures we wish to bring into existence and how we are going to do it. That is a very different thing from simply foretelling the future. The honourable senator's interjection is rather interesting because it indicates that people on his side of the Senate misunderstand the prime purpose of the Australian Commission for the Future, which of course should be doing the same thing as the Swedish Commission has been doing-namely, opening up options for public debate so that the people themselves can determine what sort of a future they want. If one is going to do that and is going to look at some factor or some part of the overall economy, one necessarily must look at that part in context. That is what has not been done under the Button car plan.

SPEECH.PARA: I briefly make the observation that when one decides to use a car, one is essentially deciding part of the transport system of the country. One is deciding something about the use of resources in that country, including non-renewable resources, both in the manufacture of the car and in its use. One is deciding something about the health of people who live particularly in urban areas. Several years ago a Senate select committee found that 70 per cent of air pollution over urban areas in Australia was caused by private motor vehicles. One is also, when deciding whether or not to buy a car and whether or not to support a car plan, or what sort of car plan one should support, making some decision about environmental damage, particularly in urban areas and especially large urban centres where we have seen the development of major freeways which run right across developed areas, interfering with people's lives and causing considerable cost to the community both in terms of direct and measurable dollar effects and also in terms of effect on health and the quality of life.

If we were to develop a comprehensive car plan in Australia we would need to look at all those factors together, and we would be looking at where we might be, if certain courses of action are taken, 10, 15 or 20 years down the track.
