We would be determining through a process of public consultation and debate where we want to go and what other alternatives are available to us. What we have in this plan is simply a recognition that part of the Australian economy was in financial difficulty and that we had to do something to correct that in the short run. What do we have? According to Senator Button's paper, we have reduced the number of models in Australia from 13 to eight, and the average volume per model has gone up from 25,000 to 40,000. Multiplying those figures out, I find that production in Australia has in fact fallen from 325,000 units to 320,000 units. So while there may have have been some improvement in overall efficiency, we have not substantially lifted the number of cars being manufactured.

As I indicated earlier, nowhere in this plan is there any emphasis on the other consequences of car purchase and car use. Several years ago an excellent American study looked at the health effects of car use. Translating its conclusion, and this goes back to 1978, to the Australian situation we find that the cost in Australia of car ownership, in health effects alone, was roughly $1,000 a year. The majority of that was related to accidents-deaths and injuries on the road, earnings forgone and the costs of patching up, often rather incompletely, the consequence of motor vehicle accidents. But, in addition to that, there were a substantial number of cancers resulting from the unburnt hydrocarbons and the interaction of those unburnt hydrocarbons with nitrogen oxides and other materials which come out of car exhausts, as well as the general respiratory effects of air pollution.

The Opposition has often extolled the virtues of the market system and has said, as I heard Senator Stone say a moment ago, that we need a more level playing field. By all means let us have a level playing field. Let those who generate the costs bear those costs, and let us put an impost of approximately $1,000 on every vehicle sold in Australia, that money to go towards those costs borne by the community in terms of hospital expenses and the other health costs directly related to the use of private motor vehicles. I just wonder whether we would then consider cars to be our best means of transportation. Remember that we are not in the broader context talking about cars; we are talking about the need of people to have access to transport in order to move themselves and their families from one place to another for essentially human purposes. The car is only one way of achieving that end.

Senator Button has stated that we earned $755m from exports in 1987. What was the cost in Australia of petroleum imports in 1987? I have had people running around in the last couple of hours trying to get the correct figure, but the best figure I can come up with-it is in the same ballpark as the figure mentioned by Senator Parer earlier this afternoon-is that $1.2 billion was spent last year on importing oil into this country. So clearly as a result of our using motor cars we have spent far more on importing oil to run those motor cars than we have made in profits from exports. I suggest that if the car plan had included an element which laid some emphasis on fuel efficiency and we had succeeded in increasing through the plan the efficiency of motor cars in Australia by as much as 20 per cent, we would be saving far more on imports and our balance of trade would benefit to a much greater extent than is now the case under the plan as we have it.

Several years ago when this Labor Government came to power it held a National Economic Summit Conference. I put before that Summit Conference a plan in just those terms. Briefly, its aim was to increase substantially the price of petroleum and to pay that money back to car purchasers who bought fuel efficient cars. It would be paid on a sliding scale, depending on the efficiency of the car. That would have been a rational way of linking the need for increased fuel efficiency with a decreased dependence upon foreign imports, along with decreased air pollution, decreased effects on health and an improvement in the quality of transport in Australia.

I notice that it is reported in the Australian Financial Review that a week ago today the United States Finance Committee recommended that in the US a tax be imposed, on a sliding scale, of between $500 and $3,850 per vehicle, depending upon fuel efficiency and starting with all vehicles with a fuel efficiency of less than 22 1/2 miles per US gallon. If the Americans, who probably have more known reserves of oil than Australia, reckon it is valuable to encourage the American car manufacturers to make cars which are more fuel efficient and so save foreign exchange, and incidentally save a non-renewable resource which we are rapidly running out of, how much more sensible would it be for Australia to follow along the same sorts of lines and substantially increase the price of vehicles, whether imported or Australian manufactured, if they do not meet certain efficiency requirements? As I say, that concept brings together a number of things which this plan does not. The plan is very simple and looks at one thing in isolation. An interest in ecology teaches a person that one of the basic laws is that everything is connected to everything else. One cannot twiddle the price of cars or support for a car industry without there being a rippling effect through other aspects of society, such as health, quality of life, interference with other transport modes, and the like.

During the life of a car, the figures show, it uses approximately 10 times as much energy as goes into its production. Some people might argue that to turn over car stock, to make new cars which are more fuel efficient, may involve an increase in energy use and a decrease in efficiency. The figures quite clearly show that it would be very much in our interests to turn over our car stock and, as rapidly as possible, achieve a much more efficient form of transport.

In conclusion, I simply say that it is good to see that the Government, in the car plan, has looked a few years ahead, but it is bad that it has not looked far enough ahead in terms of the reserves of oil in Australia. We can speculate, as was done during Question time this afternoon, about the prospectivity of Australia. We may discover more oil somewhere near Timor. However, that in itself will be a limited resource. It will run out. Somewhere further down the track we will have to change this means of transport. It would be intelligent to take a much longer term, comprehensive view, to look not just eight or 10 years ahead, as this plan has done, but 10, 15 or 20 years ahead, to see what sort of transport modes would be sensible, supportable, economically desirable, healthy and equitable for the community, and make that view the basis for a plan which would integrate planning for cars and transport with all other aspects of Australian planning.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —In analysing the statement made today by the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button, entitled `Mid-Term Review of the Car Plan', it is necessary to take a very brief look at the context in which the initial 1984 car plan was introduced. On coming to office in 1983 the Labor Government and Senator Button as the Minister for Industry and Commerce, as he then was, were confronted with the crisis in the Australian manufacturing industry. There are a variety of reasons for this which are too far-ranging and comprehensive to look at today. Three require brief mention: we were then in the middle of a domestic recession, with all the implications that that has for consumption and therefore for purchasers of motor vehicles; we had an overvalued Australian dollar which had a significant impact on the capacity of the Australian motor vehicle industry to compete; and we had an appalling industrial relations policy and, as a consequence, an appalling industrial relations record.

SPEECH.PARA: After addressing the Government's promised first priority in that area, which was the steel industry, Senator Button turned his attention to the car plan-more correctly, the passenger motor vehicle plan. The announcement which has been made today is a further stage in the development of that 1984 plan. It is not a change to the plan as such. A mid-term review was always intended and clearly understood. It is an adjustment, as a consequence of that mid-term review, to restore the original effects of the car plan. In his May 1984 statement, amongst other things the Minister said:

This government is firmly committed to the continuance of a viable motor vehicle manufacturing industry in Australia. It is an industry which employs a large number of Australians, which has nurtured managerial and engineering skills, and which contributes significantly to gross domestic product.
He also said:
It is the Government's task to facilitate the process of change, and to ensure that it is accomplished with minimum disruption and cost.
Further in that statement he said:
Government policy since the mid-1960's has been increasingly characterised by short-term crisis containment, lack of direction and inward-looking policies.

In setting out to change that, he outlined the principles that underlined the 1984 strategy. I want to refer to those before analysing the consequences of this mid-term review. On that occasion he said:
There are a number of principles which have guided the Government in considering an appropriate strategy:
1. There must be a process of adjustment over a period of years.
2. The need to concentrate on the strengths of the industry with a view to encouraging exports.
3. The encouragement of rationalisation and cost reduction.
4. The necessity for greater integration of the Australian industry.
He then went on to say:
If the strategy is implemented with firmness and commitment, the local manufacturing industry should be considerably more efficient in the 1990's than it is today.
This section of the statement is significant in terms of today's comments:
That efficiency should be reflected in-
amongst other things-

an ability to compete without quota restrictions on imports . . . an industry which has concentrated its efforts towards its strengths, and is not only more competitive against imports, but is also an active exporter . . .

Those statements of objective, measured against performance and against what is contained in this review, indicate the substantial success of the car plan and the appropriateness of the changes arising from this mid-term review.

In the last four years substantial changes in the direction envisaged by the 1984 plan have developed. For example, statistics indicate that the imports share of the passenger motor vehicle market has fallen from about the 20 per cent level that it was in 1984 under the quota system to approximately 11 per cent now, which is significant in the decisions concerning quotas made in this statement. The consequence for the Australian passenger motor vehicle industry is significant and positive. As Senator Button has said, exports have doubled since 1984. They increased by 63 per cent in 1987 to the very important level of $755m. A matter that cannot be underestimated is the significance of that increase and the contribution to that all important problem confronting the Australian economy, the balance of payments.

Senator Button also referred to the expectation of a continuation of that increase in exports. Of course, that is classically illustrated by the agreement by the Ford Motor Co. of Australia Ltd to export 40,000 Capri model sports cars to the United States. It is interesting to know the reasons underlying it-the indications from the United States industry of a perception of competence in the Australian industry in low volume production of specialised vehicles. That is a portent for the future of great positive benefit and significance to the continuing development of the Australian motor vehicle industry. It is important to the industry that the Capri is a success. I am sure that other senators will have seen the Press reports of the recent motor show in which the Capri was rather unfortunately titled `a smash hit'. It is not exactly the description that one would usually envisage being most appropriate for a motor vehicle, but it was certainly very warmly received. There is now speculation that the 40,000 target may be exceeded and that it may have an increasing role in the very important United States sports car market. Those two questions of import reduction and export increase which are fundamental in analysing all economic and industry decisions in Australia in the 1980s are particularly important.

Senator Button also referred, and I will not repeat his comments, to the important rationalisation that is going ahead-the Holden-Toyota rationalisation, the Nissan-Ford rationalisation and the optimism that by the end of 1989 the number of models released will have reduced from 13 to eight and average volume will have increased from 25,000 to 40,000. The additional matter to which I refer, which I think is of particular importance and which has been a constant theme in all my contributions on economic policy since coming to the Senate is the significance of the investment decisions that have been made. Average investment has increased sharply from $194m per annum in the triennium 1982-84 to $503m per annum in the triennium 1985-87. Investment in this very important industry has more than doubled and nearly tripled.

It is important to note that the smooth process of rationalisation that has taken place in the car industry has occurred in times of what we can politely call severe market stress. The first signs of improvement in the domestic market for motor vehicles are now emerging, and the industry, on the basis of its increased efficiency, on the basis of its increased competitiveness and in particular on the basis of those significant investment decisions, is well placed to take advantage of any improvement in the domestic motor vehicle market and in particular to maintain its increased market share of that increasing market.

I refer briefly also to the objective that Senator Button outlined in 1984 concerning quotas and the ability to compete without quota restrictions. Our success in achieving that objective is clearly evident in the fact that quotas are being abolished because, due to the increased competitiveness of the industry, they have not been used. They are no longer relevant as a protective measure for the Australian motor industry. As I understand it, the tender premiums over the last two years have been zero and there have been no over-quota imports. As I have said previously, the import share has fallen from 20 per cent to 11 per cent, and that is reflected in the abolition of quotas.

It is important that mechanisms be put in place to identify any possible exploitation of the changes that have been made, and those mechanisms are outlined in the Minister's statement and will be incorporated in the activities of the Australian Customs Service. As I have said, these changes are really adjustments to restore the original effect of the plan. They are important in terms of providing continuity and allowing planning based on that continuity because of the long term nature of the investment decisions that we need to continue to make in the Australian motor vehicle industry. It appears on the basis of the analysis that I have been able to make and on the preliminary figures that have been made available that, taking into account all the changes that have affected the competitiveness of the Australian motor vehicle industry, including the changing value of the Australian dollar, particularly compared to the yen, a safety margin has been built into these changes. That is, even after the changes are made, on the best evidence available, the Australian motor vehicle industry should still be more competitive than it was in 1984.

In drawing together the comments I have made so far, I want to emphasise four highlights. These changes alter the mechanisms to achieve the objectives of the plan, but they make no fundamental change to its objectives. They maintain and sustain the necessary review procedures and they contain the mechanisms to identify unfair policies and the exploitation of changes in the quota system which might emerge.

I take this opportunity to make very briefly some general comments about this statement in the context of wider industry policy. A government confronting pressure for change to industry policy, as the Government was with regard to this industry in 1984 and 1988, and as were previous governments, is faced with three broad options within a continuum of policy options. One is to try to preserve the industry in aspic, in line with what might be summarised as the McEwen policy, which has had its advocates. They are rarely heard now and it seems to be essentially discredited, but it is important not to forget that the attempt to implement that policy has been the genesis of the problems with which we are struggling now.

There is the alternative, which I might summarise as the back of the axe policy, of removing all the protection, getting rid of what are perceived by the people in the relevant ivory towers as uncompetitive industries and hoping the resources will be transferred to some more appropriate industry, which is highlighted by what was referred to earlier as the Treasury zero tariff option. I have always had the view that the first economist to come forward to advocate that unemployment should increase as a measure of economic policy should be sacked. That would increase unemployment by one and show him or her exactly what it felt like, and the next economist who wanted to make that representation could come forward if he or she were brave enough.

The third alternative is to adopt a policy of planned change. This is obviously preferable from a social point of view, and that is a matter that could be debated at great length. But I want to refer to its economic advantages. I think option 2, even if the outcome is desirable-and in many instances that is arguable-fails to comprehend the cost of precipitate and unplanned change; from the disruption that leads to loss of production to the increased unemployment, with what we all know, with what all the evidence shows but which seems continually to be ignored: the cost to revenue of unemployment and the cost in expenditure of unemployment. That is, we receive less tax and we have to spend more money. It was one of the underlying features of the blow-out of the deficit in 1982-83 that unemployment was increasing. That led to an enormous blow-out in the deficit because of the cost of welfare payments and the falling tax base.

We have today in the announcement of this review a symbol of mode 3. Change is needed; everybody understands that. Let us look at the effective rate of assistance as the Industries Assistance Commission (IAC) has examined it for Australian manufacturing in general and for this industry in particular. The IAC has assessed the effective rate of assistance to the passenger motor vehicle industry at 250 per cent, to the transport equipment sector generally at 66 per cent, and to the manufacturing industry in general at 19 per cent. Conversely, it can be said that the 19 per cent level of industry protection could be reduced to 13 per cent if the special rates applying to the passenger motor vehicle and textile, clothing and footwear industries were excluded. That would bring us very close to the international norm. As everybody knows, we are competing in a declining tariff regime with far fewer non-tariff barriers than many of our competitors.

The other point I want to make in terms of general industry policy is that Australia needs this industry. The back of the axe strategy also ignores the significant contribution that this industry makes to other industries through its demand for their products and through the development of new techniques that it brings forward, particularly with the enhanced competitiveness of the industry in 1988 as a consequence of the car plan and the competitive pressures. It has been, for example, one of the catalysts to introducing total quality control into Australian manufacturing, to the introduction of a just in time system and to instilling quality as a factor in Australian management. It has been developing significant and enhanced linkages between Australian firms and other, particularly Japanese, firms, and, through that, it has been expediting the transfer of ideas which then flow on to other industries.

In conclusion, in welcoming and supporting the mid-term review of the car plan, I simply say that this review is just another stage in what is comprehensively the most effective process of structural adjustment in Australian economic history. It does not throw away the substantial achievements of 1984 to 1988, but it provides pressure for and incentives to encourage change. This is another symbol of the fact that must be recognised by all involved in Australian economic management-the fact that planned change in industry policy can work and must be made to work.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the outset, I commend, as have my coalition colleagues, the announcement by the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button, relating to the motor vehicle manufacturing plan. In particular, I commend the decision which has been taken to abolish as from today tariff quotas on imported vehicles and to reduce as from today the tariff rate on passenger motor vehicles from the present 57 1/2 per cent to 45 per cent, with a further staged reduction to 35 per cent by 1992. Similarly, as from today the tariff on light commercial vehicles will be reduced from 35 per cent to 25 per cent, with further staged reductions to 15 per cent by 1992.

SPEECH.PARA: Those decisions are certainly very welcome. However, it should also be recognised that this is not really a giant step forward. All these decisions do is correct the course of the operation of the plan which had been substantially altered by the massive depreciation in the value of the Australian dollar since the plan was first implemented in 1984. Of course, in that context not only does it reflect the failure of the Button plan to be sufficiently flexible over that period to take account of changes in the international economic environment and Australia's place in it, but also it reflects the dismal failure of the present Labor Government's overall economic management.

The other comment that is relevant to this announcement is that the decision is really much too late. It is some time now since this economy and the car industry in particular experienced the very detrimental effects of the massive depreciation in the value of the Australian dollar. On my return to this Parliament after the last election in my first participation in the Senate Estimates committees last October I asked the Minister about the effects of the depreciation on the operation of the motor vehicle plan. At that time I suggested that changes should be made and further immediate reductions in protection should be undertaken to restore to the plan the balance which had been destroyed by that depreciation. It is now some six months later that the Government is taking this initiative. As I said, it is really much too late.

It is also not a giant step because it leaves the motor vehicle manufacturing industry with more than three times the level of protection of the rest of manufacturing, excluding the other heavily protected sector, textile, clothing and footwear. Even by 1992, the level of protection of the motor vehicle industry will still be more than double that for the rest of manufacturing industry, again excluding the other heavily protected sector, the textiles, clothing and footwear industry. So while there is a reduction from the present situation where the effective rate of protection is something in excess of four times the rate of protection applied to other sectors of manufacturing industry, it is still a somewhat marginal reduction. Obviously the long term goal of any effective industry plan must be to have the industry capable of surviving and competing at a level of protection which matches that of manufacturing industry as a whole.

These failures in the plan highlight the total inadequacy of central planning in a competitive international economic environment. The failure of the plan thus far must be sheeted home as a direct responsibility of this Labor Government. The depreciation of the dollar is the direct responsibility of this Government. Its failure adequately to manage the Australian economy and its failure to restrain wage increases and therefore cost increases on our domestic economy have been a major factor contributing to that depreciation of our dollar. The Government introduced a fringe benefits tax which had the effect of increasing the real cost of motor vehicles, particularly to the business sector. We saw the introduction of a sales tax at the level of 30 per cent on some segments of the motor vehicle industry, which further increased the costs of motor vehicle products.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you going to abolish the fringe benefits tax?

—As Senator Maguire would be aware, it is the policy of the Opposition to abolish Labor's devastating fringe benefits tax. He ought to be aware of that. It is this Government which is responsible for the economic recession which this country has experienced over the last year or so in particular and the consequent fall in living standards which all Australians have experienced, which has made it much more difficult for them to afford new motor vehicles. As a consequence of that, demand for motor vehicles has fallen while, because of the cost impost which this Government has inflicted on the industry, prices have soared.

SPEECH.PARA: Indeed, between 1985 and 1987 the average price of locally manufactured motor vehicles increased by some 49.8 per cent while that of imported vehicles increased by 69.5 per cent. Of course, this is way above the rate of inflation in this country, which was something less than 10 per cent per annum over that period, although it should be noted that the rate of inflation is itself double that of our trading partners. So it is no wonder that the average Australian cannot afford to buy new motor vehicles. These factors have combined to have a devastating effect on car sales, which at the moment are experiencing a 20-year low.

In 1985 some 510,000 motor vehicles were sold in Australia but by 1986 the figure had plummeted to 400,000 and it is estimated to have fallen further to about 340,000 in 1987. As a result of this dramatic fall in the sales of motor vehicles some 600 dealers have disappeared from the industry over the five years of this Labor Government; and how many more thousands of employees of those 600 dealers have lost their jobs and been placed on the employment market and left to survive on unemployment benefits? It has also been estimated that in the next few years, if there is no change, some 3,000 dealers could go out of business and that obviously will have a devastating effect on employment in the industry. So while the high costs caused by the protection of this industry may have protected a few jobs on the manufacturing side they have quite clearly destroyed many more jobs in the marketing and servicing side of the industry.

As a consequence of declining sales, the changeover time for the average buyer has increased from 3.5 years to five years while for fleet buyers it has gone up from 2.5 years to 3.5 years-yet another indication of the way in which the effects of the policies of this Government have made it much more difficult for people to purchase motor vehicles. The initiatives which the Minister has announced today, particularly in regard to the reduction in tariffs and the abolition of quotas, certainly will allow prices to stabilise between now and 1990, but people ought not to expect too much from this announcement and expect prices to fall because importers are still recovering from the currency losses which they have experienced over the past couple of years as a result of the combined effects of the operation of this plan and the massive depreciation of the Australian dollar. Certainly, to get the motor vehicle industry back into a thriving, prosperous situation this Government needs to take further initiatives which would include the abolition of the fringe benefits tax so that the business demand for vehicles will increase. Of course, we also need economic management which will ensure a stable economy and the absence of further fluctuations in the value of our Australian dollar.

Despite the very welcome aspects of this announcement, I believe there is one significant shortcoming in the Minister's statement and that is that it announced only a minor modification of the local content requirements under the plan. That minor change is that the penalty duties previously applied to non-compliance with the 85 per cent local content requirement for Australian manufacturers are to be replaced by a penalty which will be somewhat less severe in being aligned with the completely built up unit tariffs. That is, from January, a tariff of 42.5 per cent will apply on any shortfall below the 85 per cent content plan and by 1992 a tariff of 35 per cent will apply. I am disappointed that the local content requirement itself has not been reduced below the current 85 per cent level to 80 per cent or perhaps even 75 per cent. There is no doubt that the high level of local content specified in the plan has led to the continuation of the production of an extensive range of components in Australia, some at very high cost relative to equivalent imports. So, by continuing a high local content requirement, the Government is continuing to make an important contributing factor to the lack of international competitiveness of the Australian industry.

The Government boasts about the opportunities for exports which its plan has allegedly created, both of components and completely built up vehicles, as Senator McMullan mentioned a few moments ago when he referred to the Capri. But it is the export facilitation provisions relating to the local content requirement which, in effect, provide a subsidy to support such export activity. The magnitude of the subsidy available to exports is equivalent to the cost disadvantage of the domestic content which is resourced from imports. Of course, in Australia this disadvantage, and hence the available export subsidy, is high. Evidence suggests that the majority of Australian automotive exports would not be viable in the absence of this subsidy. That makes sense. If components and, indeed, completely built up motor vehicles cannot compete on the Australian market without heavy levels of protection, how can they compete on foreign markets, open to free competition, without subsidies? It is very clear that those export markets are being developed largely as a result of the subsidy-a subsidy which is being paid by Australian consumers, because it is the extra cost of motor vehicles which Australian consumers have to pay as a result of the protection regime in place that, through the export facilitation scheme, provides the subsidy to overseas consumers to buy Australian products. What sort of nonsense is that, that Australian consumers ought to be providing a subsidy for overseas consumers to buy our products at a price cheaper than we can buy them ourselves?

When the Industries Assistance Commission (IAC) looked at the effect of local content schemes and export facilitation, it reached the conclusion that the local content scheme is unlikely to contribute to the development of an efficient vehicle industry in Australia. The complexity of the scheme means that it is extremely difficult to ascertain its effect on the component producing sector. It is fair to say, as far as the Australian components industry is concerned, that we have still got a long way to go not only in terms of the cost competitiveness of those components but also in terms of their quality.

Some component manufacturers in Australia have, under the plan, taken the initiative of developing the capitalisation, technology-base and management skills needed to supply high quality components and to keep up with frequent model changes. But it is also fair to say that many others have not taken that initiative. Indeed, criticism has been levelled by car manufacturers about the quality of some local components, the lack of constant supply, the failure of some component suppliers to adapt their technology to the latest flexible car manufacturing processes, and industrial relations problems within the car component manufacturing industry. All of those factors continue to contribute to the lack of competitiveness of this sector of the industry.

The effective monopoly provided for many local component producers by the 85 per cent local content rule has contributed to many of the problems of the industry in recent years. That is why it would have been a very welcome additional decision if the Government had eased those local content requirements.

One of the problems that the motor vehicle manufacturing industry in Australia faces is the significant degree of oligopoly with regard to the supply of components. BTR Nylex is virtually the sole manufacturer in Australia for about 30 per cent of the components of a new car, including gearboxes, transmissions, universal joints, rear axles and drive and tail shafts. Through its half share in Pilkington ACI Ltd, BTR Nylex also has a slice of the monopoly manufacture of car glass in Australia. A reduction in the local content minimum would allow car makers to source more of their componentry offshore and give BTR Nylex a bit more competition.

As I said, the IAC concluded that the `local content scheme is unlikely to contribute to the development of an efficient vehicle industry'. This raises the question of whether an internationally competitive passenger vehicle industry can be encouraged if domestic component production continues to be assisted through such a local content scheme. If a decision is taken that it cannot, the question that needs to be considered is how and over what time frame a local content scheme should be dismantled. This statement today has given the Government a marvellous opportunity to take at least some initial steps in reducing that local content requirement and begin to abandon the local content scheme in the same way as it has indicated it is abandoning the high levels of tariffs and quotas as a means of protecting the domestic industry from international competition.

There are also questions to be raised about the efficacy of recent intervention designed to facilitate achievement of the structure specified by the Government through the plan as being appropriate for the vehicle industry. Industry structure, including the scale of operation of individual firms, is not an independent causal factor influencing an industry's competitive position, but rather the outcome of the demand and cost conditions facing producers. The existing structure of the motor vehicle manufacturing industry, involving low volume production of a relatively large number of models, can be seen as an appropriate response to consumer demand for a differentiated range of vehicles, given the stringent restrictions imposed on imports since the mid-1960s. So penalty provisions which this Government has provided to discourage low volume production have the error of focusing attention on one outcome of the industry's lack of competitiveness rather than the fundamental cause, which is the high and made-to-measure assistance which has been given to this industry in the past, which has continued until today and which in some respects will continue beyond today, particularly with regard to high local content and, indeed, a continuing level of tariffs which, as I said earlier, is several times that of the manufacturing industry in general.

Whether the structure specified is appropriate can be questioned. Indeed, the remaining years of this assistance package should raise that question in particular. Whether in fact the scale of producers' operations ought to be the focus for assistance arrangements after 1992 should be examined very closely. There is an alternative arrangement, and that would be to concentrate on the overall level of assistance to be provided to the industry and leave the restructuring response to the industry itself. Certainly this statement goes part of the way down that track, by getting rid of quotas and leaving the major element of protection in the form of tariffs. But these other penalties will still apply if the restructuring which the Government regards as appropriate to be introduced is not introduced by the various segments of the industry.

There are other initiatives which this Government needs to take if we are to see a successful, profitable and prosperous Australian motor industry. The first of these is the need to improve Australian manufacturers' share of the worldwide export market on a genuine competitive basis, not on the basis of the subsidies which the export facilitation scheme offers and to which I referred earlier. There is also the need to rationalise componentry so that components can be shared between the various vehicle manufacturers. There also needs to be further development of the just in time system of manufacturing aimed at maximising plant--

TALK.START.PARA: —We've got it.

—As Senator Watson says, we have got it, but it needs further encouragement and further development. It certainly is not yet being exploited to its fullest; indeed, it is often hindered by industrial unrest and disputation on the part of less than cooperative industry unions. So we need to give more encouragement to that just in time scheme to improve plant efficiency, inventory management and decreasing on-site stockpiling.

SPEECH.PARA: The other initiative which needs to be developed further is that of total quality control designed to improve overall quality rates at all stages of product manufacture. An additional benefit which this industry could well use to improve its efficiency and profitability would be the adoption of flexible manufacturing processes. The relative lack of investment by some sectors of the component supply industry in flexible manufacturing technology is to be deplored. If Australia is to have a really efficient and prosperous industry, that aspect of manufacturing must be introduced in greater degree to compensate for our small domestic market and thereby reduce the cost inefficiencies of the industry in Australia. It is also important that the Government, apart from taking initiatives such as those which have been announced today, should have a long, hard look at their imposts and how they detrimentally affect the industry. I have already referred to the fringe benefits tax and the excessive levels of sales tax which are applied to this industry. Certainly, it is issues such as these to which the Government must give attention if we are to have a further beneficial effect on the cost structure of motor vehicles and a further beneficial effect, therefore, on the number of vehicles sold in Australia through a cheaper price being available to the consumer.

In conclusion, we really must ask the fundamental question whether a continuation of a high level of assistance, which will continue notwithstanding the announcement made by the Minister today, is really consistent with this Government's economy-wide objective of encouraging the development of a more internationally competitive industry structure. While this statement is to be welcomed to the degree to which it does significantly reduce the levels of excessive protection which apply to this industry, there are a number of other initiatives which the Government and the industry must take if we are indeed to have that internationally competitive industry which will not only provide cheap, high quality cars to the Australian consumer, but also will allow the industry to compete on the international markets without the need for any subsidies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier this afternoon the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) made a very significant statement in the context of a mid-term review of the car industry plan. I enter this debate as a person who has had a background in manufacturing. I find that all too often critics of manufacturing in Australia speak in terms of platitudes or with tunnel vision in that they do not direct their attention to some of the underlying conditions in the environment that manufacturers have to cope with in Australia. For that reason a lot of that criticism is quite invalid.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to record my satisfaction that the Minister has made no significant changes to what I refer to as the 85 per cent local content rule. It is true that there have been some changes at the fringes. I believe that this rule is a major plank in supporting what I term the bedrock of the industry, most particularly the parts and bearings manufacturers who rely on Australian motor manufacturers for their existence. It must be understood by us that changes to the car plan affect not only the big companies such as General Motors, Ford Australia, Toyota and so on. They also affect many more companies which are involved in component manufacture and part supply in Australia. I know from personal experience in northern Tasmania that this is an area where component factories provide much needed regional employment. I speak particularly of ACL Bearing Co., part of the former Repco complex, which has an impressive export record. It is a record that could well be followed by many others in this field. The car industry therefore provides a wide input into many areas of light and heavy manufacturing throughout Australia.

The Minister said early in his statement that one of the long term objectives of the plan is that it must provide consumers with quality products at reduced prices in real terms. Unfortunately this objective is a long way from being realised, largely because of both the economic and taxation policies pursued by this Federal Government. Since coming to power in 1983, the Labor Government has made decisions which have severely hit the automotive industry. I say this mindful of Senator Button's very genuine commitment to rejuvenating this sector of the Australian economy, but the Senate must realise that other Ministers have, to some extent, been pulling in other directions so far as the health of the motor vehicle industry is concerned. For example, the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) have introduced increases to sales tax and the horrendous fringe benefits tax, both of which have been body blows to the health of the car industry. In fact, last year we saw new vehicle sales slump by 15 per cent. Admittedly the Australian and global economies share some of the blame but, as other speakers have said, we must look to the fringe benefits tax because company fleet passenger vehicle sales, a vital market for car makers, have slumped over 45 per cent since the end of 1985. The fringe benefits tax has been roundly criticised not only by the coalition but also by many industry groups, particularly in the automotive field.

I think it is a pity that while the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button, has been trying so hard to assist the consolidation and efficiency of the industry, at the same time some of his colleagues, such as Mr Keating and Senator Walsh, have developed a taxation policy which really has humbled the sector. I note that Senator Button has said that tariffs on light commercial vehicles and four-wheel drive vehicles are to be reduced immediately from 35 per cent and 25 per cent respectively to 20 per cent and this will be phased down to 15 per cent by 1992. I think that this will assist primary producers who need small trucks and other similar off-road vehicles as essential tools for their work. I believe that this announcement should also be greeted by business generally as a step towards containing many of the operating overheads.

I am also pleased that Senator Button has spoken to the New Zealand industry Minister, the Hon. David Caygill. The Opposition looks forward very much to the Minister's report to the Senate on the trans-Tasman rationalisation of the motor vehicle industry in both Australia and New Zealand. This is particularly important in regard to the closer economic relations (CER) agreement originated by the Fraser Government and continued under Mr Hawke and the CER impact on the car industry plan.

I note that throughout the ministerial statement Senator Button has instructed the Australian Automotive Industry Authority to undertake certain reviews and monitoring of the car industry plan. I hope that the Government's confidence in the Authority is well placed and that the Authority is well equipped to carry out this vital role. I believe that this could perhaps be better done had this been within the Minister's own Department because so often authorities can be used as pigeonholes for difficult decisions. I hope this is not going to be the case with this particular authority.

Despite the objective of the initial plan at its outset to bring about a reduction in the price of the family car, unfortunately quite the reverse has been the case. The depreciation of our dollar, particularly against the Japanese yen, has substantially increased the price of both imported and domestically produced and assembled cars. This factor, in conjunction with increases in sales tax and the introduction of the fringe benefits tax, has spelt disaster for many automotive dealers. In my own State of Tasmania, new vehicle registrations last year sank to their lowest level since 1962. As a result many dealers have been forced out of business-not only in Tasmania but across the nation. The hardest hit have been those in rural areas where turnover is naturally much lower.

It is encouraging to see that the Government is now prepared to take some action on this issue and to take steps that may result in more affordable cars for the consumer, but that remains to be seen. As the Button car plan was in place prior to the currency realignment, it is possible there is some room for change in the tariff structure. I think that would be welcomed by consumers. In effect, as the dollar has gone down in value the effective protection has increased in relative terms and some adjustment to tariff levels can be afforded by the industry as a result. Unfortunately, some of these changes will come too late for many to benefit from them.

It appears that the Government may have been using the motor vehicle industry as a pawn in a very much larger game plan. I refer the Senate to an article entitled `Wheels come loose' that appeared in the 27 July 1987 edition of Time magazine. In that article the President of the Australian Automobile Dealers Association, Mr Graham Woodward, relates how he approached the Treasurer, Mr Keating, during a lull in a cocktail party in Hobart. He asked Mr Keating whether he had deliberately used the motor industry to help with the Government's objectives; that is, to reduce consumption expenditure. Mr Keating was reported to have responded with the following words, `That's right, it's the biggest one and it's the easiest target'. If this statement is reported accurately-I would like the Treasurer to deny it-I hope that the Government will pay more attention to the advice of Senator Button, who almost certainly has a greater concern for the plight of the industry and those employed within it than do some of his colleagues on the ministerial front bench, including the Treasurer. I believe that the ministerial statement delivered by Senator Button is a halfway mile post in the plan. The Opposition, like the industry, awaits the result of the car plan in 1992. It is proper to make warning comments on an occasion such as this, and I hope that the Minister takes some notice of what has been said.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Aulich Sen T.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the statement made by the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button. I believe the Minister ought to be congratulated at the outset on the tenacious and intelligent way in which he has attempted to reform the Australian car industry through the car plan announced in May 1984. It has not been an easy task to bring an insular, pampered and basically uncompetitive industry into the latter part of the twentieth century. As we in this chamber all know, for years that industry has hidden behind high tariff barriers and the use of quotas on imported competition. The result has been a gradual decline in our competitiveness, the takeover of our domestic sales by Japanese imports in particular, and a lack of long term security for those who work in what is in fact one of Australia's most important manufacturing industries. For those trendy people who have consistently underestimated the future and importance of manufacturing in this country, the car industry's survival and growth under this Government should be an eye opener.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said, the importance of the car industry must not be underestimated. According to figures produced by the Australian Bureau of Statistics, in June 1987, 68,000 people were employed in this industry; that is, about 7.5 per cent of all those employed in Australian manufacturing. In many cases they are widely dispersed throughout this country in key strategic areas. The service sector and the finance sector of the economy may be the glamour growth areas, but the long term survival of those 68,000 jobs in the car industry must still be the priority of this and of any government.

Of course, a consumption and fashion based industry such as the car industry cannot afford just to tread water. It must be efficient, technologically sophisticated and export oriented. The penalty for standing still is not only to lose one's status in the world but also to be passed by, as the United States of America found out in the 1960s when the first invasion into that country of the Japanese manufacturers began. That is what happened here in Australia in the late 1960s when the Japanese moved in here and when imports ultimately accounted for something like 20 per cent of domestic sales.

TALK.START.PARA: —How much?

—Twenty per cent of domestic sales in this country. The response from governments and the industry itself to that invasion or competition has been interesting. I guess it is an example of Australia's then reluctance to accept that we were very much a part of a world economy and that somehow or other sloppy standards would not be tolerated by our own local consumers, let alone by overseas markets. We are starting to find out that that is not the case. The response during the 1960s and early 1970s was to try to keep out competition by lifting tariffs on imported cars and imposing restrictions or quotas on the number of foreign cars allowed into this country. That was a very clumsy mechanism for control and certainly one which in the long term did not benefit this industry as it became, as I indicated before, extremely sloppy and, in many cases, uncompetitive.

SPEECH.PARA: Since that time a number of government car plans have been imposed. The statistics over the last decade or so show that on average one car plan or major modification per year has been implemented since the 1960s. None-I repeat, none-succeeded in arresting the decline of the industry until this Government imposed its plan in 1984-a plan intended to last until 1992 and to be reviewed mid-term with appropriate adjustments being made. The Minister made his statement today to indicate that that review has been going on and that adjustments are now being made.

What is outstanding about this Labor Government's plant is its success and its consistency. The two are related to each other. Everyone in the industry knows what the ground rules are, and accordingly the industry has lifted its game. Let us look at the figures. Since the Button plan was implemented four years ago the level of foreign imports as a percentage of sales in Australia has dropped from 20 per cent to 11 per cent. Australian car manufacturers and component makers have now penetrated overseas markets in a way that would have been considered impossible 10 years ago. For example, we export Holden engines to Japan, alloy wheels, braking systems, and springs to Mercedes in Germany, and suspension systems, to name just a few. The list is impressive, but what is more impressive is that those Australian components are now being built to a quality standard that is acceptable to the very high standards of the Mercedes and Japanese car companies, for example. That is a commentary in itself not only on the success of the car plan and the views of the Government in 1984 when the plan was brought in but also on the way in which the industry itself has responded to the challenge.

There cannot be success for an industry like this unless the challenge is laid down, and that challenge will never be laid down or seen by manufacturers if they are hiding behind high tariff walls and quotas imposed on foreign cars coming into this country. The basic cause for these components being sold successfully overseas is the offset system that has been imposed under the Button plan, where credit is basically given to those manufacturers who are able and willing to export and are therefore given credit internally for buying in other components from elsewhere. There are many other areas I could nominate as being a cause for the change that has occurred, but I think it is sufficient to say at this stage, given the shortness of time available in this debate, that the total plan has worked.

There have been teething problems. Certain importers have been very critical indeed of the Government. However, I wish to make a very brief comment on the attitude of some of the importers of foreign cars. I well recall the rather arbitrary decision in 1974 under the Whitlam Government to cut tariffs by 25 per cent on imported vehicles. Like a few of its decisions on tariffs, that decision was generally not thought through as well as it could have been and had consequences in a number of industries. The interesting thing about those tariff cuts was the fact that, despite a revaluation upwards of about 25 per cent of the Australian dollar, the importers, with one exception, did not pass on to the Australian consumers one dollar per unit for cars sold in this country. At the time the motoring magazines looked very closely at the adjustment in prices that occurred as a result of the Whitlam Government cutting tariffs by 25 per cent and the associated revaluation of the Australian dollar. The Australian domestic consumer should have benefited enormously from those moves. Yet, at the time Fiat was the only importer who was able to pass on any of those benefits to the consumer. I believe that in the case of the smallest Fiat car, something like $100 by way of discount was passed on to consumers. Every other importer simply pocketed the difference and said thank you very much to the rather naive Whitlam Government at the time, and continued on its merry way.

Since then, of course, knowing their market better, importers have continued to mark up a significant number of vehicles in their range and at times have attacked those few importers in this country who have decided to keep prices down to a reasonable level. About two years ago one European importer was criticised and had anti-dumping challenges levelled against it-not officially, because the other importers were not game to proceed to a formal investigation. That importer was maligned in the motoring Press and in the general Press simply because it decided to keep its prices down while other comparable car importers, or people who were selling a similar product, were raising prices by as much as $6,000 to $7,000. That shows that there appeared to be a cartel of importers operating at that time using the import quota restrictions as a method of lifting the mark-up on the particular vehicles that they were selling.

This is not a simple matter and one cannot simply change an industry by dropping tariff barriers or dropping the restrictions or quotas on imported cars. That is not good enough because, as I said, some importers will simply pocket the difference. Rather, one must look at the total plan in which one is involved, look at the market niches around the world, encourage the manufacturers both of cars and of components to head for those market niches, and support them in every way one can. In particular they should be given credit to import other components that may not be able to be made here but which can be imported duty-free as a trade-off for their export activities overseas.

The transition in the car plan has not been easy. As we all know, the manufacturers and retailers initially baulked at the challenge. In the past that reluctance on the part of the industry to move usually resulted in governments backing down under pressure from manufacturers and, I must say, from unions. In those days a batch of sackings was all that was required. Many honourable senators will remember the strategic sackings that took place in the Australian car industry during the 1970s as successive governments attempted to get the industry to move towards a more export oriented basis of operation.

Politically it has been necessary to hold a steady line against those pressures. As everyone knows, a Labor government is generally fairly vulnerable to pressure from the trade union movement. There is no doubt, as I have said, that in the past manufacturers unwilling to move in line with government plans to change the car industry were very willing to simply sack workers and say to the unions, `Well, it is your Labor Government; you go to Canberra and convince your confreres there that they have to keep the car industry as it is'. It was not good enough simply to keep the car industry as it was. As I said, any industry that stands still at a time of rapid evolution will be passed by.

It must be said of this plan and of the man behind the plan, Senator John Button, that he has displayed a consistency and firmness that everyone in the industry is now beginning to appreciate. The Government did not walk away from the absolute need to hold the line on this plan. What was needed was, of course, simply consistency and firmness. Industry workers and consumers now have that. This Government has its faults, but on the whole it set out to make industry in this country more competitive. The car industry plan is part of that approach. I am very happy to say that I welcome the Minister's statement and look forward to the next four years and the return of a Labor government which will be able to oversee the new plan in 1992.
Debate (on motion by Senator Chaney) adjourned.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Chaney proposing that a matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The failure of the Hawke and Bannon governments to come to grips with the obstruction of the submarine construction project by elements of the trade union movement in South Australia and the disastrous implications for both defence and industry development.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —This debate, following on the debate about amendments to the Government's car plan, touches on a different form of industrial project, one of which is of major significance for Australia. I refer to the major project announced by the Government only last year to build submarines in Australia for the Royal Australian Navy. In the announcement on 18 May 1987 the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) made clear that this was a matter of very great importance to Australia. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government's decision is a major step towards implementing recommendations in the Defence Policy Information Paper and, together with projects for frigates, minehunters and other vessels, constitutes the greatest peacetime warship building program in Australia's history, at a projected cost of eight billion dollars.
The Submarine project is also a great step forward for Australian industry in developing new and upgraded capabilities for both domestic and export markets.

More than 600 jobs will be created at the assembly site in Port Adelaide and thousands of other jobs elsewhere. There will be a massive transfer of new technology to Australian industry, including an upgrading of production skills and quality assurance flowing from the project.

That is a very clear statement from the Government that the project is one of immense significance for our defence and for our industry. The cost of the project in 1986 dollars was put as just under $4 billion. We find that after great competition from New South Wales and Western Australia the project was awarded to South Australia, one of the principal reasons being that State's reputation as having a significantly better industrial relations history, atmosphere, record, or call it what you will.

However, in 1988, less than a year after the announcement of the award of the project to South Australia, there has been a serious dispute for the past four weeks or so, preceded by several months of industrial unrest. The Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Willis), rather late in the day, is spending the day in Adelaide to try to repair the damage. The latest statement on the state of the project, published this morning, was that so far the ban had delayed work only slightly and that the Australian Submarine Corporation had maintained its commitment to South Australia at this stage. Those representatives in the Parliament who have long been urging that the award of the contract to South Australia was utterly appropriate and would ensure that the project was dealt with efficiently must be concerned that there is even a possible suggestion that the project could be lost to South Australia because of the difficulties presently being encountered.

Heavy engineering throughout Australia has been in great difficulties. The Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) has had to bring forward a heavy engineering plan. He would know that a number of shipyards in Australia have closed, and that one of the substantial reasons for those closures has been the incapacity of those shipyards to meet foreign competition. One of the elements of that failure has been the restrictive work practices which have been a feature of those shipyards. Senator Button would know that the award of this project was based on the expectation that better practices would apply on the submarine project. It is the threat to those better practices which has caused the concern, which is certainly felt by the Opposition and, I think, by the community, and which puts this important industry project at risk.

It is important to note that the Opposition has supported the Government's proposal that the submarines should be built in Australia. We have supported it in the interests of Australian industry and of Australia's defence. But there are risks in the project, and it appears to the Opposition that those risks are now becoming very evident and rather higher than they should be. Basically that is because there are difficulties within the trade union movement. There have not been difficulties between the Submarine Corporation, that is, the employer, the contractor, and the trade union movement generally or between them and their work force, or because they are trying to achieve conditions for the work force that are unsatisfactory. It is the fact that there are disputes within the trade union movement itself, between the ACTU and the United Trades and Labour Council of South Australia, that this project is being thrown under a cloud.

Clearly, if the Government and the Submarine Corporation are to succeed in this very important project there need to be new attitudes brought to bear by the trade union movement generally and not just elements of it. There need to be new approaches to industrial relations. It is quite clear that that is being sought by the Submarine Corporation, but that at the moment that is being subverted. I remind the Senate that the good industrial relations record of South Australia was an important selling point in achieving the contract for South Australia. When the contract was awarded, Mr Bannon took out advertisements showing a very fine photograph of him and containing these words:

We've won the submarine contract. Once again, South Australia has shown what can be done by working together. Many South Australians, including business, unions and the Submarine Task Force deserve credit for their work in helping to win the contract. Thank you. Now it's time to prove to Australia that we can do the job-and do it well.

Mr Bannon and Mr Beazley, the Federal Defence Minister, were saying that the industrial relations argument was a key factor in favour of South Australia. The Opposition saw that as an appropriate factor in South Australia's favour. It is tragic that a few months down the track it appears that the South Australian trade union movement is unable to come to grips with the arrangements which have been put in place not as a unilateral, employer-imposed matter but as a matter of agreement between the employer and the ACTU-an agreement which is now causing so much disruption from the United Trades and Labour Council.

One might well ask whether there is any reason why the Commonwealth or indeed the State Government should be criticised because, after all, this is a dispute between elements of the trade union movement and the employer. I say in response to that rhetorical question, since it may well be raised in debate, that both State and Federal Governments were prepared to accept the credit for a good industrial relations record. They bear some responsibility in this project, which involves just under $4 billion in 1986 dollars but obviously ultimately much more than that, and they cannot on the one hand take the credit for the good industrial relations system and then duck for cover as soon as the difficulties emerge. The fact is that this project has proceeded with Commonwealth Government support on the basis that there is a need for a new deal, a new approach. Clearly, the Submarine Corporation is following the spirit of the Government's own approach in dealing with trade unions at Federal level and in seeking to delimit the demarcation disputes and other problems which traditionally have arisen in Australian shipyards.

What is being sought by the Submarine Corporation is in no sense unusual. We have a situation where there has been negotiation between three major unions at the national level. They have entered into discussions with the Submarine Corporation, the Amalgamated Metal Workers Union, the Electrical Trades Union and the Federated Ironworkers Association. They, with the backing of the ACTU, have agreed to try to reach a national agreement. That agreement is expected to cover things which are not repressive of the work force, but which are in the interests of the work force as well as of the employer. It is expected to cover wages, hours, general conditions, training, skills enhancement, personnel career growth, occupational health and safety and quality control. The assessment of the Minister for Defence as to the intention of the Submarine Corporation to enter into this sort of agreement was that it would:

make an important contribution to the success of the submarine project. The proposed union agreement with the ASC could provide a model for industrial relations in future defence projects including the ANZAC Ship project.

That was said by Mr Beazley just before Christmas, and that is the basis on which we are now so deeply concerned that the project is running into such difficulty. Clearly, on the assessment of both the Opposition and the Government, the Submarine Corporation is trying to do the right thing, and yet is being blocked by the United Trades and Labour Council of South Australia.

What is being sought to be done here in Australia is no different from what is being sought to be done in other countries with which we are in competition. We are in competition in a direct sense because the alternative to building these submarines in Australia, or ships in other contracts in Australia, is of course to buy them overseas. People in other countries, including Great Britain, who are entering into this sort of transaction are insisting on single union, no strike deals before they invest in new projects. It is consistent with the present Government's own drive for an internationally competitive secondary industry that we should be following down the same track in Australia. Yet we have this negative trade union reaction, we have had months of disruption, and we have had from both Federal and State governments essentially a hands-off approach to this and a refusal to get involved until today's visit by the Federal Minister.

The position today is exactly as I have described it. The ACTU is supporting the agreement between the Australian Submarine Corporation and the Federal branches of the three unions that I have named. There will be pressure at State level on the Federal Minister to use his position to force the Submarine Corporation to throw out or modify the agreement so that work on the submarine site can proceed without the benefits of the agreement. The Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce shakes his head. I am glad if that indicates that the Government is not going to be prepared to go along with that line, and I welcome that on behalf of the Opposition. But the reality is that this contract will not be satisfactorily carried out if we revert to past practices.

The matter of public importance raises implications for both defence and industry development. The significance for Australia in what is happening is that if the Government fails in its attempts to get this submarine project operating satisfactorily, out of economic necessity Australia will be forced back to off the shelf buying from other countries. What is happening in South Australia must deter others who might otherwise invest in the sorts of projects that we are discussing today. There is no basis for certainty or for efficient operation if the sorts of disruption, bans and limitations which are being imposed in South Australia are allowed to continue. The Opposition believes that for projects of this sort to proceed we need agreements which remove the risk of demarcation disputes. We need agreements which are positive for the work force and management, and that appears to be what is being sought in the instant case with both the employers and the ACTU involvement. We believe that these agreements need to contain dispute settling procedures to avoid costly losses of time due to strikes or limitations of work. Indeed, we believe that so far as possible there should be no-strike agreements in these matters.

In bringing this matter forward, again it might be asked whether this is entirely a matter to be left to the Submarine Corporation and the unions involved. In the view of the Opposition, that is not the case. The Opposition's view is that so far the Government has signally failed to live up to it responsibilities in this matter. Its responsibility is as the custodian of the $4 billion plus of taxpayers' money that will have to be put into this project, which may well become $8 billion plus if precedents are followed. What needs to be done by government? For a start, a clear lead needs to be given by government as to what is required. That lead was apparent while things were going smoothly. In December, Mr Beazley and Mr Bannon were able to state quite frankly what they thought was required for the success of the project because there appeared to be agreement between the parties. They have been very low in their profiles on this matter ever since the difficulties started two to three months ago.

The first obligation that is on the Government is to establish some sort of lead in this matter and to make clear what is expected. The second thing required of the Government is that it should make it clear to the parties that the Government is not prepared to see this project sabotaged. The reality is that the Government has set the Submarine Corporation a goal to build a number of submarines for a certain price in 1986 dollars. If it becomes apparent that it is impossible to meet that objective within the present parameters, the Government has to be prepared to change those parameters.

It has been the view of the Opposition that the placing of this contract in South Australia be supported. We remain of that view. But it is also true that in Western Australia and New South Wales it is now being argued that the contract could be more satisfactorily dealt with out of South Australia. I believe that the Commonwealth could help to clear up this matter by making it quite clear to the parties concerned that they have a national obligation and that national obligation is primarily to see the defence requirements of Australia met and the submarines built. They should seek to have those submarines built in Australia if that is possible, and if that cannot be done in South Australia it should be done elsewhere. If it cannot be done elsewhere in Australia, it should be done in Sweden. In other words, there is no unlimited source of funds for this project.

I believe that unless there is toughness on the part of the head contractor-that is, the Commonwealth itself-there will not be a successful resolution. The Minister at the table, Senator Button, smiles. He always likes to accuse the Opposition of being macho in these matters, but I remind him of the attitude of the Labor Government in New South Wales with respect to the New South Wales State Dockyard. After years and years of losses it finally took the necessary view that the dockyard would have to be closed because it could not operate in an economic way. The same standards are required to be imposed on this project from day one, and I believe there is room for a much more forceful stance on the part of the Commonwealth.

The third activity the Commonwealth should undertake is an examination of the Opposition's policy on essential services. Again this should not be dealt with in a partisan way on the basis that every time a matter like this is raised it involves union bashing. I remind the Senate that Mr Unsworth found it necessary to use essential services legislation in the dying days of his Government to protect petrol supplies in the State of New South Wales. It has been the policy of the Opposition for some years that there should be Commonwealth essential services legislation similar to the existing legislation in the States. It has been the policy of the Opposition for some years that that legislation should make provision for the outlawing of strikes and other industrial action in any declared essential service while the declaration is current, and that particular attention should be given to defence matters and industries associated with the defence of the nation. Mr Howard repeated that commitment at the Federal Council of the Liberal Party only last weekend, and I would urge the Government to look to its responsibilities in that regard also.

The fourth way in which the Government can act in this matter is by making it clear that where the employer is behaving in a proper way towards its employees, as is certainly the case here, the Commonwealth will support the taking of legal action by the employer in those cases where the trade unions are not prepared to cooperate. This matter has already been raised within South Australia. The bans put in place by the Trades and Labour Council are probably in breach of the Trade Practices Act, and whilst the Opposition would agree that this matter would most satisfactorily have proceeded by entering into agreements in the interests of both parties, where there is a flouting of any agreement the Commonwealth should make it quite clear that it will support the employers protecting their rights against unlawful activities by trade unionists.

Finally, it is also important that the Commonwealth indicate that, in its administration of the contract, it will take those circumstances into account. They are circumstances which we hope would not occur but which appear to be becoming ever closer in this case-circumstances where the employers have to take legal action to protect the rights of Australian taxpayers and the rights of the Commonwealth under this contract. The reality is that, as the Minister at the table and Government senators know, industrial blackmail can be used to good effect when the taxpayer is ultimately paying the bill and there is not much chance of any effective remedy. I believe that unless the Commonwealth is prepared to act in those ways-that is, unless it is prepared to give a clear lead as to the direction to be followed, unless it is prepared to make it clear that it is not prepared to see this project sabotaged, unless it makes it clear that it is prepared to consider essential services legislation and unless it makes it clear that it is prepared to support the use of legal actions by employers in cases where the trade unions are clearly breaching the law-we will not get the sort of orderly administration of this contract which is required in the national interest.

The last thing I wish to say is that the State of South Australia went to a great deal of trouble to get this contract. It did get the contract on the basis of a demonstrated fine record in the industrial relations area. It is a shame that the lack of communication between the State Labor Government and the United Trades and Labour Council has brought this project to a point where there are significant delays and significant concerns about its successful conduct within that State. There is an enormous obligation on both the State and Federal governments to act in this matter, and the Opposition calls on them to do so.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Government, I certainly agree that this issue raised by Senator Chaney is a matter of public importance, or may well become one if the current situation goes on. I just want to speak briefly on the matter and put the Government's perspective in relation to the various issues raised by Senator Chaney.
