First of all, the industrial relations aspects of this project remain a matter between the Australian Submarine Corporation and the unions involved. That is so, and that will remain so. I want very quickly to identify, and in some way, in part, I agree with Senator Chaney, what the Government interest in this matter is. The Government interest in this matter is as a customer. The Government interest in this matter is as a customer which will be spending some $4 billion of taxpayers' money.
—And the rest.

—I do not want to debate that; I am using Senator Chaney's terminology. Roughly $4 billion is being spent on this program. That is the Government's interest, as a customer. I do not mean to say by that that because the Government is the customer it can be in any way indifferent to many of the issues raised by Senator Chaney. As far as the Government is concerned, there have been constant consultations between the parties and the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) and the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) regarding this issue. Senator Chaney pointed out that Mr Willis is in South Australia today, actively involved in attempting to resolve some of these issues. He is not there as an Industrial Relations Minister whose function it is to rush around the country pouring water on industrial disputes wherever they occur, because such matters are primarily matters for the parties involved. They would be under the Liberal Party's policies, just as they are under this Government's policies. He is there reflecting the Commonwealth's interests in the need to resolve this dispute as quickly as possible, as the customer concerned in this whole project.

SPEECH.PARA: Admittedly there has been some concern about delays, but let me make an important point about that: this submarine project involves work throughout the Commonwealth. The South Australian site is the assembly point, in essence, and a wide range of work on this project is proceeding in a large number of locations around Australia. Work has also proceeded on the site. To this time there have been no delays in the program. That does not mean that they will not arise very shortly unless this issue is resolved.

What we are talking about in terms of this Government's policy, involving both the submarine and frigate programs, is at least a $10 billion shipbuilding program. During the entire period of the Liberal Government which preceded this Government there was no defence shipbuilding program in this country. Two ships were built in that entire period, and they were built on a cost-plus basis. The view of the Liberal Government of the time was that it was easier to get these things done overseas than to build them here.

TALK.START.PARA: —We did try to build some, didn't we?

—Yes, on a cost-plus basis. That is a very important point. When we came into government after seven years of Fraser Government there were 24 unions on site at the Williamstown Naval Dockyard. Did the previous Government do anything about tackling that issue? When we have a big program of shipbuilding in Australia which is important for employment, which is important for technology transfer and which is important for wealth generation--
—In all of which you have our wholehearted support.

—As Senator Chaney says, we have the Opposition's wholehearted support in those matters. In those circumstances, it is absolutely essential that the sorts of issues which are now being reflected in South Australia are tackled, because we are talking about a 10-to 15-year program. If in order to resolve some of these issues of a multiplicity of unions on site and so on there must be a brouhaha at the beginning, it is much better that it happen then rather than having down the track a series of demarcation disputes between 18, 20 or 24 unions-as we inherited, for example, at the Williamstown Naval Dockyard.

SPEECH.PARA: The defence and industry policy of this Government is about building in Australia a capacity to construct ships as sophisticated as the submarine and the frigates. It is recognised by the Government that we cannot do it in the multi-union environment which we inherited. There is an argument at the submarine site at the moment as to whether three or more unions should work on the site. That is an argument between the company and the unions in South Australia. The Government's view, expressed on a number of occasions, is that there should be no more than three unions on that site. So that is our interest in ensuring that we can build industrial capacity here.

There have been suggestions of delays. If the Opposition had had its way the submarines would not have been built here at all. That was implicit in statements of Opposition spokesmen at the time of the signing of the contract for the construction of the submarines.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not true. It was clarified.

—It is clarified now, is it, Senator? That is true in terms of Opposition statements made at the time. For example, Senator MacGibbon favoured the British submarine tender and wanted to delay the signing of the contracts. Public statements were made by Opposition front benchers on the need to delay the signing of those contracts. I believe that they would still be working out whether they should have signed the contracts if those public statements, which were made at the time, are to be believed.

SPEECH.PARA: In May last year, prior to the Federal election, Mr Peter White, the Opposition spokesman on defence-it suited him at the time, I suppose-said that, if the Opposition was elected in the July 1987 election, it would consider cancelling the contract for the submarines. His statement was repudiated the next day by the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Howard. So much for the certainty engendered by the Opposition in relation to the question of delay! On 10 April 1988 Mr White was at it again in a Press release of that date. He talked about the desirability of considering a nuclear-powered submarine and cast doubts on the program in South Australia. If the Liberals had had their way in that matter I am sure that there would have been even greater delays.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is even harder to prove that something might have happened than that you have stopped beating your wife.

—I am just relying on the statement of the shadow Minister for Defence. As I said, when a company which is committed to building the submarine in Australia takes on a program of rationalisation it will undoubtedly run into difficulties because of the structure of the work force which we have inherited in this country. Those difficulties have to be overcome before the project starts. Nobody can run away from them. This is not a cost-plus contract. That submarine will be delivered at the price agreed or we will not get it at all. I think that is what it amounts to.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Chaney said that Mr Willis went to South Australia rather belatedly today to intervene in this matter on behalf of the Federal Government. Not so belated was Senator Chaney, who managed to slip down to the submarine site during a by-election in South Australia, and talk to the unions. Senator Chaney then went public on the issue. He incited the unions down there. What Senator Chaney said arising from that meeting-and I am glad he has met a few trade unionists; it is a very useful experience for him-was that the State and Federal governments were to blame for an industrial dispute which threatened further work at the construction site. Senator Chaney talked to representatives of two unions and one employer group which he would not name-very hush-hush stuff, submarine project!-who were involved in the dispute. Senator Chaney did all of that in the context of a by-election in South Australia. I understand that; it is part of the political business.

Senator Chaney said that the unions had certainly been very critical of both Labor governments-and that may be true-and that they had to resolve their difficulties with the Australian Submarine Corporation Pty Ltd. He said: `If they say, ``Fellers, you can work on this site with 10, 15 or 20 unions and the Commonwealth Government will continue to pay'', they are labouring under a delusion'. I hope that Senator Chaney said nothing to make them think that that would happen. He may have said that because that was his experience in government. The Liberals built two cost-plus ships in all their time in government. The thing blew out. There was no attempt by the Government at the time to tackle some of these problems which have to be confronted in South Australia. Senator Chaney made the point that there are other shipyards around Australia. There is one in Western Australia which has one union. It can happen.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is right; a very good shipyard.

—As Senator Chaney says, it is a good shipyard. The point that this country has to recognise is that, if we want to undertake major projects such as this submarine construction, it is the responsibility of the parties to work together to that end. That means that unions involved in these projects have a responsibility to ensure that production can take place in an efficient and competitive way.

SPEECH.PARA: Only a month or so ago a major motor car manufacturing company decided to erect a very big motor manufacturing plant in Scotland. It probably decided to do so long before that, but the issue came to a head two or three months ago. Under the-some Opposition senators might say enlightened-reign of Mrs Thatcher, no agreement could be reached between the trade unions and the company as to various issues relating to demarcation disputes and numbers of unions on site. The car company said, `Thank you very much. It is not on. We won't build this plant here'. It has been taken to another country. I mention that because we can either build the submarines here efficiently at the cost which the customer is prepared to pay or they will not be built in South Australia. There are other places in Australia where they can be built. If they cannot be built in other places in Australia they will be built overseas. That is a reality which any government confronted with this situation has to comprehend. This Government does not in any sense run away from that.
If I might just summarise what I have been saying, I do not want to comment on Senator Chaney's string of--

TALK.START.PARA: —Things to do.

—Senator Chaney's little shopping list of things that a Liberal government would do if it ever had the fortune to be here. I do not want to comment on all that because I do not think it goes to the central point. I just reiterate that this is a matter between the parties. It is important that it be resolved now, not in a series of disputations over the life of the submarine program. It is important that the parties reconcile their differences on this issue as quickly as possible. It is absolutely essential in a major engineering project of this kind, namely, the assembly of a submarine, that there be no demarcation disputes between a whole range of unions. This country cannot tolerate that in the future and it will not tolerate it as long as this Government is around. I assure all those involved that the solutions which have been suggested have to be dealt with and the dispute resolved as quickly as possible.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Chaney says that what is required is new attitudes and new views. I am glad he said that, because the last thing we should do is revert to old attitudes and old views, the sorts of old attitudes and old views which prevailed when Senator Chaney was a Minister in the previous Government. That Government allowed shipyards-Government-owned ones such as that at Williamstown-to operate with 24 unions. It ordered ships and made them cost plus, so the Government was hostage to any disputation which took place. That Government had old views and old attitudes. We have to move away from those. I believe that we are doing so. There will be difficulties along the way. This matter of public importance is about one of those difficulties. I urge the parties to resolve it as quickly as possible.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats cannot support this proposition. We feel that it is yet another example of the reactionary attitude of the Opposition towards industrial relations in this country. The Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) has just hit the nail on the head with the phraseology of his last sentence or two when he said that it was exemplary of old attitudes and old views. That is probably the basis of our primary objection to the proposition. It does not carry us forward; it just opens up the old psyche and the old attitudes and maintains a negative stance in relation to industrial relations as we have witnessed in this country in past decades. It is time now to move forward.
—Didn't you listen to the debate?

—I say that it is time to move forward. The dispute referred to in this motion is basically one of demarcation. The aspects which we would prefer to focus on are the industrial relations ones rather than the defence issues. The Australian Submarine Corporation came to an agreement with three unions-I suppose that in itself is significant-the Amalgamated Metal Workers Union, the Electrical Trades Union of Australia and the Federated Ironworkers Association of Australia, to conduct the work on the Royal Australian Navy's replacement submarines. I sense that this angered other construction unions such as the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union, which objected to being excluded from a $4.6 billion project, even though subcontractors were free to hire members of whatever unions they thought appropriate. So there is potential for flexibility in employment, even though inherently there is an initial commitment essentially between the employer and three broad unions.

SPEECH.PARA: Site work is now almost completed and the project is about four weeks behind schedule at this stage. I believe that the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) was intervening today in an attempt to take positive steps. He became involved to see whether anything could be done federally to ease the situation. We see that as having been a fairly positive reaction to a crisis which is in its fairly early stages. It does not appear to us that the Australian and South Australian governments have done anything in this dispute which labels them as `failures in coming to grips with the obstruction of the project by elements of the trade union movement in South Australia'. In other words, we do not see either the Australian Government or the South Australian Government as having failed at this stage. In fact, I see the intervention of Minister Willis today as having been constructive, fairly early and fairly appropriate. I see the statements of Premier Bannon of the last few days as being responsible and as appeals based upon responsibility and not irresponsibility and neglect.

What does the Opposition want the governments to do-to put on jackboots and go in bashing heads at this stage of the procedure? This is a dispute between the Australian Submarine Corporation and some Australian unions at a fairly early stage of the project. We believe it is appropriate and responsible to leave the parties at least to attempt at this point to resolve their differences and settle down-not to prod the dispute like a hornet's nest at the very beginning of the process but to allow the parties to establish positive and appropriate relationships.

The basic problem in this dispute is the state and the structure of industrial relations around Australia, and that is the problem which I would now like briefly to address. Even though there has been a trend towards enlightenment and an easing of strained relationships between the combatants in the past 18 months, industrial relations is still one of the most confrontationist areas of our society. I have in the past cited in this chamber the report of the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) and the Trade Union Development Council mission to Western Europe in 1987, which is entitled Australia Reconstructed. The Australian Democrats have argued that this is a valuable and responsible document which outlines several steps that Australia must take if we are to move from confrontation to reconciliation in industrial relations. This is, of course, what we must do if we are to progress internationally, and the Australian Democrats believe that it is not constructive to stir the possum and prod the hornet's nest in the situation which has been cited in this matter of public importance.

Australia Reconstructed emphasises the importance, first of all, of the provision of a stable economic environment by means of an incomes policy and, secondly, a range of policies designed to support efficient industries and to encourage industry reconstruction. It supports direct measures to promote productive investment and full employment. The first of the initial steps in achieving these aims is identified as the need for increasing emphasis to be placed on policies which strengthen the linkages between small and large firms so as to enhance import substitution by encouraging domestic supply of intermediate goods to larger exporting firms. Another initial step is the introduction of industry and trade programs with a strong regional focus which emphasise both efficient restructuring and the maintenance of a geographically and industrially diversified economy. The report emphasises research and development as being crucial to the restructuring process and the need for support programs specifically directed at high growth and strong international sector demands. It also cites a balanced approach to foreign investment as being critical, with specific policies directed towards ensuring that maximum benefit to the domestic economy accrues from both incoming and outgoing investment.

One recommendation of the report which has direct bearing upon this dispute is that for the amalgamation of unions. Fewer unions will produce fewer demarcation disputes and more industrial harmony. The report suggests that the Federal Government remove legislative barriers to the amalgamation of unions. In that respect it is a positive and constructive move that this employer is negotiating with essentially three unions. There is the potential difficulty that the 25 other unions on site will have their feathers ruffled, but we see the proposal as being appropriate and, in accordance with the suggestion of this report, the negotiation on site in this case is primarily with three unions. This does not appear to the Australian Democrats to be a radical document and the moves taken on site do not appear to be radical in themselves.

When reading through Australia Reconstructed it struck me as a reasonable blueprint for industrial development. Many of its recommendations have been advocated by the Democrats for years. What we did find shocking was the reaction of the Opposition to the report. It horrified the Federal Liberal and National parties. That is the word used. The Confederation of Australian Industry (CAI) labelled it as `extremely dangerous'. This reactionary attitude will not help in the slightest. The Opposition and some of the major business organisations such as the CAI are indulging in the kind of destructive confrontationism which has blighted Australian industrial relations for decades. We see that the proposal before the chamber at the moment is couched in such terms and continues in that vein. This type of attitude has done untold harm to the economy, our competitiveness on international markets and our living standards. Compared with our trading partners, Australia's industry has an abysmal record in utilising technological innovations, in improving industry based training and retraining and, most importantly, in generating an appropriate level of productive investment.

The union movement, through the ACTU, has acknowledged its responsibility to contribute to Australia's industrial regeneration by acknowledging that wage rises must be tied to productivity rather than merely to cost of living increases; by showing its willingness to discard the outmoded adversary system of industrial relations and replace it with a co-operative strategy embracing business, unions and government; and by using that consensus model to gear up productive investment, skills formation and export trade promotion. All this must now be encouraged by all sides of this Parliament and by all State parliaments. We cannot achieve industrial progress until we change the obviously unsatisfactory way in which we are doing things. This submarine dispute is a classic example. Both the Government and the Opposition, as well as the Australian Democrats, should now be thinking about ways to assist in developing the structures and processes which will be necessary to improve our competitiveness on international markets. In taking this attitude to industrial relations in general the Opposition continues to do a disservice to Australia.

As far as the defence aspects of this dispute are concerned, it is obvious that future defence contracts must be allocated with this dispute in mind and the Government must ensure that this set of circumstances never recurs. Apart from that, we cannot see what defence implications this dispute immediately has. The submarines will be built. They will be built in Australia, as should much other defence equipment. We see this proposal as a provocative action which will simply prod a hornet's nest and we do not believe what has occurred on site to date has been inappropriate and, frankly, we do not see the action of the present Australian Government or the South Australian Government as being either inappropriate or untimely.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Australia's largest ever defence contract is in jeopardy and a five-week strike is still proceeding in my State, South Australia, and the Australian Democrats' spokesman, Senator McLean, chooses to sit down quietly and to be ever so polite in not criticising the present Australian Labor Party Government federally and in South Australia because he has, on this first occasion of speaking about industrial relations, a commitment in the Australian Democrats to the labour unions' paper, the Australian Council of Trade Unions paper, Australia Reconstructed. If I have ever heard a lame, quiet, lie down approach to a major dispute that threatens our major defence project I have heard it today.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button, in his response to the speech of the Opposition Leader, Senator Chaney, was complacent, as the most senior representative of this Government in this chamber, because he said the objectives of this major defence project are all sound. The Government has been prodded by the Opposition and indeed by the whole expectation of the Australian people these days to have a more rational industrial relations environment. So he sought to defend himself by saying that by moving to a three-union contract on this site, by having a fixed contract for the Australian Submarine Corporation to complete this project-I acknowledge that it is a 10- to 15-year project-because these foundational decisions have been made by the Government in the past, the present crisis is not of any concern or worry. Yet in his remarks he did acknowledge that the project is in jeopardy. He clearly said that if this matter is not resolved the project will not proceed in South Australia. Indeed, there will not be any submarines built if the terms of the contract cannot be met.

This morning in South Australia wider implications were seen not only for this project being in jeopardy but for any Australian defence project being in jeopardy. The Senate well understands that we have only recently moved to maximising Australian content and Australian self-reliance in defence projects. Over the past 50 years we have depended too much upon our allies, bought equipment off the shelf and contracted overseas. Those days are gone. I agree with Senator Button and Senator Chaney that Australia needs to maximise Australian content and self-reliance. But if this project fails I predict that we will not see a healthy atmosphere for Australian defence contracts. Not only this contract is in jeopardy; also overseas industrial investment in this country and the reputation of my good State of South Australia are being very much compromised by this five-week strike. The submarine project is the biggest defence contract ever determined in this country. It involves $4.6 billion to provide six submarines to be assembled in Adelaide. Such a big project has the attention of overseas investors. If they want to measure the industrial relations climate in this country and are considering whether they will invest here they look to projects such as the submarine project, especially given the very warm and glowing professions by the Hawke Labor Government and the Bannon Labor Government in South Australia about the good industrial relations foundation in South Australia. An article in this morning's Adelaide Advertiser reads:
Overseas investment decisions regarding South Australia were being `put on hold' because of the submarines row, the South Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry said yesterday
Mr Deare-
the acting general manager-
said that the demarcation dispute over which unions would cover the assembly of submarines at Port Adelaide had made news in business circles overseas.
The Chamber had information that investment decisions involving South Australia were being `put on hold' because of the volatility of the situation.

It is not just in terms of industrial investment from overseas. The Western Australian competitors, as Senator Chaney said, are awake to this. A week ago there was a report in the West Australian that there had been a debate in the Western Australian Parliament indicating that Western Australia is ready to take up the project. It is now professing to have a good industrial relations climate. Indeed, it has its labour council on side to say to the Federal Government, `This biggest defence contract is in jeopardy in South Australia, but we are ready to pick up the ball in Western Australia'. I know that other States are ready to do the same. In fact, Senator Button said that if it fails in South Australia we will not have submarines. He directly conceded that this whole project is in jeopardy.

It is no good just saying that we have moved into an attempt to have a three-union site. I agree that it is long overdue to move away from the confusion of 24 unions, all with demarcation disputes such as those at the Williamstown dockyard, to a three-union contract. Like the Minister for Defence, Mr Beazley, I endorse the goal of a three-union contract such as has been determined by the Australian Submarine Corporation. But the endorsement that was given by Mr Beazley on 22 December of last year, at an early stage in these developments, however timely and clear it was, has not been given by the South Australian Premier and has not been given by the South Australian Trades and Labour Council. These are the villains in terms of the building of a good industrial relations environment. The Premier of South Australia, Mr Bannon, has now been elected President of the Australian Labor Party. Is he frightened to offend the unions? I put to my Labor colleagues from South Australia: Is he frightened to offend the Trades and Labour Council in South Australia? He certainly has not come forth with the same clear words that were used in December by the Minister for Defence.

Mr Willis has gone, on behalf of the Federal Government, to try to solve this dispute and, as Senator Button said earlier, to try to get a resolution of a three-union contract on this site. Mr Kelty went last Friday and failed. The Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) has endorsed the concept of a three-union contract. I would like the Senate to note carefully the following statement on 22 December:

The Minister for Defence, Mr Kim Beazley, today welcomed the announcement by the Australian Submarine Corporation that agreement had been reached with three unions to negotiate a national agreement covering the assembly of submarines and associated production work.

This statement was worked out with Mr Halfpenny. Senator McLean, speaking for the Australian Democrats, has referred to Australia Reconstructed. I reject his assessment of that document, and he knows that the Opposition does. Mr Halfpenny was one of the authors of that document, along with Mr Carmichael. He was the one who, with ACTU backing, negotiated this three-union agreement with the Australian Submarine Corporation. The Defence Minister, as the customer on behalf of all of us, also endorsed it. Then January, February and March passed and we are into April, and the Premier of South Australia, the President of the Australian Labor Party, is too frightened to endorse it. He wants to allow flexibility to the Trades and Labour Council.

It was with little surprise that, when I visited the South Australian Parliament on Wednesday of last week, I noted that the Opposition moved a motion of censure of the South Australian Minister of Labour, Mr Blevins, and of the Labor Government in South Australia-I heard it while it was being put forward and it is still on the books-on the inability of the Bannon Labor Government to ensure an industrial relations climate in my State of South Australia which will guarantee that this most important defence project proceeds in its assembly phase in my State. The terms of the motion moved by Mr Stephen Baker, the Opposition spokesman on labour, began in this way:
That this House condemns the Minister of Labour for the damage he has caused to-
(a) the submarine project by his support for the participation of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers and the Building Trades Unions in the engineering Works.

It went on to stress the failure to ensure a good industrial relations climate in South Australia. There was then a direct reference to three of the mad hatter unions which are wanting to get in on this assembly site in Adelaide, because the three-union agreement which was negotiated with the ACTU and Mr Halfpenny involves the Amalgamated Metal Workers Union, the Federated Ironworkers Association of Australia and the Electrical Trades Union of Australia.

Senator Button, representing this Government here in Canberra, said today again that that three-union agreement is endorsed by the Federal Government. But I put it to the Senate that to have a superior objective in terms of the nature of the contract, in terms of the industrial relations objectives, is not to say that that contract or environment has been achieved. We have had five weeks of strike, and in this debate today the urgency that we bring from the Opposition leads only to complacency, in response from the Government, and quiet politeness on behalf of the Democrats. I, along with all other Opposition members, can only warn the Senate that we have a major project in my State of South Australia which is now in jeopardy because of the failure of the Labor Government in Canberra and the Labor Government in South Australia. Unless we get some recognition from the remaining speakers from the other side we will continue to bring that alert to the people of Australia. The defence programs that reach right through to the end of the century are in jeopardy unless we can get a favourable industrial relations climate in this country.
Let me refer to an advertisement that the Premier of my State placed in May of last year in the Advertiser. I have it in my hand. It has a glowing self-portrait of the Premier, along with the words:
We've won the submarine contract.
Once again, South Australia has shown what can be done by working together.

He put forward that view, and we supported him in a bipartisan way to get the project for my State of South Australia. But then he tried to claim all the credit for it because of his success in building an industrial relations climate that was sound and good for this project. Now what is he doing about it? January, February and March have gone by and we are into April, and he has not given any endorsement of the foundation that we have seen endorsed by this Federal Government. I bring to the Senate the urgency of this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen C.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been in the Senate for only a short time, and I must say that the performance of the Liberal Party on this matter of public importance is astonishing. When Senator Teague says that the project in South Australia, to build the submarines, is in jeopardy because of the Federal and State Labor governments, I am amazed. It is only because of the efforts of both those governments that we have the project in South Australia. If we had relied on the Liberal Party policy that existed here for 23 years and then for another seven years, there would not be any submarines built anywhere in Australia. The Opposition policy for years was to buy submarines off the shelf from overseas and to give the money to somebody else. That was its attitude to defence procurement and expenditure in Australia. Senator Teague said that we are going to lose the project because of Labor governments. We have got it going only because of Labor governments. I wish he would give due credit to those governments.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Teague has, in a bi-partisan way, supported the submarine contract. I point out to the Senate that during the mid-1980s I was State Secretary of the Party in South Australia. I can remember when John Bannon first started the campaign to have submarines built in South Australia. The Federal Labor Government announced that it was going to build the submarines in Australia rather than adopt the usual Liberal attitude of buying them off the shelf from America or somewhere in Europe. When John Bannon started that campaign it was treated with derision in South Australia and ignored by many members of the Liberal Party. It was not given much support because the concept was too imaginative for the Liberal Party in our State to comprehend.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not true.
—That is the truth.
—It is not true. It was roundly supported.

—This is the absolute truth, Senator Teague. I was part of the campaign leading up to the 1985 election when, to the honourable senator's great chagrin, John Bannon won a great electoral victory with the support of the South Australian people. One major plank was the campaign to get the submarines. By that stage, yes, the honourable senator's Party was acting like a very lame duck in supporting the Bannon campaign because it realised that there was going to be every opportunity for success. I want to point out to the Senate today just what has been the Liberal attitude. If we go back over the last two or three years we find a consistent, carping negativism by the Liberal Party towards the submarines. First of all, I would like to quote Mr Aldred, who I understand is the Federal member for Bruce in the House of Representatives. I understand that he may be chairman of a Liberal Party parliamentary finance committee. He has made a number of statements in the Parliament and issued a number of Press statements which I think make very instructive reading about the current attitude of the Liberal Party towards the submarine contract in Australia and particularly South Australia. On 23 February 1988 in the Parliament, Mr Aldred stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Australia's new conventional submarine project must be halted now.

There was no equivocation; it was a statement of fact. That is what he said. If that is not an indication that at least some members of the Liberal Party are wanting to run dead, I do not know what is.

TALK.START.PARA: —What did he say, Senator? Read it again.
—For the information of Senator Crowley and again to emphasise the point, I will read it again:

SPEECH.PARA: Australia's new conventional submarine project must be halted now.
That is what he said on 23 February 1988, eight months after the project had been granted to South Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not the Opposition view.

—He is a member of the Opposition. Why does the Opposition not expel him? He knew what he was doing. It was not a slip of the tongue. He stated that in the Parliament in a debate on defence matters and he issued it as a Press statement. In the same debate-he also put this out as a Press statement-he stated:

SPEECH.PARA: In light of India's acquisition of nuclear submarines and the very real probability of Indonesia acquiring them in the very near future, I call on the Minister for Defence to adopt the only viable option-to ensure Australia's future security, our submarine project must be comprehensively reassessed.

There is no doubt that the Liberal attitude is to undermine the project in South Australia. Mr Aldred, a long-standing member of the House of Representatives, has clearly belled the cat for the Liberal Party. I now turn to statements made by Mr Sinclair. I know he is not a member of the Liberal Party but he is a great friend of the present Leader of the Opposition. He calls him `Sinkers' in his quieter moments. Mr Sinclair is the shadow Minister for defence. I will quote four different points that he has made in the Melbourne Age going back to September 1986. He stated:
A Liberal-National Party Government would consider scrapping the $2,600 million purchase of new conventional submarines in favour of nuclear-powered vessels.
That was Mr Sinclair's attitude. Everyone knows that we would not be able to build nuclear powered submarines anywhere in Australia. In a Press statement on 20 March 1987, he stated:
I am still worried about the design selected by the Government.
Again, great doubts were raised about whether the project should proceed in Australia. In May 1987 in the Parliament, he stated:
However, I am a little curious as to the siting of the project.

He is not warmly endorsing the South Australian possibility at all; he is trying to throw cold water on it and damage the prospects of South Australia getting the project. I notice that he never came down to Port Adelaide at any stage or into South Australia and repeated those remarks although he had many invitations to do so. On 29 May 1987, he stated:
We on this side of the House want to look at the smaller propulsion unit that was included in the French design submarine, the Rubis, which has a small nuclear cell.

This was in late May 1987 just as the project for South Australia was about to be signed. He was still raising the nuclear option knowing full well that if it was adopted that would be the end of building conventional submarines in Australia because we could not build nuclear submarines in this country. So that is the attitude of the shadow Minister for defence, Mr Sinclair, towards the project.

I now turn to the extraordinary performance of Mr White, who later became the shadow Minister for defence. I understand that at this stage he still is the shadow Minister for defence. When I quote these passages I know that I will be told that they have been corrected and changed and that there was a misunderstanding, but they give real substance to the view that a large section of the Liberal Party wanted to dud the submarine project in Australia. On 28 May 1987 the Australian Associated Press (AAP) reported Mr White as stating:
The signing of contracts for Australia's new submarines should be delayed until after the election.

That created mayhem in South Australia for the Liberal Party. Mr Steele Hall immediately repudiated it. Members of the Liberal Party got on to John Howard and he immediately repudiated it and said, `The shadow Minister for Defence does not know what he is talking about. That is not correct'. But this was stated by the shadow Minister for defence. It is probably a further indication of why the Liberal Party was unfit to be considered to win the election. AAP also reported him as follows:
Mr White said he stopped short of committing a Coalition Government to repudiating the contracts but said there was no guarantee a new government would accept them.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. The quotation of history is not relevant to the necessary defence that the Government should mount on a matter of current urgency and a matter of public importance. We have yet to hear in seven minutes from Senator Schacht on this matter--
—Order! There is no point of order.

—I thank Senator Teague. I knew that I was making a sharp point against the Liberal Party. The point of order indicated that. Mr White stated, `There was no guarantee a new government would accept them'. Again, that is an indication that the Opposition was dubious about the contract being granted not only to South Australia but obviously anywhere in Australia. Again in a Press statement on 22 May he stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The Liberal Party is not going to accept the $4 billion project simply because the Minister says it is alright.

Is that not a clear indication that he has grave doubts about the submarines being built in Australia, let alone in South Australia? In January this year, eight months after the project had been announced, Mr White stated:

Australia should immediately examine the option of acquiring nuclear powered naval vessels and particularly nuclear powered submarines. We should know just what are their capabilities and their costs and what infrastructure is required to support nuclear vessels.

This is an indication that the Opposition has not given up trying to torpedo the submarine project for South Australia. It was still at it earlier this year. (Quorum formed) I know that Liberal Party senators will be reading onto the record the attitude of various people to this project. A couple of members of the South Australian Parliament ought to have their views recorded. One of them is Dale Baker, the State member for Victoria in the House of Assembly in South Australia. In May of last year he issued statements in his electorate in which he indicated that the submarine contract was a waste of time and a waste of money. That was the attitude of a senior member of the Liberal Party in South Australia. I think the final chagrin of the Liberal Party in South Australia is indicated by the statement that Mr Olsen issued the day that South Australia was awarded the submarine contact. The statement is headed `Disappointed, says Olsen' and reads:

Opposition Leader, Mr Olsen, said today South Australia had won only 20 per cent of the $4000m Navy submarine contract and he was disappointed with this after the work done by industry, unions and the South Australian Government.

He did not have the good grace to congratulate South Australia on achieving such a spectacular industrial development. In view of those statements that have been made over the last couple of years, Opposition senators cannot say that the matter of public importance proposed here today is other than self-serving and a political stunt that enables the Liberal Party suddenly to jump on the bandwagon and say that it is all in favour of the submarine project in South Australia. To say the least, that is hypocritical. I believe that the Liberal Party has been exposed as having run soft and run dead and having done much to undermine the project. It hopes that the project is lost to South Australia because it believes that that will gain it political kudos in South Australia in trying to win the next State election. The Liberal Party will be in for a great shock. The contract will not be lost to South Australia. The project will proceed.

I do not disagree that at present difficulties are being experienced between the contractors and the unions. Those difficulties will be negotiated to a satisfactory conclusion in the next few days. However, when they are satisfactorily concluded it will be because of the sound industrial relations record in South Australia. For 20 years that State has had the lowest level of industrial disputation of any State in Australia. It does the Liberal Party no credit suddenly to jump up today and say that everything is wrong in South Australia. Certainly we do not dismiss the idea that difficulties are being encountered. They will be overcome with the good offices and the work of the Premier of South Australia, the Minister for Industrial Relations, Mr Willis, and the Minister for Defence, Mr Beazley. I look forward to seeing the submarine project go forward, despite the carping criticism of the Liberal Party of Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter of public importance before the Senate today concerns the failure of the Hawke and Bannon governments to come to grips with the obstruction of the submarine construction project by elements of the trade union movement in South Australia and the disastrous implications for both defence and industry development. The key elements in that matter of public importance are the failure of the Hawke and Bannon governments to cope with the crisis they have when being stood over by the union movement and the grave consequences that arise from that for the defence of Australia and for industry. Before I speak to the matter of public importance I shall deal briefly with the remarks of those from the Left who have spoken against this important matter; but that will not take long. Senator Button sought to pretend that there was no problem at all. He very much took the Bannon line that it was between the company and the unions. That is a flagrantly dishonest and a morally cowardly way to go.

—I take a point of order, Madam Acting Deputy President. I draw your attention to those remarks of Senator MacGibbon, which blatantly misrepresent what Senator Button said. I suggest by way of taking a point of order that if he wishes to criticise Senator Button's remarks he may not use the terms that he did in this place in blatantly misrepresenting the truth.
—I wish to speak to the point of order. I was present in the chamber when Senator Button spoke; Senator Crowley was not.
—I was so. That is another misrepresentation.
—Order! I do not believe a point of order is involved; it is a matter of opinion.

—The point is that the Government has a moral and legal obligation to Australia to clean up the mess in Australia today in the submarine program. Senator Button promised to do everything but help in that process. Senator McLean's remarks were typical of statements made by the Australian Democrats-the far left branch of the Australian Labor Party. He said in effect, `Be kind to the bullies'. Appease them as much as you can and hope that somehow or other the tiger that you are riding on will not eat you'. The most amazing statement of all that he made was that he could not see the defence implications in the problems that the unions were creating. Perhaps that was a true statement. The approach of Senator Schacht to the matter demonstrated an almost childlike naivety about the great complexities and the great technical risks involved in the submarine program. One would think that we were involved in something like making cans for beans or something, if one were to listen to his remarks. He showed a total inability to understand what is involved and the risks that the Australian taxpayer faces in undertaking this huge program.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn to the matter of public importance before the Chair. As I said, its two key elements are the failure of the Government to act in the face of union intransigence and the consequences of that for defence and industry in Australia. The matter concerns the building of submarines in Australia. For the information of the Labor Party, we on this side believe that, Australia having started to build these submarines, that exercise must be executed as efficiently and effectively as possible. We have very great doubts about the design selected; we have great doubts about the site selected. I shall come to those matters in a moment. The first point I make is that we got into this through mismanagement on the part of the Government. There was no pressing need to replace our submarines. Most things in Australian defence are dealt with years behind schedule, but we have a fleet of six very good submarines-the best diesel electric submarines in the world-whose life could be extended to the end of the century. There was no need for us to get involved in this program at the breakneck speed that we did.

I wish to refer to two elements of the program: first, the design itself and, second, the place at which the submarines are being built. The one common denominator in all of this is the way in which the Government has mismanaged the program. The design for these boats is less than good. That is because we are dealing with a builder-the state government dockyard in Sweden, Kockums-which was bankrupt. It was saved from closing its doors only by the order it received from Australia for these boats.

In many ways Sweden is not a technologically advanced country. In many ways it is not as advanced as Australia. It has a population of about only eight million people. It has never built submarines larger than about half the size of the one that it is building for the Australian Government. It has never built boats of the size, with the range and, least of all, with the weapons systems fit that are required for these boats. It is running into enormous problems. That is demonstrated by the fact that the first boat now must be built almost entirely in Sweden. Minister Beazley promised us as part of the deal that we would build the first boat in Australia. We now find that because the Swedes have never designed a power discharge tube for the torpedoes they cannot design the bow section, so the bow section must be built in Sweden. There are midship problems with the centre section of the hull, and so it has to be built in Sweden. Now we find that the stern section has to be built in Sweden. So much for that.

TALK.START.PARA: —No-one is building it here.

—That is right: no-one is prepared to move at the moment. We are involved in a program that has enormously high technical risks. As custodians of the public dollar, we are very concerned at the inevitable cost increases that will occur in this program. Already it is the most expensive contract we have ever signed. These submarines will cost $1 billion each by the time they get into the water. Six of them will cost more than $6 billion. There is an argument for buying new submarines, but not at that price. If we are to spend that sort of money, we could probably buy two carriers with air wings to go with them. These are the sorts of priorities we get into if we go down that path. The Labor Party would throw its hands up in horror if I suggested that we buy a carrier, but it is spending a lot more money on these submarines. The technical problems involved in this program are really quite enormous, and the Government simply does not realise what is involved.

SPEECH.PARA: One of my main objections to the whole program is the dishonest way in which it has been handled. The argument has never been about the design of the submarines, their capabilities, their cost, or anything like that. The program has been carefully turned into a pork-barrelling exercise as to where the submarines will be built. The whole debate during the selection process revolved around whether they would be built in Adelaide, Perth, Brisbane, Sydney or Melbourne. That, of course, was entirely beside the point. In the end South Australia won the prize, and good luck to it. As I said at the start of my speech, South Australia having won it, and having signed the contract, we should all of us get in and make it work. We should not be held to blackmail by irresponsible unions.

I would not have selected South Australia, because it has no heavy engineering skill base. It is not commonsense or economic sense for the submarines to be built where there is no industrial skill base to go into a heavy engineering program. However, the argument advanced was the great industrial relations record of South Australia. I have two things to say about that. First, as there is no heavy engineering in that State, there has not been much strike activity. Secondly, the only two shipbuilders in the history of South Australia both went broke and out of business as a result of union blackmail. Criminal activities and union demarcation problems drove the two South Australian builders out of business. Yet, the argument was that South Australia's industrial relations record was so good that it should receive the contract. Of course, the truth came out of the bag when good old Mick Young, everyone's mate, resigned a month or so ago, and Mr Bannon and other senior members of the Ministry said that Mick got the submarines for South Australia. I really think that probably was the sole determining influence in South Australia obtaining the contract.

There is now this great strike and industrial problem between the United Trades and Labour Council of South Australia and the Australian Submarine Corporation, which is attempting to build and satisfy the contract it has. Right from the time the Australian Submarine Corporation signed the contract it recognised the supreme importance of union relations, and it has been scrupulously diligent, careful and correct in what it has done. It has talked and talked and reached agreement with the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU), and indeed it has the public support of the ACTU to refine the number of unions on site to three: the Amalgamated Metal Workers Union, the Federated Ironworkers Association and the Electrical Trades Union. It is very important that it did that, because Australian shipbuilding has been bedevilled by demarcation disputes between dozens and dozens of different unions. As I said before, the demarcation disputes and criminal elements, particularly within the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union, have driven other builders in Australia out of business.

The Australian Submarine Corporation, in consultation at every stage with the ACTU, reached agreement as to what would be the union practices on the site. But, what happened? The United Trades and Labour Council in South Australia has bailed up, gone on strike, and put work bans on the development of the site. As a result the whole program has been held up for five weeks. The problem appears interminable; no one can see any solution to it. Mr Bannon and Mr Hawke are simply political tools of the trade union movement. They just will not stand up and tell the people in the Trades Hall in Adelaide that they cannot proceed with what they are doing. Mr Bannon looks particularly weak and effete over this matter. I think he always looks that way. He just wrings his hands. Tomorrow he is getting on a plane and is running away to Japan for a few days or a few weeks-no doubt hoping that when he returns the problem will be solved. He will not create a very good impression in Japan, with its industrial relations record, when he opens up a paper there and realises that the Japanese are reading about what is happening in Adelaide.

The Government's responsibility is very clear. It cannot wring its hands and say that it is a matter between the Australian Submarine Corporation and the trade union movement. If the Government had the backbone, it would stop the pickets outside the South Australian site. However, when we and the people of South Australia turn on our television sets tonight we will see pickets at the Williamstown Dockyard in Victoria. Labour senators who have contributed to the debate have made great play of the building of the FFGs at Williamstown Dockyard, and the Anzac ships to be built later. I shall be very surprised if they are ever built, the way things are going there. The work force has completely closed down at Williamstown Dockyard, and the Victorian Government is doing nothing at all to correct the situation. It is just waiting for the unions to fight it out amongst themselves. When the unions have had enough and decided what needs to be done, the Government will have its problems solved for it.

The result of all this will be that the shipbuilding program in Australia upon which we are embarking, a program worth $15 billion over the next 15 years, will die, because we cannot build ships if the unions will not provide the work force. What the Government must do is move towards voluntary unionism, reducing the number of unions, and, above all, making unions answerable to the law. Today in the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development, one country will not invest in another if it has more than one union to deal with. In Australia we have come a long way. With this contract the number of unions has been reduced to three. However, the Government will not give that aspect any practical support at all.

The second part of this motion deals with the effects on our industry and on defence. The effects on industry are enormous. Unless the hulls of these submarines are started and built, the whole of the program, worth between $6 billion and $8 billion, will fail. Australian industry is being asked to make a big investment, a lot of capital, in high technology. The program is very closely disciplined with regard to time. Companies will not make the investment to provide the weapons systems and all other equipment for the submarines if the hulls run one, two or three years over time on production. So, the regeneration of Australia's manufacturing base, which is absolutely critical to Australia getting out of the debt position into which the Labor Government has spent us, depends on getting the workers in South Australia back to work straightaway.

The consequences for our defence capability also are enormous, because delay means money. The Government has cost the Australian taxpayers billions of dollars because it has not been concerned about the welfare of the men and women in Australia's defence forces. Because the Government has not been concerned, many of the personnel have left. On top of the loss of billions of dollars caused by the premature resignations from the Services there has been this delay in the execution of contracts to buy new equipment. The Government having embarked on this course of action, its only option is to get in and deal with these unions in an honourable and effective way so that the Australian taxpayer is not put at any further risk than at present.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the following matter of public importance:

SPEECH.PARA: The failure of the Hawke and Bannon governments to come to grips with the obstruction of the submarine construction project by elements of the trade union movement in South Australia and the disastrous implications for both defence and industry development.

One by one speakers opposite have read that out or alluded to it. They have accused Government speakers of not addressing the issues in the matter of public importance, and have then refused to speak to the matter themselves. As the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) said in refuting the words of Senator Chaney, Senator Chaney's contribution to the debate was principally a shopping list of what would be a good idea of what to do in the future. The comments of Senator Teague seemed to fall somewhere between criticising Senator Button for not being serious-`complacent' was the word he used, and I very nearly sprang on that because of its total dishonesty-and remarking on how seriously Senator Button had described the issue. I cannot understand how one can say how serious a matter is and at the same time accuse somebody of being complacent.

We have just heard Senator MacGibbon scatter his bullets in every direction, except as to the matter under debate. He put forward not one suggestion as to how the issue should be tackled. He just kept saying that it should be tackled in the three or four times that he strolled back towards the subject. He did not refute the Government's claims that the Opposition is unclear, confused and divided in its attitude to the submarine project. Criticisms from the Opposition by way of interjection were to the effect that that is not the case now-presuming, inadvertently, to admit that it was the case then. I wish to quote a few remarks by Opposition spokesmen to point out that this still is a matter of confusion among the Opposition. I address not only last year's quotes but statements made this year. Further to that, we had Senator MacGibbon's comments that, as the matter is on the ground, let us get on with it; but he also commented that, in the meantime, it is not the right thing to be doing. I take his point that he is at least saying that we should proceed with the project but is giving the matter tame or half-hearted support. He certainly agrees with some of the quotations that I shall now come to. First-this has been quoted before but I think that it is important to put it on the record again-let me quote a report about Mr White, the defence spokesperson, on 28 May by Australian Associated Press:
The signing of contracts for Australia's new submarines should be delayed until after the election, Opposition Defence spokesman Peter White said today.
Mr White said he stopped short of committing a Coalition Government to repudiating the contracts but said there was no guarantee a new government would accept them.

The Opposition seems to suggest that that was not the case, that it did not really mean it, that it was not really said, and so on. Not only was it really meant and really said, but Mr Howard raced to repudiate it, to the point where the Minister for Defence, Mr Beazley, on 29 May 1987 put out a Press release saying that he:
welcomed the Opposition Leader's repudiation of his spokesman on Defence, Peter White.

Those points have been elaborated in this chamber. The Opposition was and is confused as to its attitude to the submarine project. It sort of wants it but it sort of does not, and it is not quite sure what sort of project it would prefer if it had the opportunity. That confusion remains and it illustrates the division and erratic nature of Opposition policy. It has been brilliantly illustrated over the last week in terms of Opposition tax policy.
To bring the matter more up to date: on 10 April this year the Federal member for McPherson, the shadow Minister for Defence, made the following statement in a whole page Press release:
Nuclear powered ships for the Royal Australian Navy is an option which must be examined.
He continued in that statement:
It is to the everlasting shame of the present Government that no proper study of the nuclear option was carried out when the proposals for the Australian submarine were being examined.

That clearly indicates that the Opposition would like to keep its nuclear power options open. If that is the case, how does Senator MacGibbon hope to spend the money he wants to spend, or says that his Party is committed to spend with the current submarine project, in order to keep his nuclear submarine options open? Going on past experience, I would have thought that the coalition parties would buy the submarine off the shelf from overseas because Australia is unable to build some critical parts of nuclear powered submarines and is unable to service or maintain such submarines.

What is the Opposition's policy on submarines? Labor senators have the right to claim that there is confusion among the Opposition. That point needs to be made because the Federal Labor Government, in its commitment which it has expressed with clarity and in instigating a defence program with an Australian component in which the submarine will be built in Australia, makes a nonsense of the Opposition's attempt to introduce a matter of public importance on this topic. No government-neither the South Australian Labor Government nor the Federal Labor Government-which has gone to this amount of effort and trouble to get a submarine project in place will sit around and do nothing about the difficulties confronting the project. The Opposition's argument on this aspect is specious and ridiculous. By way of contradiction of Senator MacGibbon's comments, I would point out that nuclear submarines were considered but dismissed by the Navy as unsuitable to our operational needs. It seems that Senator MacGibbon grossly misrepresented the adequate and comprehensive examination of Australia's needs in this area when he lightly dismissed Government evidence that the most appropriate submarines are those which we have sought to build and which are in the process of getting under way.

My colleague Senator Button made the Government's position clear. He gave the Senate an excellent summary of the Government's position and an excellent understanding of the Government's attitude to industrial relations. He clearly indicated his understanding of the position and of the problem, and pointed to the Government's attitude and awareness in this respect. To suggest that because Senator Button did not shout, or throw his arms around, or thump the table, he was complacent is a gross misrepresentation of what he said. Surely the Opposition should have had the grace to admit that Senator Button dealt comprehensively with an analysis and understanding of the situation that faces Australia. The Government is more than aware of the difficulties and is taking steps to address them. It is aware that these problems are not solved overnight. If the Opposition is unclear as to the Government's seriousness in attempting to come to grips with the issues in submarine construction, I urge it to read Senator Button's comments tomorrow.

Senator Button made clear that essentially this is an issue between the employers, the Australian Submarine Corporation, and the unions involved. The Government's involvement is twofold, as Senator Button said. First, we are a customer and we have a serious interest from that point of view. Also, as the Federal Government-and in terms of this matter of public importance I think that we can speak on behalf of the South Australian Bannon Labor Government-we have an interest in the importance to Australia of the development of this significant Australian defence industry, and the commitment to changes and developments in the industrial arena. It is curious that the Opposition wants to attack Minister Button, particularly in the light of his statement this afternoon, when there are any number of examples of his commitment to appropriate changes in Australian industry in seeking to do the many things which the Opposition failed to do in a period of 23 years, and a subsequent period of seven years, in government. Opposition members have a great gall to talk about industrial matters. Senator Chaney acknowledged the good record of industrial relations in South Australia. He conceded that that was one of the proper reasons why the submarine contract went to that State. I quote from the Advertiser of 12 March 1988 during the Port Adelaide by-election campaign:
The Federal Opposition's spokesman for Industrial Relations, Senator Chaney, said in Adelaide he had talked yesterday morning with key unions involved in the dispute and a project representative but-
this was a point made by Senator Button-
he refused to name the unions involved or the representative.

How coy! The Premier, Mr Bannon, is described in the article in the Advertiser as talking of Senator Chaney's moves as `a cynical political stunt'. When Senator Chaney was accused of the same by Senator Button in this place today, he grinned in acknowledging that it was all part of the political campaigning in the Port Adelaide by-election. Senator Chaney acknowledged the importance of the industrial relations record for the approval of South Australia in obtaining the contract for the building of the submarines. He said in an article which I paraphrase from, I think, the Queensland Courier-Mail on Monday, 14 March, that South Australia has a justifiable record of industrial relations and that record properly contributed to its being awarded the contract.

For the record, I want to recall the industrial disputation record of the present Liberal Opposition when it was in government. (Quorum formed) It is curious that the Opposition should call a quorum when I am about to compare this Government's record and the previous Liberal Government's record on industrial disputation. The November working days lost figure of 126,700, whilst slightly higher than the October figure of 117,600, is the lowest November figure achieved by this Government. It is more than 50 per cent lower than the November average of 272,700 working days lost under the previous Liberal Government. The dramatic improvement in dispute activity since the election of the Hawke Government is better illustrated by the monthly average of working days lost, which has dropped by 53 per cent to 116,100, compared with 249,600 under the previous coalition Government. This improvement is even more remarkable when employment growth over the two periods is considered. Clearly this demonstrates that the Hawke Government's industrial relations policy, including the accord with the union movement, has contributed to a significant improvement in industrial relations in Australia. That is on the record and beyond dispute.

I simply say, in summary, that the Opposition in bringing on this matter of public importance has failed to address the issues. It has simply wanted to blame Federal and State Labor governments. It has failed to address the seriousness with which the Federal and State Labor governments are addressing this issue-if for no other reason than they have worked so hard to get this project in place. Of course they are serious about the industrial difficulties confronting the project at the moment; of course they are taking steps to address it; and of course we will see the solution that we can see any number of times on this Government's record. The Opposition's arguments are hollow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Burns Sen B.R

TALK.START.PARA: —This debate has been instituted by the Opposition as a cheap political manoeuvre to enable it in a very hypocritical way to parade ignorance as expertise. The Opposition is critical of the Bannon and Hawke governments because of what it perceives needs to be done to bludgeon the trade unions into submission. I would suggest that the understanding and expertise in the industrial relations area of those governments is far greater than that of the Opposition. I also suggest that we will not under any circumstances adopt the Liberal-National Party approach to industrial relations and bludgeon people, making them industrial conscripts. That is no solution; it will not work in the short term or the long term.

SPEECH.PARA: For some time the Opposition has been critical of the number of unions involved in the industrial scene in this country-a situation which without doubt has led to a quite substantial number of demarcation disputes. Of all disputes, these disputes are probably the most negative and unrewarding to all parties. On many occasions, though, people ignore the fact that such disputes are commenced on the basis of people's concern for their livelihood and the welfare of their families-their concern about having the right to a job. It may be that if one stands back and takes a broader view, one finds that such disputes are not the correct way to go, but for those people involved they certainly are. Bringing them enlightenment and understanding about what needs to be done in the future in the interests of this country is much more profitable, much more rewarding, than suggesting that because they may not understand the broader situation, because they may have an imperative worrying about whether they will get paid or have a job next week, they should be bludgeoned into submission. I suggest that is the wrong way to go.

The Liberal and National parties also quite consciously, although saying there were too many unions, legislated to prevent amalgamations-amalgamations which have now been shown, and it is on the record, to have led to the elimination of demarcation disputes in many instances. Further amalgamations, which are supported by the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) but obviously opposed for narrow political reasons by the Liberal Party, would lessen much further demarcation problems in industry. The Amalgamated Metal Workers Union, the Electrical Trades Union and the Federated Ironworkers Association of Australia were undoubtedly motivated by such a desire when they came to an agreement with the Australian Submarine Corporation concerning this engineering project. It is an engineering project, quite different from the situation where there is a ship on a slipway in the traditional shipbuilding fashion. I understand, having been involved in these matters over many years, that the unions are concerned about building up industry in this country. They are conscious of the fact that mistakes have been made in the past and they are seeking to build up industry by taking a rational approach to the construction of the submarines, and that is why they have reached an agreement with the company. That, of course, does not mean that people who will find themselves without work and unions that will find themselves not representing people in an area they feel they have a right to represent them in will not feel left out and will not take some sort of action to try to protect their position. The answer is not to bludgeon them and it is not to misrepresent the position, as has been done by the papers and by members of the Liberal Party. Let us look at the Liberal Party's attitude. A Mr Aldred, who is the Opposition's treasury and finance committee chairman, has said:
Australia's new conventional submarine project must be halted now.

He said we can buy them off the shelf cheaper. He was absolutely unconcerned about the possibility of technology transfer. He was absolutely unconcerned about the number of jobs that would be available, even though there was some dispute about how the project might be proceeded with. That is the Liberal Party position. It does not care about jobs and it does not care about workers, but that is not unusual because that is its approach to all sorts of problems in industry in this country. I repeat that the ACTU has played a very important role in seeking to reduce by way of amalgamation the number of unions, and so create a better climate for industry in this country.

The task of building the submarines will involve a lot more unions than the three I have mentioned. It will involve a number through the system of subcontracting. A subcontract has already been let in Sydney which will involve other unions. I refer again to the fact that people have been trying to misrepresent the position. A letter from Mr D. G. Williams, the Chief Executive Officer of the Australian Submarine Corporation, was published in the Australian of 4 April. He referred to the rubbish being peddled by people on the other side of the chamber about great delays and all the additional money that it will cost this country. He said:

During the project definition study work undertaken by the Australian Submarine Corporation in 1985/6 the launching of our first submarine was scheduled for 1993. That has not changed. For any new naval vessel there is a period of tests and trials scheduled. Accordingly, Submarine 01 is to be commissioned into the RAN in early 1995, as is specified in the contract between the Commonwealth and the Australian Submarine Corporation. There has been no change to this schedule since the contract was signed.

We would also like to point out that there is no basis for the implicit suggestion that the cost to the Commonwealth is increasing dramatically or in some uncontrolled manner. There have been no contract amendments to date which could lead anyone to that conclusion.

That letter was written by the Chief Executive Officer of the company which will build the submarines. He pointed out to those people who are trying to suggest that the construction of the submarine facility is tied to the construction of the submarines that it is not tied in a direct way. All the unions whose members would normally be expected to work on the site will be and have been working on the site. Work has been proceeding without an agreement for some six months with little or no industrial disputation. I am informed very reliably that an agreement has already been signed by all unions bar the Amalgamated Metal Workers Union, which has some problem about wage relativities with some other union. But it will be signed by those people because they seek to have that sort of agreement.

An ex-Liberal Party member in Queensland was quoted recently as saying what a wonderful agreement had been reached so that the World Expo 88 site was completed on time. He paid tribute to the honour of the trade union movement in keeping that agreement. He said how happy he was with the proceedings as far as Expo was concerned. Senator Stone would put his head under his arm when that was being said. He would not want to know about it. He wants to know only about the bad things that are said about the trade union movement.

The Hawke Government and the Bannon Government are saying, `If we can be of assistance'-and I understand that Ralph Willis is over there today-`we will do whatever we can to help. We will not bludgeon trade unions into submission. We will not make them industrial conscripts. We will help'. At this stage there has been no question of people, either the trade union members or the employers, asking for assistance. They are seeking to work the matter out, as is evidenced by the letter I quoted from which was dated as late as 4 April. I believe that that is the way to go. If there must be some delay in a project to maintain the right of citizens of this country to show that they are not wage slaves-after all, all that workers have is their capacity to sell their labour, they have very little else; they are not like some rich people in the country who can exploit others-and to maintain some right to sell their labour, and some right to say that there are some things they are not going to do, it is a very small price to pay. The Hawke Government and the Bannon Government are proceeding on a basis of offering that help and encouraging people to take a stand and develop a point of view, a policy and a strategy which will lead to better relations in this country. I believe that they are right and the Liberal Party is wrong.
