DEBATE.TITLE: SOCIAL SECURITY AND VETERANS' ENTITLEMENTS (MAINTENANCE INCOME TEST) AMENDMENT BILL 1988

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator Gareth Evans) agreed to:
That the Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
This Bill is complementary to the Child Support Act 1988. Together they constitute the major elements of the Government's Child Support Scheme.
Many Australian families over the last 10 years have experienced the pain of marriage breakdown.
That is something Governments can do little to help-but Government can take action to alleviate dramatic and sustained drops in living standards for children in those families.
For too long poverty has been the traumatic result of marriage breakdown for children in sole parent families.
This Government is committed to ensuring that by 1990 no child need live in poverty.
The Child Support Scheme is a central part of our programmes to achieve that objective.

The centrepiece of the Child Support Scheme is the Child Support Act which will ensure that parents who have the capacity to pay do not abandon the financial responsibility of supporting their children to the social security system.

The Child Support Act establishes an agency which will ensure that maintenance is efficiently collected from those liable to pay it and that maintenance is distributed to the families entitled to receive it.
The Family Law Amendment Act, which passed through both Houses late in 1987, encourages more substantial awards of maintenance than had been customary previously.
This Scheme overall will increase the number of families receiving maintenance, increase the level of that maintenance and ensure that it is received on a regular basis.

This Bill will amend the Social Security Act 1947 and the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 to provide for changes in the way maintenance income is treated in the social security and veterans' benefits systems.
I turn now to outline the features of the Social Security and Veterans' Entitlements (Maintenance Income Test) Amendment Bill.

The Bill will bring into account a wide range of maintenance income received by social security and veteran pensioners and beneficiaries. The most straightforward of these is cash maintenance paid on a regular basis. At present this is taken into account as income for only some pensions and benefits.
In addition, the Bill will provide for the assessment of in-kind maintenance income.

Maintenance in-kind may take many forms. For example it may be food provided, household items supplied, payments of medical benefits insurance, the provision of housing or payment of rent, payments of household accounts or educational or child care expenses. It could come in the form of payment of motor vehicle registration and running costs.

Another type of maintenance payment which has not traditionally been assessed by Department of Social Security or Department of Veterans' Affairs as income is the transfer of a substantial lump sum of capital, perhaps in the context of distribution of property following a divorce. The Bill will include such capital transfers as maintenance income in so far as they are completed for the purposes of providing maintenance to the pensioner or beneficiary, or his or her dependent children.
The Bill will provide in most cases for the assessment of capital maintenance amounts by their imputation over a number of years. This imputed income will be taken to be received fortnightly.

The Bill seeks to encourage sole parents in receipt of maintenance income to increase total income by seeking other forms of income, especially income from remunerative employment. This will arise through two income test free areas in the Act. One affects maintenance income and the other applies to all other types of income. The advantage which flows from the receipt of both general and maintenance income is a total income test free area considerably more generous than where only one type of income is received. It is expected that additional non-maintenance income will generally be in the form of casual or part-time earnings.

The cornerstone of the scheme is to ensure as far as possible that, where maintenance is payable to a pensioner or beneficiary, it is in fact paid. This will shift some of the burden for the maintenance of Australian children and their parents from the social security and veterans' benefits systems to those who are liable to pay maintenance.

The Bill will further advance this intention by emphasising the requirement that sole parents, in order to qualify for pension, must take reasonable action to obtain available maintenance. Similar provisions have existed for a long time in the Social Security Act.

This Bill will rationalise the requirement and will be supported by departmental guidelines which will balance the public interest in encouraging maintenance action with the factors in particular cases which might render the wisdom of such action questionable. I assure the Senate that action will not be required where there are genuine fears of violence to the custodian or children or where there may be a threat to the security of the custodian or her children.
There are in the Bill special rules which apply to certain types of in-kind and cash maintenance income so as to reduce their effect on the resulting rate of pension, benefit or allowance.

The first of these is all in-kind maintenance income provided by the pensioner's, beneficiary's, or allowee's spouse, or ex-spouse in the first six months following separation. The purpose of reducing the impact of such maintenance income is to facilitate the adaptation by the pensioner, beneficiary or allowee to his or her new situation.

The second is maintenance in cash and in-kind provided in respect of expenses arising directly from any of various disabilities of a dependent child of the person in receipt of pension or other social welfare benefit. This rule will assist in limiting the adverse effect that the receipt of such necessary maintenance might otherwise have on the rate of pension, benefit or allowance.

The final special maintenance category will be in-kind housing maintenance in respect of the home which is the actual residence of the pensioner, beneficiary or allowee. This reflects the importance of secure housing for the children and the difficulties that separated couples often face in providing adequate housing for their children.

In recognition of the disruption that could be caused to some existing pensioners and beneficiaries as a result of these reforms, the Bill will provide transitional provisions for the preservation of the total income of a pensioner or other beneficiary so that maintenance income would not apply to reduce total income. The provisions will benefit the person until he or she no longer needs them because total income has risen above that which applied at the date of commencement of the maintenance income test.

The Child Support Scheme involves major reforms to Australia's family law and social security systems. It will involve the Tax Office and the Department of Social Security collecting and paying out child support. It will achieve more adequate income support for more custodial families in a way which closely links the levels of private and public income support. This Bill is a key element in that scheme.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Tambling) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON LEGAL AND CONSTITUTIONAL AFFAIRS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to give the Government's response to the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs on matters relating to the War Crimes Amendment Bill 1987, to move to take note of the statement and to incorporate the statement in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-
Let me say at the outset that the Government agrees with a number of the Committee's recommendations and proposes to amend the Bill accordingly.

2. I would like, however, to record my appreciation of the Committee's efforts in drawing to the attention of the Parliament a number of significant issues and the possible means for their resolution. In my view, much has been achieved in clarifying the effect of the Bill and in highlighting the procedural safeguards which the proposed legislation encompasses. I am reassured by the Committee's endorsement of the Bill's provisions which ensure that persons alleged to have committed war crimes will be subject to the same rules and processes as apply generally in criminal trials.
3. I turn now to the Committee's recommendations.

4. As to the first recommendation, the present Bill is already cast in terms which would require the normal rules of evidence and procedure to be applied in any trials to which the Act will apply. Accordingly, this recommendation does not require any amendment of the Bill.

5. Recommendations (b) and (c) would, if given effect, represent a significant departure from Federal criminal law where (like the Bill) it deals with indictable offences committed outside Australia. Thus, under s. 70a of the Judiciary Act 1903, the trial on indictment of a Federal offence not committed within a State may be held in any State or Territory (see Crimes (Overseas) Act 1964, Crimes (Hijacking of Aircraft) Act 1972). These Acts have been on the statute book for a considerable time and no suggestion has been put that residence should be the determinant of jurisdiction. Consistent with this regime, the Bill as presently drafted provides that the DPP may choose to initiate proceedings in any State or internal Territory. Further, it is an important principle underlying the Bill that defendants in war crimes proceedings be in the same position as other defendants in ordinary criminal proceedings. However, Mr Temby, in evidence before the Committee, stated that in bringing prosecutions under the Bill close regard would be paid to the place of residence of the prospective defendant, and that he would expect war crimes trials would be brought in a part of Australia where the person resides.

6. In any case, forum non conveniens as a private international law doctrine is not appropriate in the present circumstances. The doctrine has been applied by courts to enable a jurisdiction to be declined where the forum chosen by the plaintiff is clearly inappropriate, i.e. that there is another forum to whose jurisdiction the defendant is amenable in which justice can be done between the parties at substantially less inconvenience or expense, and that the plaintiff would not thereby be deprived of a legitimate personal or juridical advantage which would otherwise be available if the jurisdiction of that court were available. Commonwealth criminal law does not provide for the above doctrine and the Bill should not provide an exception to the usual practice that Federal prosecutions in respect of conduct outside Australia can be instituted in any State or mainland Territory.

7. A further difficulty with recommendations (b) and (c) is that there may well be Australian citizens who are either deported or extradited back to Australia to face war crimes charges but who have no residence in Australia. The Committee's recommendations do not take account of these circumstances nor do they take account of the possible need to limit costs by conducting joint trials in appropriate circumstances. Finally, an important principle underlying the present Bill is that persons prosecuted for war crimes be treated no differently from any other person facing criminal charges in Australia. To agree to recommendations (b) and (c) would be to put war criminals in a special position compared with other defendants.
8. Recommendation (d) is already dealt with in proposed sub-section 13 (2) of the Bill and therefore requires no further amendment.

9. In view of recommendation (e) the Government has determined that the Bill will be amended to provide a discretion in the Attorney-General to authorise such legal and financial assistance as is reasonable in the circumstances. The Government recognises the Committee's desire to ensure that special provision is made for such persons outside the normal provisions of the standing legal aid schemes. A number of other Federal Acts contain similar provisions.
10. Let me now turn to the other concerns expressed by the Committee in relation to the investigation and prosecution of war crimes.

11. Although the majority of the Committee was satisfied that overseas evidence is likely to be of sufficient evidentiary value to warrant the institution of proceedings, it nevertheless expressed concern that prosecutions should not begin until agreements have been concluded between Australia and each country from which evidence is to be obtained, including the 3 countries where undertakings have already been given (i.e. USSR, Hungary and Yugoslavia) that witnesses will be able to give evidence in Australia and have their evidence tested in the usual way. Mr Greenwood obtained initial agreements from the 3 countries to facilitate witnesses travelling to Australia. The agreements are bona fide undertakings by the countries concerned and should in my view be accepted as such-the Canadian/USSR Memorandum of Understanding similarly provides for witnesses to be made available, but only in the context of giving evidence in the USSR. We have achieved a higher undertaking in this regard from the USSR as evidenced by the letter from Mr Greenwood to Mrs Kolesnikova, the Senior Prosecutor for War Crimes in the USSR. Mrs Kolesnikova has affirmed the cooperation of Soviet legal authorities in the implementation of an agreement reached by those officials to the effect that:

The Soviet Government will cooperate with the Australian authorities to encourage relevant witnesses to travel to Australia to give evidence in Australian Courts in circumstances where the witness is not prevented by reason of serious ill health from so doing.

12. I should point out that Mr Greenwood specifically advised the Committee that he believed that in some cases, including one particular trial held in the Federal Republic of Germany, Soviet evidence could be, and in that case had been, corroborated by Western evidence. He also advised the Committee that in respect of another case which may result in a trial in Australia, he was in possession of summaries of evidence from a number of eye witnesses to alleged murder who are presently living in a Western country, and that he had been informed by a Western agency that it is in possession of material from the Soviet Union which tends to corroborate those statements.

13. The Committee was also concerned with access by defendants to prosecution evidence and documents and that any proceedings brought should be instituted by the Director of Public Prosecutions. The defence will have full access to such evidence and documents before trial in accordance with the usual processes. The Bill already provides in proposed section 12 that proceedings can only be instituted by the Director of Public Prosecutions or the Attorney-General.

14. The Committee expressed concern about the use of ex officio indictments. The DPP may present an ex officio indictment where the defendant consents or in certain other circumstances not likely to be relevant. The Attorney-General may present such an indictment at any time. In my view the Government cannot exclude the possibility that ex officio indictments may be required, e.g. where an accused consents or wishes to avoid the ordeal of both committal and trial proceedings, or where a crucial witness is unable or unwilling to travel to Australia twice. In view of the fact that any decision to proceed by way of ex officio indictment will be subject to the control of the court (see Barton v R (1980) 32 ALR 449 at 463-4) the interests of the accused are, in the Government's view, adequately protected.

15. I turn now to the Committee's suggestion that proposed section 7 of the Bill be clarified. The Committee considered that if the subsections are read conjunctively, a `serious crime' will be a war crime only if it satisfies both of the sets of criteria. Alternatively, if a less stringent disjunctive interpretation is placed upon these subsections, a `serious crime' will be a war crime if it falls within either set of criteria. The Committee felt some doubt whether subsections 7 (1) and 7 (3) should be read conjunctively or disjunctively.
16. I agree that it is desirable that the intended disjunctive effect of proposed sub-sections 7 (1) and (3) be clarified. The Bill will be amended accordingly.

17. The Committee was also of the view that having regard to the considerable increase in the number of suspected war criminals (from over 70 in the Menzies Report to the current situation where Mr Greenwood has over 450 individual files of which more than half are being actively pursued) the resources of the Special Investigations Unit and the Office of the DPP be reviewed. The needs of the Special Investigations Unit will be addressed by the Government in the budgetary context.
18. In addition, the Government has already agreed to meet Opposition concerns in relation to the progress of investigations by providing for the tabling of Annual Reports.
19. Finally, I again express my appreciation to the Committee for its report.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the statement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on behalf of the Opposition to give a preliminary response to the Government's response to the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs on matters relating to the War Crimes Amendment Bill 1987. The response is appreciated. The time that the Attorney-General, Mr Lionel Bowen, has indicated will be allowed for consideration of the response before further debate on the Bill takes place is also appreciated. However, whilst stressing that these comments are preliminary-the response has obviously been in our hands for only a short period-the response does not appear to meet some of the major concerns that were expressed by the Committee, nor does it appear that the Government gives the assurances that we believe are necessary to ensure justice in these potential cases.

SPEECH.PARA: The matter must be put in a correct context. In this instance the context is that of a Bill that has raised enormous concerns in communities of those who originated from what is now the Soviet Union or from other eastern European countries. That they might now be prosecuted for crimes which allegedly occurred some 40 years ago on the basis of Soviet and Eastern bloc evidence is beyond their comprehension. It must be remembered that many of these individuals are regarded as enemies of the state by the states from which evidence will have to be adduced in the prosecution of these alleged crimes. These individuals and communities therefore see the cases of prosecutions under the Bill in question as communist states finally catching up with them for their opposition to communism, despite the time that has passed and despite all the freedoms which we claim and believe protect us in this, their new country.

It is easy for us to say that the Australian judicial system, with all its safeguards, will protect these people from improper abuse. In the case of my generation, on the one hand, few have been through the horrors that were experienced by these people. It is much harder for them to have faith in the state. On the other hand, if there are in our midst some who have committed horrendous crimes, even though they were committed in wartime and a long time ago, in the opinion of this side of the chamber they should be brought to justice. But therein lies the dilemma which requires of government, we would suggest, very careful preparation of cases and great sensitivity to the interests of those who fear improper prosecution. The lessons of the United States experience, which were reviewed by the Committee, albeit not in criminal cases, give us reason to take great care.

The general direction of the Committee's conclusions was that great care was needed. The defendants in these trials should not be disadvantaged as against those in any other criminal prosecution that we might institute in this country. Therefore, in the unique circumstances of these trials, special support might be necessary to ensure justice for the defendant. Justice for both sides in a criminal prosecution is obviously of paramount importance. Therefore we said that the trials should be conducted in Australia and that they should be before Australian juries, not on the basis of evidence taken, say, before Soviet prosecutors, as has been the case in some of the United States prosecutions, and that defendants should be given the full protection of cross-examination before an Australian jury.

The Government in its response does not give that assurance. Rather, it says that it regards letters it has exchanged with officials in the Soviet Union, Hungary and Yugoslavia as bona fide undertakings that witnesses will be able to travel to Australia to give evidence. But, firstly, as we stressed in the report, witnesses from these countries have never in the past been permitted to leave their home states to give evidence in Western countries. We said that formal agreement would therefore be necessary to ensure justice before prosecutions were launched. In fact, when one peruses the letters one finds that they are said to be specifically subject to government approval. That government approval has not yet been given, and it seems that the Australian Government is not going to seek it; it is simply going to rely on the letters as bona fide evidence. The letters are, to our side of the chamber, simply no more than statements of intent.

We are pleased to note that the Government undertakes to provide the defence with full access to prosecution evidence and documents before the prosecution in the usual way, but we said in the report that, because of the unique circumstances, the difficulty the defendant will have to get up his defence-to go to the Eastern bloc countries to interview witnesses, inspect sites and do what is necessary to prepare a defence in the Australian circumstance or even a Western nation circumstance-the Government must ensure before prosecutions are commenced that the defendant is able to do so. We put it in recommendations 9.26 and 9.27. The report states:

9.26 The Committee is also of the view that, in the overall interests of justice, prosecutions should not proceed until the Government is satisfied that any defendants in such prosecutions will have access to defence witnesses and be able to visit such sites and examine such archives as is reasonable in the preparation of a defence.

9.27 Further, the Committee is of the view that, when negotiating about the availability of witnesses and documents, the Attorney-General should ensure that the reasonable needs and interests of possible defendants are taken into account.

Such assurances have not been given by the Government in its response today. That is a matter of disappointment to this side of the Senate and something that the Opposition will have to take into account when it determines how it will treat the Bills that will be further debated in this chamber.

The statement on ex officio indictments goes some of the way towards the requirements set out in the Committee's report. I only repeat that, to the Committee, ex officio indictments do not seem proper in this type of case. Furthermore, the flexibility that the Government is now going to give the Attorney-General to give legal aid goes some way towards meeting our concerns, but we would have preferred an absolute assurance.

We remain concerned about many aspects of this matter. The list of alleged war criminals is constantly growing. The Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) in his response says that there are now over 450 cases. We are pleased to note that, as recommended by the Committee, the Government will review its funding for the special investigator in these circumstances. But I put it to the Senate that to properly investigate and exonerate those who should be exonerated will cost this Government huge sums of money, and one doubts that when the crunch comes such money will be expended. How long it will be before individuals are exonerated, goodness only knows. We on this side of the chamber find that a most uncomfortable position.

We are still concerned that it is the easier cases that will be prosecuted, and perhaps not the worst crimes, which might be more difficult to prove. We are still concerned that the trials will amount to show trials-evidence of the Government taking action in this area. As we all know and as Mr Temby said in evidence, funds will run out and that will be the end of this exercise, and that, in the opinion of the Opposition, does not represent justice.

We in the Opposition will further consider the Bill in the light of the Government's response put down this evening. We will consider it with great care and determine our detailed position before recommencement of the debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government's response to the work of the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs with regard to the War Crimes Amendment Bill 1987 illustrates the usefulness of many of the Senate committee inquiries. It has already demonstrated that the Government, upon fuller consideration of the Committee's report, has determined that there are a number of items with which it is in agreement. The Government has indicated, for example, with regard to recommendation (1) and recommendation (5) that it is willing to make amendments. With regard to the problem that the Committee picked up as to whether clauses 7 (1) and 7 (3) were to be read conjunctly or disjunctly, the Government has agreed that it will have the Bill amended. Even those items, although, as we have just heard, the Opposition might not necessarily be totally with the exercise, show on a positive note that movement has been made. Progress has been made as a result of the Committee report, and as such the Bill which the Government now intends to proceed with is even at this stage a better Bill than the one we had previously.

SPEECH.PARA: I think it is important, particularly in the light of the Government's non-acceptance of recommendations (2) and (3), to refer to the fact that the Bill, in dealing with people who will be prosecuted for war crimes, is based upon the principle that these people will be treated no differently from other persons facing criminal charges in Australia. That principle is not totally accepted in the majority findings of the Committee report. Indeed, there are suggestions that one could easily read into the Committee report that it is seeking different treatment for people who are to be prosecuted by having, surrounding that, certain additional items.

As Senator Hill has already said, the principle that underlies a number of his comments is also that there should be differing principles with regard to people who find themselves prosecuted in this situation. I suspect that that really is one of the dilemmas of the context we are facing. From the point of view of the prosecution of these acts on behalf of the community undoubtedly the correct approach is that there should be no difference. From the point of view of the defence, one can, however, see major problems in mounting a defence under these circumstances in terms of costs and other items. I think it is at that point that one can take heart that the Government has accepted the notion that the Bill, with regard to recommendation (5), will be amended to provide for discretion in the Attorney-General to authorise such legal and financial assistance as seems reasonable in the circumstance. One hopes that amendment will not be a reiteration of the previous type of situation whereby the Attorney-General has that type of discretion under other Acts anyhow but that this will in fact provide specific discretion, particularly on the financial assistance which may be necessary to carry out the types of things that Senator Hill has just referred to so that those people can have what we believe is an adequate defence.

However, in saying that I want to make it very clear that our view is as it has been previously; that is, that people who are found in Australia by the Director of Public Prosecutions to have a sufficient case against them with regard to crimes of this nature should be subjected to prosecution. In our view it is not possible to say that such a time has elapsed that it prevents that occurring or that some other items mean that we can forget these things. It is not possible to forget about such items. It is necessary from the point of view of justice in our community to continue that prosecution. I am fully cognisant of the fact and, perhaps along with every other senator here, I have had a considerable number of representations on this issue.

I believe what the Bill is seeking to do, to retain under Australian jurisdiction the entire operation of dealing with these crimes, is the way to go. We wish to bear the cost with regard to that so that anyone who is called upon to defend himself against such a prosecution will have the full benefit of the Australian legal system rather than the probable difficulties that such a person may find whether it be in a jurisdiction of the Soviet Union or in one of the other Eastern Bloc country or countries, for example, such as my colleague referred to today in Question Time, Israel.

Undoubtedly Australians take great pride in their judicial system and in the fairness of that system to be able to adjudicate. Of course, it is not an infallible system. From time to time we seek to improve it. Probably every senator in this place could think of ways in which it could be further improved. We believe it is one of the best systems in the world in terms of the defence of human rights and enabling a person who is prosecuted for crime to have the best means of defending himself. It is upon that basis that we continue to express our support for this legislation.

However, I would not want that to be taken as a definitive statement with regard to the committee stage of this Bill. Fairly obviously, we have not yet seen the type of amendments that the Government wishes to bring forward. We have had a statement that it will be bringing them forward so I certainly cannot commit my party ahead of time to supporting amendments which we have not seen. Upon the production of those amendments, in the debate we will be able to indicate our support or otherwise for them. But I can express our support for the principle of prosecution of people who have committed such murderous and barbarous acts. If we have a case to bring against such people that the Director of Public Prosecutions believes will stand up in our courts we believe it is a matter of justice that such prosecutions should proceed.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr West) I seek leave to make a statement relating to the new Parliament House, to move to take note of the statement and to incorporate the statement in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

Over the past nine years, successive Ministers have had the responsibility of reporting to honourable senators on progress with the new Parliament House. Additional components to cover costs outside the control of the Parliament House Construction Authority have been an allowance of $2.41 million for the cost of industrial disputes, $1.42 million for reinstatement of previously deleted works including two Ministers' suites and the area to house the Australian Protective Service in the southern area of the building.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to bring to the attention of the Senate the considerable concern which is being expressed not only in Victoria but throughout Australia about recommendations that are being brought down regarding the provision of funding for the care in nursing homes of the frail aged. The aged care industry-not just the private operators of nursing homes, many of whom have been wrongly maligned and accused of ripping off the public whereas they have a commitment to the care of the frail aged, but also the voluntary sector, such as the churches and charities which run nursing homes-and the staff of community based nursing homes have joined forces with the dedicated nursing staff, the directors of nursing, the executive officers, the families of nursing home residents and even the frail aged themselves in nursing homes to express their concern about nursing home funding.

SPEECH.PARA: Over the past two weeks I have attended two public meetings. Public meetings have been held in Forest Hill, where 600 people attended; in Camberwell, where over 1,000 attended; in Footscray, where over 200 attended; and Moorabbin, where over 400 attended; and tonight, while we are meeting, it is expected that 600 people will be at Ivanhoe discussing this very issue. This is a large turnout of the public to express its concern about nursing home funding. Peak bodies associated with nursing homes, the Victorian Government itself-a Labor government-and the Liberal Party have called upon the Federal Government for wider consultation and an examination of the impact of the care aggregated model-CAM-before final decisions are made regarding levels of funding.
I would like to bring to the attention of the Senate a recommendation from the Victorian Labor Government to the Australian health Ministers at a conference on 6 March 1988. That recommendation was:
That the implementations of SAM and CAM-
the funding levels for nursing homes-
be deferred in those States where significant reductions are involved until a thorough assessment of its impact on standard of care in nursing homes have been indicated.

Even the Labor Government itself in Victoria is expressing concern about how Victorian nursing homes are being treated. One of the problems is that the nursing home situation in Victoria is different from that in other States. Victoria has fewer nursing home patients per head of population over 75 years of age, and therefore the dependency rate of those people in nursing homes is much higher. The present suggested method of funding of nursing homes will significantly affect those States where nursing home dependency rates are higher. Victoria is one of those States, and South Australia is another. The people of those States are fed up and they are expressing their concern by turning out at public meetings in numbers which have never been seen before in the history of nursing home care in this country, and they are telling the Government that it is wrong.

The industry is saying that the Government has not consulted with it. It is also saying that it is not prepared to test the levels of funding which the Government is recommending. The Opposition has asked the Government to trial the levels of nursing home hours per patient in a government nursing home to demonstrate and test whether the standard outcomes which have been set, the quality standards we would expect for a dignified end to anybody's life in a nursing home, can be achieved. The industry claims that if the number of nursing hours per patient falls below current levels patients will suffer. In fact, we have been presented with 18 areas in which that will occur. I give the example of the Victorian Aged Services Peak Council, which carried out a study last year on 24 nursing homes. Eighty-two per cent of the residents of those nursing homes required complete assistance when bathing or showering. Sixty per cent of them were incontinent; but only 20 per cent of them, given the current levels of funding, could be bathed daily. So the rest go unbathed, using sponges on the intervening days. The industry claims that patients will be left in bed longer, that physical, medical and pharmaceutical methods will be required to reduce demands on nursing hours and that other measures of care will decrease. We are looking at returning to a level of nineteenth century care for the frail aged.

One of the other things that concern me is that if this situation continues, nursing home staff will leave the geriatric scene in droves. It is not a popular area for nursing staff to work in even now, and it will be even less popular as demands increase. A number of studies have shown that nursing home staff carry out an enormous number of lifts. In fact, one study carried out in a nursing home in Melbourne showed that three staff members on a seven-hour shift made 127 lifts, possibly of heavy patients. Some of our Public Service departments recommend that people do not lift more than 16 kilograms, so we begin to see what incredible demands are being made already on nursing home staff. They will leave the area. It will become unfashionable and unacceptable to work in nursing homes. It will be not only the current residents of nursing homes but also future residents who will suffer the long term effects of this departure of dedicated committed nursing home staff from our nursing home scene.

I am not going to go into all the details this evening. The Opposition raised a number of major points in a debate on a matter of public importance in the House of Representatives this afternoon, and I will not reiterate those points tonight. If the Government does not respond to public pressure to demonstrate the viability of its proposals and test them, I will be compelled to present this issue in more detail to the Senate at a later date. I ask the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) to heed the concern of the industry, the families of nursing home residents, the residents themselves and the Government of Victoria and to examine thoroughly the implementation of the care aggregated module until its impact on those States where significant reductions in nursing hours will be experienced are evaluated. In addition, I ask the Government to demonstrate that the levels of nursing hours per patient that it will be funding can, in a trial, provide the quality of care that the frail aged in our community deserve.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K. .

TALK.START.PARA: —While Senator Peter Baume has said earlier that the Estimates committees have restricted the time that senators have to discuss ordinary matters, I think that they have also served to focus on the matter that I want to raise this evening which is of particular concern to me; that is, the mounting evidence that has come to my attention, which I will detail a little later, that the Australian Taxation Office is determined to press ahead with the concept of the Australia Card revisited.

SPEECH.PARA: The background to what concerns me is as follows: on 18 February 1987, the Treasurer, Mr Keating, wrote to the Joint Committee of Public Accounts advising that the Cabinet had given an in principle approval for expenditure of some $693m over a 10-year period to pay for redevelopment and re-equipment of computer systems for the Australian Tax Office. In the same letter the Treasurer requested the Public Accounts Committee to consider the matter and to report back to enable a request for tender to be made by June 1987. The first submission was received from the Australian Tax Office on 27 February 1987. Further information was sought by the Committee and obtained and then a public hearing was held on 30 April 1987. The worrying thing that has come from those submissions and from the public hearing in April 1987 has been detailed by the Public Accounts Committee. It makes very worrying reading. The Committee stated:

. . . the Committee was concerned that the ATO did not have a fallback position for the possible situation where the Australian Card proposal did not proceed. The Committee found that the ATO's Information Systems Plan had a clear agenda for implementing the Australia Card proposal but did not document any alternative courses of action.
Further evidence showed that in terms of existing systems the dividend and interest matching process that it has at the moment is its major activity. The Tax Office stated:
We-
that is, the Tax Office-
are only able to match, by computer, in the region of 60 per cent of the transactions which we receive.
In further evidence it was stated:
If we had nothing more than this new equipment-
which will cost $693m of taxpayers' money-
and the associated systems, but we did not have the facility of the number-
that is, the Australia Card-
used internally and externally (it is uncertain that) the 60 per cent would increase very much at all.

However, it did go on to say that the Tax Office would benefit by being able to identify better areas where there should be selective audits. Subsequent to that after the election was held and a new Public Accounts Committee was appointed, some private briefings were held to bring the new Committee up to date with relevant evidence. Following upon that a public hearing was held on 23 March 1988 and a written submission was made to the Committee prior to that public hearing. The evidence was quite concerning because it clearly demonstrated that the only savings that the Tax Office had decided to show over the 10-year period was some $516m in staff savings. There were no projected revenue figures. But more worrying still was a continued disclosure that a numbering system is still intrinsic to any proposal the Tax Office has. In the written submission I first came to terms with a new number, a CIN number, a common identifying number.

In the evidence that was given-I might say that Mr Boucher attended that hearing together with four of his officers-there was much discussion about this common identifying number. I asked Mr Boucher, `Does the common identifying number presently exist?'. He answered, `No'. I asked him whether, should such a number be introduced, it would be considered that it should have external powers which would require legislative change. Mr Boucher replied that that was a matter for the Government to decide. Since the Australia Card had its demise there has always been an uneasy feeling, in view of the requirement that it would be subject to regulation which could be disallowed, that we would see its spectre present itself again. I think it was Gertrude Stein who said that a rose is a rose is a rose. Perhaps we could say in present parlance that the Australia Card is an identity card is a CIN number. The reason I have chosen to raise this matter tonight--

TALK.START.PARA: —The proceedings are now not being broadcast, you know. You do not have to worry about all this rhetoric. Nobody is listening.

—The essence of what I have to say is important to the people who spent hours, months, protesting and bringing to the attention of the Australian people the dangers that the Australia Card posed to their freedoms.
—Senator Evans does not care about individual freedoms.

—We have noticed that from time to time. The important thing is that the Australian public should be placed on notice that again they will be faced with an attempt to foist upon them a national identification numbering system. When Mr Boucher was giving evidence I asked him, `Did the Tax Office think of the ID card itself or did someone else take the idea to you?' Following some further discussion, Mr Boucher subsequently answered in these terms:

SPEECH.PARA: I cannot, off-hand, recall exactly who else might have had the idea that there were advantages in the external use of a common identifier number. It is an idea that certainly has commended itself to me.

Right through the submissions that have been received there is a common theme-that nowhere is the total expenditure of almost $700m of taxpayers' money justified if such a common identifier number is not introduced, whether it is called a high integrity tax number, which in earlier evidence was said to be on a par with the Australia Card but without a photograph, whether it is the CIN number, or whether it has some other name. The important thing that needs to be addressed here-I have no doubt whatever about it-is that there is a proper need to update the equipment that is presently used by the Australian Tax Office. I laud its every effort to make itself more efficient and therefore able to serve the people of Australia better. Also on 23 March 1988 I questioned Mr Seymour, who was one of the officers in attendance, about whether the lines that presently exist between the mainframes at Deakin and the mainframes at Parkes were secure. He said that no scrambling device was used on those lines. Indeed, I asked whether those lines could be hacked into. Specifically I asked:
So, theoretically at this time it would be possible for a hacker to tap into that information?
Mr Seymour replied:

Let me say that the type of hacking depends upon the devices that the person may have. For instance, you would be aware that in the US the usual hacking terminology is with reference to dial in-people who have a telephone and they can make a connection into a network because that network will respond to a dial in from a telephone. That type of capability is not available in our network.
I then asked:
But there are some extraordinary hackers, too, are there not-the sort of person who managed to get into the NASA network-an extraordinary hacker could tap in?
Mr Seymour replied:
Yes, through Telecom facilities.

So I draw to the attention of the Senate and, indeed, the general public my concern that if an attempt is made to foist upon the Australian public again an equivalent of the Australia Card, when we already have evidence that the existing networks are not secure, I think the debate that raged prior to the last election will truly and properly rage again. People ought to be vigilant in protecting their freedom at all times.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not make a habit of speaking on the adjournment. In fact, I have never spoken on the adjournment, and I may never speak on it again. I must do so tonight because tonight in Alice Springs a meeting is being convened by the Alice Springs Town Council to discuss the disaster caused by the Easter weekend floods in Alice Springs which resulted in serious loss of life and a great deal of property damage. It also caused the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory to make a most regrettable and untrue statement in which he placed the blame for the deaths caused by the floods directly on the heads of the Aboriginal people of Central Australia, and Alice Springs in particular, in their attempts to preserve and protect a sacred site in the Todd River which, according to the Chief Minister, have prevented his Government from implementing flood mitigation proposals. I regret to say that the disaster also caused the Speaker of the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly to make nationally the same outrageous claims as the Chief Minister. In fact, in the 3 April edition of the Sunday Territorian under the heading `Sacred site to blame says Vale' the following article appears:

SPEECH.PARA: The Legislative Assembly Speaker, Mr Roger Vale, has entered the debate over the Todd River's sacred site, blaming it for Alice Spring's devastating flood.
`The sacred site has prevented a flood mitigation dam being built in the northern end of the Todd River,' an angry Mr Vale said.

Statements such as that from the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory in particular, even if there were some substance to them, would be regrettable at the best of times, considering that race relations in the Northern Territory are probably one of the major social issues of daily life in the Northern Territory, 25 per cent of our community being of Aboriginal descent. When such statements have absolutely no foundation at all in fact, it is a matter of even further regret. Last Easter Territorians, like most Australians, were preparing to pack up and head away for a holiday over the weekend. This Easter the residents of Alice Springs had other things on their minds. They were trying to cope with the worst floods in that town in living memory. The total rainfall recorded for the town between the Wednesday and Good Friday was 229 millimetres, which is more than 80 per cent of the average annual rainfall for the region. Most of the rain hit the town on the Thursday and police reported that five people had been washed away when the normally dry Todd River bed turned into a torrent. More than 300 people were evacuated from their homes in low lying areas of the town on Thursday and taken to emergency centres in three schools. It is generally acknowledged that the police and emergency services did a tremendous job in the circumstances.

Unfortunately, as I said before, the same cannot be said of the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory, Steve Hatton, the Minister responsible for the police and emergency services. Mr Hatton seized on the reports of five missing people during a series of television interviews at Darwin Airport and later in television interviews that he did in a studio and that were broadcast nationally. He blamed Aboriginal people for the deaths of the five people because they had blocked government moves to build flood mitigation dams because of a threat to a sacred site. Nothing could be further from the truth. Having contacted the Northern Territory police today, I was pleased to be advised that, although one person certainly has died and a second is missing, presumed drowned, the other three people who were originally reported as missing have since been found.

The custodians of Aboriginal sites in and around Alice Springs have given their approval for flood mitigation work to be carried out, and I have the documentation that proves it. They have in fact expressed concern that the Northern Territory Government's desire to build a recreation dam was removing the emphasis from the much more urgent need for flood mitigation work. I have in my possession some correspondence between the Northern Territory Aboriginal Sacred Sites Authority, the Northern Territory Government and the Alice Springs Town Council. That documentation will prove the falseness of the claims made by the Chief Minister. In order to save the time of the Senate tonight I seek leave to have this correspondence incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The documentation in fact proves that both the Alice Springs Town Council and the Aboriginal Sacred Sites Authority have been trying unsuccessfully since 1984 to get the Northern Territory Government to do something about flood mitigation in Alice Springs. In fact, the Northern Territory Government is utterly to blame for the lack of flood mitigation procedures in Alice Springs. It has been sitting on its hands for four years.

SPEECH.PARA: The Alice Springs Mayor, Mrs Leslie Oldfield-not a Labor supporter, I hasten to add-has, to her eternal credit, pointed out in public statements that the Chief Minister's statement was totally false, as has the Director of the Northern Territory Government's Aboriginal Sacred Sites Protection Authority. Mrs Oldfield rightly pointed out that the Chief Minister's unfortunate statements have done nothing for race relations in the Northern Territory. In fact, I have no hesitation in saying that they were designed for the very purpose of worsening race relations in the Northern Territory. I shall later explain why.

It appears that the Northern Territory Chief Minister, Steve Hatton, and his colleagues conveniently confuse flood mitigation work and a proposed recreation dam, which Aborigines have opposed, when it suits their need to score cheap and, in this case, extremely nasty political points. It would come as no surprise to anyone who has followed the debate on sacred sites in the Northern Territory to read a recent submission from the Northern Territory Aboriginal Sacred Sites Protection Authority on the Northern Territory Government's proposal to convert pastoral leasehold land into freehold. Musso Harvey, the Chairman of the Authority, which I remind honourable senators is the Northern Territory Government's own sacred sites protection agency, has stated in his submission to the Rural Land Use Advisory Committee, which has been established to investigate the proposal, as follows:
In the Northern Territory it is no disgrace for a cabinet Minister to be associated with the desecration of a sacred site.
It is a fact that in the Northern Territory we have had the situation where a Government Minister has been dragged into court charged with the desecration of a sacred site.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who was that?

—Marshall Perron. He, as the responsible Minister, ordered the desecration of a site which was properly registered by his own Government's agency, under Northern Territory law. Those were the days when the former Federal member for the Northern Territory, former Chief Minister Paul Everingham, was running the Northern Territory. All honourable senators know his very public views on Aborigines, their customs and culture.

SPEECH.PARA: When the present Chief Minister, Steve Hatton, assumed the role as parliamentary leader of the Country Liberal Party (CLP) he distinguished himself from his predecessors-I have paid credit to him for it in the Northern Territory Parliament-by adopting a moderate and sensible approach to Aboriginal affairs. He took on the mantle of Chief Minister with a well earned reputation as a man who sought to foster better relations between Aboriginals and the non-Aboriginals in the Northern Territory. As Conservation Minister in the Tuxworth Government he had a very public falling out with Chief Minister Tuxworth on the question of the ownership and control of Ayers Rock. In that capacity he delivered a major statement to the Northern Territory Parliament in support of the return of Uluru National Park to its traditional owners, before being gagged by Mr Tuxworth, who proceeded to spend $300,000 on a national publicity campaign against the handover. Unfortunately, however, it has not taken Mr Hatton long to climb aboard the anti-Aboriginal band wagon. This has nothing to do with Steve Hatton's personal philosophy on Aboriginal affairs. I know personally that he is a small `l' liberal on all sorts of issues.

Unfortunately Mr Hatton has failed to put his leadership stamp on the Northern Territory Government in the way that Everingham was able to. He has had a series of public rifts with Deputy Chief Minister Ray Hanrahan, who has resigned both as Deputy Chief Minister and as a Minister of Hatton's Government, and made statements that the CLP's days in the Northern Territory are numbered. He resigned his position as Deputy Chief Minister because, to quote Mr Hanrahan, he has nothing further to offer the CLP. Hanrahan leads one of the more extremist anti-Aboriginal sections of the CLP and has, as I have said, described the CLP as a spent force in the Northern Territory.

Because of the continual attacks on Hatton's leadership he has to keep the party together by, as he sees it, pandering to the extremist elements in his party. That is why there have been regret- table public statements accusing Aboriginal custodians of Central Australia of causing the deaths of five people in the Alice Springs flood. Incidentally, as I have said, on checking with the police I find, fortunately, that that death toll has been reduced to two. One young Aboriginal woman is certainly dead, and one other person is missing, presumed drowned.

If one were to be the head of the Government in the Northern Territory, one would have to govern for all of the people of the Territory. One would have to recognise that good race relations are an absolutely essential part of the progress of the Northern Territory. To try to score cheap and nasty political points based on a falsehood does not do the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory or his Government any credit at all. The Aboriginal people of the Northern Territory have publicly called on the Chief Minister to repudiate the statements he made on national media, and to publicly apologise for them. He has refused to do so. My personal view is that he must do one thing or the other: either have the intestinal fortitude to publicly acknowledge that he did make statements that were untrue, or resign his position as Chief Minister of the Northern Territory. The one thing that he certainly does owe the Aboriginal people of the Northern Territory is a public apology, and the sooner he makes it the better.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Resources, upon notice, on 15 September 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister for Resources aware that the cost to local Governments of the treatment and disposal of sewage is increasing rapidly, and that this cost increase may be a limiting factor when local Governments decide the safest and most effective means of sewage treatment and disposal.

(2) Will the Minister examine the viability of implementing a national plan for the treatment and disposal of sewage to co-ordinate the responsibilities of local Governments in this area, with a view to ensuring its cost effectiveness and minimise impact on the man-made and natural environment.

In view of the fact that it has been recently re-structured under new Federal Government legislation, will the Minister give consideration to having the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation undertake such a national plan for the treatment and disposal of sewage.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.

(2) Under the Constitution, the responsibility for water and sewerage services rests with the States and local governments who face widely varying difficulties in meeting the need for the economic provision of these services. In such circumstances the Commonwealth would face considerable difficulties in effectively coordinating the responsibilities of all local government authorities.

The Commonwealth, however, can make an important contribution by making available information on possible options for the treatment and disposal of sewage and so enable local communities to decide on the best approach available for their own circumstances. I am therefore encouraging initiatives that will lead to the development of sewage treatment systems that are more economical to construct and operate. These initiatives include a ``State of the Art'' Publication by the Australian Water Resources Council (AWRC) which will examine low cost sewage treatment options for small towns; a national workshop to explore alternative water supply and wastewater disposal technologies and strategies for small towns; and addressing the research needs of water and sewerage systems for both large and small towns under the National Water Research Program.
(3) It is the responsibility of the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation to decide on any involvement in resolving the problems of wastewater and sewage treatment.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The Department of Transport and Communications currently has 1134 officers listed as unattached. This figure includes 140 officers who are inoperative; either on leave without pay or working with other organisations under the mobility provisions.

Of the remaining operative unattached staff, over seventy-five per cent of the officers are at the base-level. Eighty per cent of these base-level staff are located in regional offices and include occupational categories such as air-traffic controllers, who are traditionally recruited unattached.
